title: Create es6 proxy for accessing config slots?
body: Accessing config slots via readConfObject/getConf can be pretty cumbersome, could it be made into es6 proxy?

title: Add style loader to plugin webpack
body:
This adds style loading to the plugin webpack configuration, so that plugins can use CSS and SCSS files. Based off the webpack config in jbrowse-protein-widget.

It also moves webpack to a peer dependency, so that it will just use the webpack of whatever imports it instead of requiring one of its own.

title: Plugin webpack build can't handle static files
body: As an example, if in a React component in your plugin you import a png like ```js import stuffPic from './stuff.png' ``` and use it like ```jsx ```` it will be included in the build, but it can't be fetched because it's looking for it locally, not where the plugin is being served from (below JBrowse is on port 3000, the plugin is on port 9000): ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/88249514-e9862c80-cc61-11ea-9b43-07fdc4550493.png) You can fix it by adding publicPath to your webpack config, e.g. ```js config.output.publicPath = 'http://localhost:9000/' ``` but then that means you have to know where the plugin is going to be hosted when you are building it. I'm not sure if there is a better way. You can also set public path at runtime like ```js __webpack_public_path__ = process.env.ASSET_PATH ``` but I don't think that will generally work for us, either. This would also affect if you had code splitting in your plugin and produced multiple files.

title: Make DrawerWidget be Widget, remove lazy Widget Component export
body:
These are some of the changes I made when getting the embedded linear view working, but I think they deserve a separate PR.

* Make DrawerWidget be Widget, since they may not always be in drawers (e.g. in embedded linear view, they are in a modal). Each product can decide how it wants to display the widget.
* Make Widget pluggable elements have a ReactComponent instead of a LazyReactComponent. This is more consistent with other pluggable elements and allows these plugins to stand on their own better. Each product can still load these lazily if it wants.
* Make main jb-web/desktop app lazy-load view and widget React components

title: Session export/import
body:
User request from BCC2020.

We need to be able to have the user download the session to a JSON file, and then import a JSON file to load a session. We had this for configs back before config and session split into separate concepts, so probably involves updating that code somehow.

This can be a way for people to save/load sessions when they get to be too long for the URL.

title: Re-enable CLI TS lib check
body: Since fancy-test merged https://github.com/oclif/fancy-test/pull/50, we're able to get rid of `@types/mocha` in our yarn.lock and re-enable lib checks in the CLI tsconfig.json.

title: Have a "Show more" and "Copy" button for large fields in alignments feature details
body:
Related to #745 

To reproduce #745 click a long read in the skbr3 bam and then scroll around, should feel a lot slower with the drawer open on master. On this branch it should at least not totally kill performance

Also some related things to #819 general feature drawer improvements. It adds a custom omit list.

Also improves the flag display to display all flags, computed from the flag value

![t1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6511937/88065059-1c350580-cb3a-11ea-9d38-f2da358e38a7.png)

title: Upload built versions zip file to s3
body:
This uploads a built zip file to each branch to s3
Also fixes multiple provider deploy yaml syntax

title: Fix EISDIR error running upgrade
body:
Appears to fix error #1083

Not sure precisely why but the logic is a standard unzip. If we require custom unzipping logic and this is invalid let me know

title: UI display issues with long refnames
body:
Taken from https://github.com/GMOD/jbrowse-components/issues/1082

This is a tricky one because the refname is simply quite large, but it seems like something that must be addressed

- Large refname has a text collision
- The refname dropdown is capable of displaying approx 2 letters before ellipses (sort of related to an older change where we allowed the clear button)
- The locstring box also fails to show the currently displayed region, however this is tricky. The refname is simply long


I think downsizing some of the default font sizes and stuff from material UI could go some ways towards this, but I wanted to track this as an issue

title: EISDIR error during upgrade with node 10
body:
```
jbrowse create test
jbrowse upgrade --url https://jbrowse.org/code/jb2/alpha/master/jbrowse-web-master.zip        test                                                                                              ✘ 130
events.js:174
      throw er; // Unhandled 'error' event
      ^

Error: EISDIR: illegal operation on a directory, open 'static/'
Emitted 'error' event at:
    at lazyFs.open (internal/fs/streams.js:277:12)
    at FSReqWrap.args [as oncomplete] (fs.js:140:20)
```

node 14 does not give this error

title: GFF3 with CSI index shows "Error: Not a TBI file" in linear genome view
body:
<!-- Please fill out as much of the template as you can. -->

**Describe the bug**

I've tried multiple GFF3 files which require CSI index and all of them show the same behaviour. Specifically, the track appears to be added to the configuration correctly as shown below but when I turn it on through the Linear Genome view track selector I see the following error message:

![Screen Shot 2020-07-20 at 3 37 52 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1566301/87989310-09b9be00-ca9f-11ea-9268-628289d9da95.png)

Here is the config file:
```json
{
  "assemblies": [
    {
      "name": "Pisum sativum Cameor v1",
      "sequence": {
        "type": "ReferenceSequenceTrack",
        "trackId": "Pisum sativum Cameor v1-ReferenceSequenceTrack",
        "adapter": {
          "type": "BgzipFastaAdapter",
          "fastaLocation": {
            "uri": "https://v1.legumefederation.org/data/public/Pisum_sativum/Cameor.gnm1.P4FG/pissa.Cameor.gnm1.P4FG.genome_main.fna.gz"
          },
          "faiLocation": {
            "uri": "https://v1.legumefederation.org/data/public/Pisum_sativum/Cameor.gnm1.P4FG/pissa.Cameor.gnm1.P4FG.genome_main.fna.gz.fai"
          },
          "gziLocation": {
            "uri": "https://v1.legumefederation.org/data/public/Pisum_sativum/Cameor.gnm1.P4FG/pissa.Cameor.gnm1.P4FG.genome_main.fna.gz.gzi"
          }
        }
      },
      "aliases": [
        "pissa.Cameor"
      ]
    }
  ],
  "configuration": {},
  "connections": [],
  "defaultSession": {
    "name": "New Session"
  },
  "tracks": [
    {
      "type": "BasicTrack",
      "trackId": "genes",
      "name": "Genes",
      "category": [
        "Genes"
      ],
      "assemblyNames": [
        "Pisum sativum Cameor v1"
      ],
      "adapter": {
        "type": "Gff3TabixAdapter",
        "gffGzLocation": {
          "uri": "https://v1.legumefederation.org/data/public/Pisum_sativum/Cameor.gnm1.ann1.7SZR/pissa.Cameor.gnm1.ann1.7SZR.gene_models_main.gff3.gz"
        },
        "index": {
          "location": {
            "uri": "https://v1.legumefederation.org/data/public/Pisum_sativum/Cameor.gnm1.ann1.7SZR/pissa.Cameor.gnm1.ann1.7SZR.gene_models_main.gff3.gz.csi"
          },
          "indexType": "CSI"
        }
      }
    }
  ]
}
```

**To Reproduce**

1. Execute the following commands in your web root:
```
jbrowse create jbrowse2
cd jbrowse2
jbrowse add-assembly https://v1.legumefederation.org/data/public/Pisum_sativum/Cameor.gnm1.P4FG/pissa.Cameor.gnm1.P4FG.genome_main.fna.gz --name "Pisum sativum Cameor v1" --alias pissa.Cameor --type bgzipFasta
jbrowse add-track https://v1.legumefederation.org/data/public/Pisum_sativum/Cameor.gnm1.ann1.7SZR/pissa.Cameor.gnm1.ann1.7SZR.gene_models_main.gff3.gz.csi --name="Genes" --trackId=genes --category="Genes"
```
2. Navigate to http://localhost/jbrowse2.
3. Add a linear Genome View (File > Add > Linear Genome View)
4. Click the "Select Tracks" button and enable the "Genes" track. It will add the track but the error shown in the above screenshot should be visible instead of the gene glyphs.

NOTE: I'm using a docker image for easy reproducibility. You can access it [here](https://github.com/laceysanderson/jbrowse2play/tree/master/JBrowseUse) including instructions on it's usage. If using the docker, execute the following commands after starting your container rather then those listed in step 1 above.
```
docker exec useJBrowse jbrowse add-assembly https://v1.legumefederation.org/data/public/Pisum_sativum/Cameor.gnm1.P4FG/pissa.Cameor.gnm1.P4FG.genome_main.fna.gz --name "Pisum sativum Cameor v1" --alias pissa.Cameor --type bgzipFasta
docker exec useJBrowse jbrowse add-track https://v1.legumefederation.org/data/public/Pisum_sativum/Cameor.gnm1.ann1.7SZR/pissa.Cameor.gnm1.ann1.7SZR.gene_models_main.gff3.gz.csi --name="Genes" --trackId=genes --category="Genes"
```

 I've also tested this on my debian web server with the same results.

**Expected behavior**

I expect to see the gene glyphs since #797 implies CSI is supported for GFF3 files (confirmed by config being correctly added).

**Version:**

Browser: Firefox 77.0.1 and Chrome 83.0.4103.116

```
$ jbrowse --version
@gmod/jbrowse-cli/0.0.1-beta.16 linux-x64 node-v10.21.0
$ node --version
v10.21.0
$ npm --version
6.14.4
$ cat /etc/os-release
NAME="CentOS Linux"
VERSION="7 (Core)"
ID="centos"
ID_LIKE="rhel fedora"
VERSION_ID="7"
PRETTY_NAME="CentOS Linux 7 (Core)"
ANSI_COLOR="0;31"
CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:centos:centos:7"
HOME_URL="https://www.centos.org/"
BUG_REPORT_URL="https://bugs.centos.org/"

CENTOS_MANTISBT_PROJECT="CentOS-7"
CENTOS_MANTISBT_PROJECT_VERSION="7"
REDHAT_SUPPORT_PRODUCT="centos"
REDHAT_SUPPORT_PRODUCT_VERSION="7"
```

**Additional context**

The public example files used are from Pisum sativum (field pea) Cameor and available for usage here: `https://v1.legumefederation.org/data/public/Pisum_sativum/`. I've also tested this with Lentil but those files are not yet public.

title: drag-reordering tracks in embedded LGV errors
body: Class attendees in the JB2 Embedded BCC2020 session report that drag-reordering tracks in the embedded LGV results in a "no containing view found".

title: Fixes for CLI
body: This fixes some bugs and adds some features to the CLI. If we could get this published tonight it would help the embedding classes tomorrow a lot.

title: Add package version number to drawers
body: Addresses #1071

title: Add code splitting to make loading bar appear faster
body:
Results in about 200kb of JS being downloaded before rendering a Loading indicator. Current master is about 3MB

Ref #1056

title: Don't fail the build on minor style issues
body:
I think that failing the build on a prettier style failure is maybe too drastic, and something that will be cleaned up by future people that see warnings, etc.

This proposes having less total build failures from style checks

title: Multiple JBrowse-CLI updates
body:
Changes for each command

add-assembly

- load flag added for local files. Choose how to get the data directory between copy, symlink, move, and trust

add-track

- add a fail if URL and load flag are passed 

create and upgrade

- revert from extract-zip -> unzipper, extract-zip and os functions had problems on macOS (https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/11422, realpathSync did not fix issue) tried to resolve with @cmdcolin but in the end unzipper is a better current solution
- change tag from JBrowse-2@v1.2.3 to @gmod/jbrowse-web@v1.2.3
- add direct url support to upgrade

title: Simplify command unzip
body:
This is a proposal to use extract-zip to download the jbrowse zip

https://github.com/maxogden/extract-zip/blob/master/index.js

title: Add-track command to cli
body:
description from --help is below
```
USAGE
  $ jbrowse add-track DATADIRECTORY [LOCATION]

ARGUMENTS
  DATADIRECTORY  Data directory file or URL
  LOCATION       [default: .] location of JBrowse 2 installation. Defaults to .

OPTIONS
  -a, --assemblyNames=assemblyNames   Assembly name or names for track as comma separated string. If none, will 
                                      default to the assembly in your config file

  -d, --description=description       Optional description of the track

  -f, --force                         Overwrites any existing tracks if same track id

  -h, --help                          show CLI help

  -l, --load=copy|symlink|move|trust  Choose how to manage the data directory. Copy, symlink, or move the data 
                                      directory to the JBrowse directory. Or trust to leave data directory 
                                      alone

  -n, --name=name                     Name of the track. Will be defaulted to the trackId if none specified

  -t, --type=type                     type of track, by default inferred from track file

  --category=category                 Optional Comma separated string of categories to group tracks

  --config=config                     Any extra config settings to add to a track. i.e {"defaultrendering": 
                                      "density"}

  --configLocation=configLocation     Write to a certain config.json file. Defaults to location/config.json if 
                                      not specified

  --trackId=trackId                   Id for the track, by default inferred from filename, must be unique to 
                                      JBrowse config

EXAMPLES
  $ jbrowse add-track /path/to/my.bam --load copy
  $ jbrowse add-track /path/to/my.bam /path/to/jbrowse2/installation --load symlink
  $ jbrowse add-track https://mywebsite.com/my.bam
  $ jbrowse add-track /path/to/my.bam --type AlignmentsTrack --name 'New Track' -- load move
  $ jbrowse add-track /path/to/my.bam --trackId AlignmentsTrack1 --load trust --force
  $ jbrowse add-track /path/to/my.bam --config '{'defaultRendering': 'density'}' 
```

title: Automatically add sequenceAdapter to CramAdapter and BamAdapter
body:
Adding this will make manually adding sequenceAdapter to the config slot for this unnecessary

Also as I've seen recently, BamAdapter also needs sequenceAdapter in the case of no MD tags being in the file

title: Add command line docs to website
body:
This proposes basically copying over the CLI for the website

It also removes the hello command, and restructures the README a bit for the CLI

It also does some manual line wrapping in the CLI tools for the PDF output, but I think it is also good practice to line wrap this output anyhow

title: Automatically get version in HelpDrawerWidget
body: The version number is hardcoded

title: Small Improvements to create and upgrade testing
body: changes by @garrettjstevens to improve the test files of create and upgrade. Instead of having nock persist, nock is called during the setup of each test. also fixes an EISDIR error by watching for just file entries and making directories based off file locations

title: Use a when to wait on the assembly from the reaction
body:
Due to code from this PR https://github.com/GMOD/jbrowse-components/pull/1038

The waiting for assembly to load was broken

These lines in particular

https://github.com/GMOD/jbrowse-components/pull/1038/files#diff-de94407b67871344a97594d4eb5e8cbfL731-L738

This PR restores an when(() => {}) on the assembly being loaded from the reaction

title: 1059 plugin development
body:
* moves the GDC plugin out into its own repo
* started npm publishing @gmod/jbrowse-core and @gmod/jbrowse-developer-tools
* modules in the ReExports list are now provided to plugins as window.JBrowseExports['module_name'], which is consumable by plugins using [webpack externals](https://webpack.js.org/configuration/externals/), which is part of the base plugin configuration  

fixes #1059

title: React Linear View
body:
This adds a linear genome view React component that functions as described in #1027. There are working examples in packages/jbrowse-linear-view/stories/JBrowseLinearView.stories.tsx.

Getting it to build in such a way as to be able to publish it to NPM is a bit tricky, since normally it would rely on the core plugins it uses being published to NPM, too. I'm working on a solution now (part of the reason this is still a draft).

If anyone wants to poke at some of the visual oddities (like the overview bar), feel free.

Resolves #1027

title: SNPCoverage drawing enhancements
body:
* Draw insertions on SNPCoverageTrack
* Optional drawing of deletion and or skip allele counts on SNPCoverageTrack
* Mouseover counts for deletion, skip, insertion
* Indication of what basepair is being hovered over on the SNPCoverage track
* (possibly even for PileupTrack make it's mouseover indicate the current hovered base instead of the larger feature)



These things are disabled right now because they are misleading in the general case

XRef #1064

title: Fix insertion calculation for SNPCoverage
body:
The insertions were being expanded to cover a range of genome coordinates, causing some weirdness as seen in the below screenshots

IGV
![Screenshot from 2020-07-12 13-33-42](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6511937/87252875-75b77900-c444-11ea-8694-d9cdb4c99d31.png)
JBrowse 2
![Screenshot from 2020-07-12 13-33-52](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6511937/87252876-76500f80-c444-11ea-8dd1-94568723accb.png)
Samtools tview
![Screenshot from 2020-07-12 14-21-22](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6511937/87253673-0d1fca80-c44b-11ea-84cd-b4a02cf96b10.png)

There is a large insertion to the left of these, and the code would expand it so that the insertion would cover the range to the right of the insertions, but that would be incorrect

Now one thing that may be worth noting is that insertions are not not plotted from snpcoverage, and already deletions are also not plotted. Indeed

title: Vertical scrolling track makes a tooltip move
body: Scrolling the track causes the tooltip to go up and down the screen. The tooltip should probably go away on scroll instead

title: Status callback
body:
This is a demonstration of possible status callback


This is somewhat intermediary between progress bar and opaque loading status
#343

It's not completely finished here but I think it is a nice usability add on for large data, curious if the basic concept (basically, attaching a worker.on and worker.off in BaseRpcDriver) is a way to go for this

title: Cross doc links not loading due to s3 appending slash
body:
Both of these are valid url, and can appear via different navigations
http://jbrowse.org/jb2/docs/single_page/#bigwig-tracks
http://jbrowse.org/jb2/docs/single_page#bigwig-tracks

The first does not load pictures. Might need to go back to using mdx with useBaseUrl possibly

title: Data directory concept that contains multiple configuration files
body:
The current config.json file as a concept contains all assemblies and all tracks

If someone wanted to compare human and mouse but has a UCSC scale jbrowse 2 instance, it would load a lot of config data

If there were some orchestration of which assemblies are loaded and a way to modularize configs in a better way, it might make scalability better

The idea of synteny and comparative datasets is challenging but I think having

individual per-species config files
single config file with lots of comparisons

could be one approach (phytozome has a single folder with all vs all species inparanoid comparisons for example, and then per species folders)

title: design and document plugin development workflow
body:
Extract GDC plugin from the monorepo, publish plugin-development-tools package on npm. Get GDC plugin running outside of the monorepo.

Then lay out and document the process for somebody to develop a plugin in an external repository.

Something like: 

* make a repository from the boilerplate repository
* run a dev server for your plugin
* make a test configuration for developing the plugin, that lives inside the plugin repo
* run a local jbrowse-web dev server, and point the jbrowse-web at the plugin's development configuration

body: Fixes #1057

title: lazy worker creation
body:
BaseRpcDriver right now creates all the workers in the worker pool at the same time. This results in all the workers downloading their main "*.worker.js" bundle **in parallel**, at startup, which can easily saturate the user's connection, and results in a long wait for the worker pool to be ready.

If we created the workers lazily, like if `BaseRpcDriver.getWorker` were async, and there was a smarter worker pool object (right now it's just an array), we could create workers on demand, and some of the ones created later could possibly benefit from the HTTP cache of the main worker bundle. That could cut down on total bytes of downloaded JS by quite a bit.

title: jbrowse create CLI command and upgrade CLI command
body:
create: 
```
downloads and installs the latest Jbrowse 2 release

USAGE
  $ jbrowse create LOCALPATH [VERSION]

ARGUMENTS
  LOCALPATH  Location where JBrowse 2 will be installed
  VERSION    Version of JBrowse to download, defaults to latest

OPTIONS
  -f, --force         Overwrites existing JBrowse 2 installation if present in path
  -h, --help          show CLI help
  -l, --listVersions  Lists out all versions of JBrowse 2
  -u, --url=url       A direct URL to a JBrowse 2 release

EXAMPLES
  $ jbrowse create /path/to/new/installation
  $ jbrowse create /path/to/new/installation --force
  $ jbrowse create /path/to/new/installation -u url.com/directjbrowselink.zip
  $ jbrowse create /path/to/new/installation 0.0.1
  $ jbrowse create -l
```


Current setup is that there is a versions.json file in the jb2_releases s3 bucket that looks like
`{ versions: [0.02, 0.01] }`. When create is run with the path argument, it will take the latest version (0 index in the array) and fetch that version's zip file, i.e https://s3.amazonaws.com/jbrowse.org/jb2_releases/JBrowse2_version_0.0.2.zip, and unzip into the path provided. Users can specify a different version if they want an older version of jb2, or specify a url to download that specfic jbrowse release.

NOTE: It's only 0.0.2 to test that switching between different versions would work and that it could detect the latest version. Can change the array to only have 0.0.1 and have the uploaded release end in 0.0.1

update: 
```
Upgrades JBrowse 2 to latest version

USAGE
  $ jbrowse upgrade [LOCALPATH]

ARGUMENTS
  LOCALPATH  Location where JBrowse 2 is installed

OPTIONS
  -h, --help           show CLI help
  -l, --latestVersion  Displays the latest JBrowse 2 version

EXAMPLES
  $ jbrowse upgrade
  $ jbrowse upgrade /path/to/jbrowse2/installation
  $ jbrowse upgrade -l
```
similar to create but needs to have an existing JBrowse 2 installation to run. Also checks the latest version in same way as create and overwrites the existing JBrowse 2 files. In future, if we have a way of detecting the installed JBrowse 2 version, can check with the latest version in s3 bucket and reject upgrade if they already on the latest version

title: Include PileupTrack "sort-by option", "show soft clipping" in track state
body: If we can include these options in the track state that gets serialized, we can generate links that include these things turned on which is helpful just for linking, and might also be important for jbrowse_img type scenarios

title: Add testing for valid VCF END
body:
This is a follow up on a gitter comment where https://solgenomics.net/projects/tomato100 has vcf with END in the INFO field that is less than the start, and actually appears to be basically a bogus value so it is ignored


@garrettjstevens  suggested that we check if it is truly a symbolic field to see if we interpret the END

I tried this out here in this PR but I did have a couple of concerns

1) It is a little unclear of the checking of the symbolic field is really the right behavior here? It seems to work, so as a stop gap it does help this situation
2) It is sort of clear to me that, given that there can be multiple alternative alleles, each alternative allele could have it's own "END" field potentially. this is a little weird, and we could consider this maybe a non-issue and say our "parent variant" is the maximum range of the individual alternative alleles in it's "container"

title: Standardize on "jbrowse-*" for product names
body:
We discussed this a while back but then never made the change. This standardizes on having the `jbrowse-*` directories in `packages/` be our normal distributed products (`jbrowse-web`, `jbrowse-cli`, `jbrowse-desktop`, etc.). It changes `protein-widget` to `jbrowse-protein-widget` and `jbrowse1` to `legacy-jbrowse`.

Also, if we want to have further separation/organization later, yarn workspaces allow multiple workspaces. Right now we just have the single `packages/` workspace, but we could, for example, have a `plugins/` workspace and a `products/` workspace.

title: Generate MD tag from BAM if none supplied
body:
Sometimes one may forget to generate the MD tag on their BAM file as I did recently, and furthermore it makes your BAM file about  ~30% smaller so has some nice savings and performance wise does not seem to cause much notice from quick examination


Xref jbrowse 1 issue https://github.com/GMOD/jbrowse/issues/1022

Note this also PR sort of suggests that adding a sequenceAdapter to BAM in addition to CRAM is needed, and might be good if sequenceAdapter is automatically added

It also was needed to change the sequenceAdapter to a types.frozen, because if it is a equivalent from cram adapter it gave a maximum call stack size exceeded error



Screenshot showing equivalence of the BAM without MD to a CRAM
![calmd](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6511937/86558568-c2242580-bf27-11ea-85b2-7245a05f8225.png)

title: Change block loading to decrease test timeouts
body:
I was having trouble with test timeouts on my branch and noticed that the linear track block loading animation seemed to be causing it. This PR reverts the loading animation to the Material-UI LinearProgress, and is then able to reduce or remove several test timeout increases.

The LinearProgress component is probably not the best, so if we decide to merge this we should probably re-open https://github.com/GMOD/jbrowse-components/issues/968, but seems like a good quick fix for now.

title: Removes most tsconfigs to fix ts errors
body:
When running yarn tsc from folders that are not root, such as alignments or bed, it would return with ts errors. Also, vscode started to show ts errors such as below 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22454194/86183806-abc13880-bae7-11ea-84de-5b12ecd33d2c.png)

This would not cause an issue in travis-ci since travis runs yarn tsc from the root folder which returned 0 errors

The change removes all tsconfigs expect the ones in jb-web, desktop, cli and the root folder. Now, yarn tsc passes when run in any folder and ts errors have disappeared from those files

#967 
Alignments track now do a full track reload when reloaded, previously was only reloading the block that the user selected to reload. Each track model has a reload() action, base action is to reload whole track but specific tracks have additional steps needed before reloading track, such as running get stats or clearing sort. Can also now recover from 404 - file not found error by not caching the error before re-running

title: jbrowse add-assembly CLI command
body:
In addition to the add-assembly command, this PR contains a change so that JBrowse looks for the default config in `config.json` instead of `test_data/config.json`. If there is no top-level `config.json` (which there isn't in our dev builds or a new prod build), it just shows a screen saying JBrowse hasn't been configured yet, and in dev it lists our development configs you can navigate to. For the branch deployment, it copies `test_data/config.json` to `config.json` after building, so our travis-deployed builds will have a default config and the current behavior is preserved.

Here is the documentation auto-generated for this command in the README:

```
USAGE
  $ jbrowse add-assembly SEQUENCE
ARGUMENTS
  SEQUENCE
      sequence file or URL
      If TYPE is indexedFasta or bgzipFasta, the index file defaults to <location>.fai and can be optionally specified
      with --faiLocation
      If TYPE is bgzipFasta, the gzip index file defaults to <location>.gzi and can be optionally specified with
      --gziLocation
OPTIONS
  -a, --alias=alias
      An alias for the assembly name (e.g. "hg38" if the name of the assembly is "GRCh38"); can be specified multiple
      times
  -c, --config=config
      [default: ./config.json] Config file; if the file does not exist, it will be created
  -f, --force
      Equivalent to `--skipCheck --overwrite`
  -h, --help
      show CLI help
  -n, --name=name
      Name of the assembly; if not specified, will be guessed using the sequence file name
  -t, --type=indexedFasta|bgzipFasta|twoBit|chromSizes|custom
      type of sequence, by default inferred from sequence file
      indexedFasta   An index FASTA (e.g. .fa or .fasta) file; can optionally specify --faiLocation
      bgzipFasta     A block-gzipped and indexed FASTA (e.g. .fa.gz or .fasta.gz) file; can optionally specify
      --faiLocation and/or --gziLocation
      twoBit         A twoBit (e.g. .2bit) file
      chromSizes     A chromosome sizes (e.g. .chrom.sizes) file
      custom         Either a JSON file location or inline JSON that defines a custom sequence adapter; must provide
      --name if using inline JSON
  --faiLocation=faiLocation
      [default: <fastaLocation>.fai] FASTA index file or URL
  --gziLocation=gziLocation
      [default: <fastaLocation>.gzi] FASTA gzip index file or URL
  --overwrite
      Overwrite existing assembly if one with the same name exists
  --refNameAliases=refNameAliases
      Reference sequence name aliases file or URL; assumed to be a tab-separated aliases file unless --refNameAliasesType
      is specified
  --refNameAliasesType=aliases|custom
      Type of aliases defined by --refNameAliases; if "custom", --refNameAliases is either a JSON file location or inline
      JSON that defines a custom sequence adapter
  --refNameColors=refNameColors
      A comma-separated list of color strings for the reference sequence names; will cycle through colors if there are
      fewer colors than sequences
  --skipCheck
      Don't check whether or not the sequence file or URL exists
EXAMPLES
  $ jbrowse add-assembly GRCh38.fa
  $ jbrowse add-assembly GRCh38.fasta.with.custom.extension.xyz --type indexedFasta
  $ jbrowse add-assembly myFile.fa.gz --name GRCh38 --alias hg38
  $ jbrowse add-assembly GRCh38.2bit --config path/to/config.json
  $ jbrowse add-assembly GRCh38.chrom.sizes
  $ jbrowse add-assembly GRCh38.config.json
```

Resolves #1018

title: plain-JS wrapper for embeddable LGV
embeddable-LGV state model and theme providers
body:
In `packages/embeddable-linear-genome-view`:

Make some factory functions that make it easy to make a state tree root model, theme provider, and all the other tooling that a JB2 view needs in order to run. If you find yourself duplicating tons of code from elsewhere, try to refactor the core models to reduce duplication.

```jsx
let model = stateTreeFactory({
  assembly:{ /* full assembly config snapshot */ },
  tracks:[ /* array of full track snapshotIn */ ],
  plugins:[ /* optional list of runtime plugins to load */ ],
  location:"chr4:12345..234534",
  defaultSession:{
    /* session snapshot just for an LGV */
    bpPerPx: 1,
    displayedRegions: [ /* list of displayed regions */ ]
   },
  onChange:(mst_patch) => { console.log("something changed in here", mst_patch) }
})
let theme = useDefaultJBrowseTheme()

<ThemeProvider theme={theme}>
  <JBrowseLinearGenomeView  model={model}/>
</Theme>
```

This should not spawn any web workers, it will use the main-thread RPC driver. Should not require any webpack worker support.



Main tasks

- create a pluginManager with a set of core plugins that are necessary to make a linear genome view
- create a stateTreeFactory that is "easy to use"
- pass state tree model to the React component
- fix some small display issues when displaying the LGV in this standalone way

body: Ping timeout appears to result in worker being killed and reloaded, but it is not killed and reloaded in such a way that a track (or other thing) might recover from that error

title: Overview bar over multiple displayedRegions when horizontally flipped
Bundle size/bundle loading
body:
An initial load of the app requires 15MB of javascript to be downloaded, and can take up to 30 seconds to get the refSeq names displayed on this link on a connection like mine

https://s3.amazonaws.com/jbrowse.org/code/jb2/alpha/master/index.html?session=eJxlkFFrwkAQhP-K7HNSYkzF3lux0BakShULFR_Wy2iOJpewdzUV8b_3olKEvi07s9_M3ZEsVyBFb2h7czhnattLkzSJk2GcZot-pgZDlSZ36ejhkyKqWHbGkkoiyoVbyIfJfUFqMMoi2hu0jtTqSCYPyLKNl9PsfvwY7vyh6VImxoLlGbausAzuoNTbrYOf_ZyZm2YG6eZ-4BvXlHxA_o5daNWB1wEkrL-uc2FyvIBzCKktlw63q-ke0hX6k86Xc5TQvpbFpU9hICy6MJrL0MUVdbvobBPeoAwpXr5xWY9hPaTrfwWe1jdfsIMP7uMpItbe7PH0X9C1tSE6vOTVOs9W4yycfgGYY4Mu


There are several stages of loading which includes first javascript bundle for the main thread, and then, each worker individually downloading the same ~2.8MB bundle which is actually literally downloading it four times, the resource is not singly downloaded once.

The refName loading on the ImportForm for LGV and in the header bar for the LGV have the same loading pattern using the worker to do a getRefNames. We could make this faster if we made the getRefNames for the assembly did not use the worker, but this may just "kick the can" for downloading the worker bundles down the road a bit. It might be warranted if it improves perceived performance though

![Screenshot from 2020-06-24 10-39-26](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6511937/85577400-321cdc80-b607-11ea-99dd-b4807d7a0a5f.png)

See screenshot for 30s loading time end to end for a fresh load of the page.

title: runtime plugins
body:
Draft PR for runtime plugin loading. Salient changes:

* booting the main thread and the workers now calls a PluginLoader to load all the runtime plugins, then installs them into the PluginManager after they are loaded
* every Plugin is now supposed to have a `name` attribute, which is the string name of the plugin
* plugins can now have `exports` attributes on their plugin object that they can use to runtime-export things that other plugins can use. LinearGenomeViewPlugin is doing that in this PR so that the GDC plugin can use its base track models.

fixes #337

title: Hi-C visualization
body:
Still WIP but I thought this is a nice demo

Uses DynamicTrack with custom renderer. It overrides a couple base ServerSideRendererType functions such as the getFeatures function becuase the features returned are not simpleFeatures as far as I can tell, just data like {bin1:800, bin2:850, counts: 1000}  but these correspond to genome range queries

![hic](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6511937/85189395-d2c47280-b27c-11ea-8586-f162a5c0e426.png)

This is just a proof of concept but leverages the hic-straw library from Jim Robinson, had to make a small modification to the library (removing checks for "navigator" in his remoteFile code...could possibly make his code work with generic-filehandle or similar as an alternative)

Deleting these lines from hic-straw remoteFile
```
            const isSafari = navigator.vendor.indexOf("Apple") == 0 && /\sSafari\//.test(navigator.userAgent);
            const isChrome = navigator.userAgent.indexOf('Chrome') > -1
            const isAmazonV4Signed = this.url.indexOf("X-Amz-Signature") > -1

            if (isChrome && !isAmazonV4Signed) {
                url = addParameter(url, "randomSeed", Math.random().toString(36))
            }
        }
```


Still a draft PR but makes a good demo

#hic

See #1012 for issue

title: jbrowse-cli set-default-session
body:
jbrowse set-default-session --view 'LinearGenomeView' --tracks 'trackId1,trackId2' will set the view chosen and tracks named as the default session

Note that the logic here might have to look up the trackId1 track type to create an accurate session

jbrowse set-default-session /path/to/defaultsession will grab a file at the specified path and use the containing info as the default session. If there is a previous default session set it will override and let the user know that a new one has been set. 

Users will be able to use either to set up their default session, and possibly can have a flag to see what the current default session setup is so they can choose if it needs to change

title: jbrowse-cli add-track
body:
Make a new jbrowse-cli subcommand for adding track configuration.

Args to support:

* trackId (optional, inferred from filename, will validate that this is unique in the current config)
* name (optional, can take trackId as value if none specified)
* category (optional, can be a comma separated string)
* description (optional)
* type (optional, autoinferred, consider also, while implementing, whether we want to support this option at all because if autoinference fails, then it seems to immediately jump into a more advanced config mode)
* config (accepts JSON string that gets deep-updated into the new track config)

Positional args

* single filename or URL
* assemblyName (single) or assemblyNames as comma separated string. If none is provided, and there is only one assembly, then use this one, and stderr that this assemblyName was used. possibly we can also allow assembly alias


Example commands to support:
* `jbrowse add-track /path/to/my.bam` will add an Alignments track called 'my' in the default category, with BAI file automatically inferred as /path/to/my.bam.bai

We will want to consider what to do about file system file paths e.g.

With /path/to/my.bam  we could have options to copy, move, or symlink the file into the data directory


One goal of the add-track is to have a streamlined base case scenario that makes adding tracks very simple, hence the autoinference of storeClass, track type, and then we can add some progressively more advanced options for users

title: jbrowse-cli add-connection
body:
```
jbrowse add-connection hg19 http://mysite.com/jbrowse/data/
jbrowse add-connection hg19 http://mysite.com/jbrowse/custom_data_folder/ --type JBrowse1
jbrowse add-connection hg19 http://mysite.com/path/to/hub.txt
jbrowse add-connection hg19 http://mysite.com/path/to/custom_hub_name.txt --type UCSCTrackHub
jbrowse add-connection hg19 --type custom --config '{config here}'
```

Can also define name with `--name`, by default will guess a name.

title: jbrowse-cli create and upgrade
body:
`jbrowse create /path/to/new/installation` will download the latest JBrowse 2 release zip and install it at the given path. If the given path contains an existing installation, it will refuse to overwrite it unless the `--force` argument is passed.

People should be able to bootstrap a new JBrowse 2 by running `npx @gmod/jbrowse-cli create /path/to/new/installation`

`jbrowse upgrade /path/to/installation` will download and unpack the latest JB2 on top of another one, making sure not to overwrite any configuration. If at a later date we have configuration file migration scripts (upgrade one version of the config to a new version), those will be run with this command as well.

Also make a small executable called `create-jbrowse` that makes it so people can also make a new JB2 by typing `yarn create jbrowse /path/to/installation`

title: Cached abort detected, infinite loading
body:
This is a bit hard to reproduce but it's happened to me several times today

I am looking at for example the GFF3Tabix NCBI track in the config_demo.json

Using a very fast side scroll (touchpad) while the track is loading seems to be a possible trigger for this

![Screenshot from 2020-06-17 22-54-02](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6511937/84972722-7a129f80-b0ed-11ea-84b5-41cb18dd9fe5.png)

title: Guide hover tooltip is ~0.5bp off
body: The base pair count changes in the middle of a base

title: Add longer timeout for jbrowse test
body:
Unfortunately the cause of some slowness in #1008 is sort of unclear. There are some patterns I observed

- Using only pako can improve some performance, e.g. remove nodeUnzip
- Using gunzipSync can improve some performance, e.g. change nodeUnzip to use gunzipSync 
- There was another thing where we can sometimes reduce the amount of data we unzip in the BAM header because it by default adds two BGZIP blocks onto the end of the first request (indexData.firstDataLine + 65535 and then again). These added blocks are probably paranoid, and can likely be removed, only unzipping up to firstDataLine which improves some performance
- Other general BAM header and BAI index parsing improvements could be made (the babelization of the BAI parsing seems to result in some inefficient code sometimes, too much abort checking while parsing BAI header, etc)


 All those things could be done, and it could cut down on BAM setup time. For now, it seems like just adding a timeout is helpful though, and if there is any feedback I can go and make some of the other changes here.


This PR also adds node14 to the build matrix

Also, while it seemed to affect that particular test a lot, it's not clear if it particularly affects this test super badly, as any BAM test seems to be affected, it's just this one ended up standing out somehow.

title: Overview rubber band fixes
body:
I was navigating using the new overview rubber band, and found a situation where selecting a region caused a crash. See the added failing test in 2ebe710c2ce7825a117180725298c79ee9ce4fc6.

While looking at the zoomToDisplayedRegions code, I had an idea for a new algorithm for determining where to navigate to. Basically it does this:

- For each displayed region, check if it intersects with any the selection regions
  - If it does, use that region and selection to calculate a start offset and an end offset
  - Only set the start offset once, and update the end offset with each new overlap
- If there were any overlaps, use moveTo to navigate to the offsets (no longer uses navToMultiple)

This change passes all the previously existing tests as well as the one I added that was originally failing.

Also has one small change so that you have to select more than 3 pixels to trigger a navigation (this matches the behavior other rubber band).

One note on the bit of reorganizing I did on the overview rubber band tests, I was trying to separate each case out into its own test. For naming, I used [this suggestion](https://jasmine.github.io/2.6/introduction#section-Grouping_Related_Specs_with_%3Ccode%3Edescribe%3C/code%3E) that the `describe` and `it` parameters when combined should form a sentence.

title: Test 'renamed refs -> test that bam with contigA instead of ctgA displays' failing on node 14
body:
Above test fails on local machine 100% of the time with following message: 

-  test renamed refs › test that bam with contigA instead of ctgA displays

    expect(received).resolves.toBeTruthy()

    Received promise rejected instead of resolved
    Rejected to value: [Error: Unable to find an element with the text: ctgA_110_638_0:0:0_3:0:0_15b. This could be because the text is broken up by multiple elements. In this case, you can provide a function for your text matcher to make your matcher more flexible.

Does pass on travis-ci and mostly passes on @cmdcolin  local machine, may have something to do with OS or node version? My local machine specs are OSX v10.15.4, node v14.0.0. Did a fresh clone of repository and issue was not solved

title: Add rubberband functionality to LGV Overview Bar
body: PR adds rubberband functionality to the LGV overview bar. Users may click and drag on the overview bar and zoom into displayed regions. Similar to the regular rubberband, a tooltip is shown that guides the user where they are on the overview bar, and two popover labels indicate what start and end of the zoom is selected in addition to a box indicating the selected area.

title: add a shortId to configurations, have sessions include the config ID and validate it
body:
Make each configuration have a `id` attribute in the root that is a shortId.

Add a `configId` attribute to sessions that contain their corresponding config ID.

If you try to load a session and the config ID doesn't match, throw an error or something (implementor will need to figure out the details).

title: Config/session issues and proposed solution (single config)
body:
Lately I've been having questions about config and sessions, so I wanted to explain some of my questions and problems and propose a solution. Here are some of the potential problems/issues I've seen:

- In jbrowse-web, saved sessions are in the config, but the config is not editable by a user.
  - If we move sessions to localStorage, we need some reliable way of saying which session belongs with which config. Would have to use the location of the config in the localStorage key, maybe, but that seems a bit complicated and potentially unstable.
- If you had a session that was too big for a URL, currently the only way to share it is to export it as JSON so someone can re-import it (functionality actually probably broken right now, but could be fixed easily). Same as above, need some reliable way to say what config that session belongs to.
- jbrowse-desktop only has a single config. If jbrowse-web supports multiple configs, do we need to do that in jbrowse-desktop as well?
- There's no way to switch configs in the UI, we just have to "know" the right URL and enter it manually.

#### My proposal

I propose we only have a **single config** for jbrowse-web. Here are some of the potential drawbacks of a single config, and how I propose to mitigate them:

- **Environment separation** - Right now we have a small "production" human config, a more extensive human config with tracks we use a lot in development, and a volvox development config. I propose having these all in the same config and adding **global** and **session filters**. With these filters a user could include (or exclude) whole assemblies or individual tracks (maybe based on some track metadata). That way we can still only show a subset of the whole data, but still have one config. Note that these filters would just visually filter the assemblies/tracks from things like the assembly selector drop-down or track selector. The assemblies/tracks would still exist and if a session used one of the filtered assemblies/tracks it would still be valid.
- **Sample separation** - Perhaps a researcher only wants to see tracks from a specific sample. Instead of having a separate config for each sample, you would use filtering in your session as described above to filter by sample.
- **Config size** - One concern is that a single config JSON could get too big to be easily worked with. We've already said we want our tracks to be able to have multiple sources, so if we're still committed to that, we could split tracks out into separate JSON file "sources" and control the size of the config that way.

Some of the advantages of a single config are:

- Sessions no longer have to be associated with a particular config, so complexity in saving/sharing sessions is reduced
  - Moving saved sessions out of config into localStorage would be easy
- Don't have to worry about UI for config switching
- Don't have to worry about supporting multiple configs in jbrowse-desktop

One other thing I would like to propose is that sessions in jbrowse-web aren't saved automatically, you have to File->Save them manually. If we add a new session in localStorage every time you go to a URL that has a session in it, they'll add up quickly.

title: Adaptive headroom wiggle base
body:
This adds an "adaptive headroom" that is rounding up to the nearest 2^n basically

This works for positive and negative values

It also adds a value before rounding to the nearest 2^n so that it doesn't round to like "4" when there are 3 base pairs, it will round to something like 16 which I think for most cases is better

For fractional values it does not apply this adaptive headroom

fixes #996

title: jbrowse-cli boilerplate
body:
This adds boilerplate (just a simple hello world command) for jbrowse-cli so that we can decide if we agree on this before adding any specific commands. The framework used is [oclif](https://oclif.io/).

If you're in the jbrowse-cli package, the base command is `./bin/run`, which will show the help and the availabe commands. The hello world command can be run with `./bin/run hello`. Here's some example output:

```
$ ./bin/run
A command line tool for working with JBrowse 2

VERSION
  @gmod/jbrowse-cli/0.0.0 linux-x64 node-v12.14.1

USAGE
  $ jbrowse [COMMAND]

COMMANDS
  hello  describe the command here
  help   display help for jbrowse
```

```
$ ./bin/run hello --help
describe the command here

USAGE
  $ jbrowse hello [FILE]

OPTIONS
  -f, --force
  -h, --help       show CLI help
  -n, --name=name  name to print

EXAMPLE
  $ jbrowse hello
  hello world from ./src/hello.ts!
```

```
$ ./bin/run hello
hello world from ./src/commands/hello.ts
```

```
$ ./bin/run hello --name Sam
hello Sam from ./src/commands/hello.ts
```

And a screenshot to show some of the formatting:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/84315616-28837700-ab27-11ea-9008-d8da0db33b36.png)

oclif has support for publishing the CLI to npm and as a bunch of different kinds of installers/packages (e.g. .deb, snap, Windows installer, macOS installer). Those installers bundle node with the CLI, so the user wouldn't necessarily have to have node installed.

title: Remove usage of display:flex in the feature details drawer
body:
We found that usage of flexbox in the basic detail drawer widgets was basically unnecessary, and actually caused some slowdown when it contained long reads related to #745

Doesn't completely solve #745 still, but this just suggests removing the unnecessary style element

title: Use repeater element to make denser messages
body:
![Screenshot from 2020-06-10 16-33-19](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6511937/84316629-6d180e00-ab39-11ea-8f75-24018f19dc57.png)


Without this change

Also removes BlockError dependency from other modules on the linear-genome-view's BlockError...this is a pretty clear instance of too much DRY (dont repeat yourself)

title: Zoom in sort test so individual read order doesn't matter
body:
For the alignment sort test, this changes the alignment track and zooms in so the snapshot of the block only has three reads, all of which span the whole width of the block have no snps/indels/etc. This means that as long as the sorting works (red read on top, blue reads on bottom), the snapshot test will pass, since even if different versions of node sort the blue reads differently, they are visually the same.

There may be other ways to address different versions of node sorting differently, but this is the simplest one I could think of.

Fixes #997

title: Restore old breakpoint split view
body:
This PR restores the old breakpoint split view

It seems like it is important to keep that demo alive, and it actually works quite well for it's purposes, and I think it's worth restoring

I think it helps,even during large refactorings, to keep things working throughout the refactoring and as breakpoint split view was subject to the large linear_comparative refactoring and was broken (#964 ) this seems like it would be worth restoring the old version until we can get the new one working properly

title: Soft clipping not rendering beyond a certain point
body:
If you are zoomed in and then try to have soft clipping turned on, it stops rendering past a certain point even though tooltips are there

![Screenshot from 2020-06-09 20-03-38](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6511937/84212657-739c7c00-aa8c-11ea-9bac-10e0859101b0.png)

title: Alignment sort test fails in node>=11
body:
In JBrowse.test.js, the test `alignments track : selects a sort, updates object and layout` fails on node versions 11 or greater.

The reason is that node v11 updated to V8 v7, which [included a change](https://twitter.com/mathias/status/1036626116654637057) that made `array.prototype.sort()` stable. The difference in sorting implementations means that the features in the test get sorted differently when run in node<11 vs node>=11.

V8<7 supposedly only used the unstable sort for arrays with more than 10 elements, so I tried updating the test so only 9 features were sorted, but I'm still getting different results in v10 vs v12.

title: Adaptive headroom for wiggle tracks+SNPCoverage
body: The current headroom argument creates a constant increase above max value, but something that is like N% of the threshold would be good

title: convert circular view to be canvas-based
body:
The circular view is currently SVG based. It's becoming clear that this isn't going to be performant, because it just makes too many DOM nodes.

It seems like the biggest challenge in making canvas-based circular views is going to be allowing mouse event handlers to continue to function correctly, for example, to enable clicking on arcs. The best approach we can think of so far for this is to make an invisible canvas that has a numeric ID of the object that is under each pixel, so when you interact with the canvas, it looks up the ID of the thing that is under that pixel, and runs a handler on it.

title: BAM parsing optimization
body:
This addresses #969 

The performance is about 3x as fast, measured here

https://jsperf.com/md-parsing

This does so by adjusting CIGAR parsing and MD usage of the CIGAR

title: Make sure bpPerPx and offsetPx are clamped
body:
This makes sure that all places in the LGV model that modify `bpPerPx` or `offsetPx` use `zoomTo(bpPerPx)` and `scrollTo(bpPerPx)`, which makes sure they are properly clamped. Before this, using setDisplayedRegion might result in the new region being completely offscreen (the root cause of #987), but now the clamping ensures that any new regions are on screen.

Also removes `showAllRegionsButSlightlyZoomedIn` since with bpPerPx being clamped, you never end up with the displayed regions square with the overview scale bar.

Bumps [websocket-extensions](https://github.com/faye/websocket-extensions-node) from 0.1.3 to 0.1.4.

title: More options for smooth zooming
body:
This is kind a "wish list" item, but I think smooth zoom out with slider or ctrl+wheel would be very cool. The current zoom animation demonstrates that it "is possible" to do this, so I am wondering if it could be extended to be user controllable.

Zooming out is sometimes a slow operation, yet zooming in and out on genomic context can be quite useful. Also, jbrowse 1 had a big magnifier to zoom in/out farther which might be useful

title: Make navigating via RefNameAutocomplete create a "showAllRegions" type view
body: This fixes #987 by navigating to a new refName causing basically a "showAllRegions" but I make it slightly zoomed in because it looks a little nicer that way (has a nice trapezoid pattern a la jbrowse 1 rather than both overview bars being square with each other)

title: Alignments track refactor #2
body:
This is additional refactoring that addresses the following needs

1) Designate PileupTrack to be in control of sorting and showing soft clipping, which was till this sort of dependent on being contained in a AlignmentsTrack (RE: #981 )
2) Remove the usage of Sort by being in a view menu, making it a per track option (RE: #982 )
3) Makes it so that the "Show pileup track", "Show coverage track", "Show softclipping" remain with the text "Show" with a checkbox to indicate the status of it being shown (previously toggling between "Show/Hide" which to me can be slightly jarring)

Base branch is alignments_track_refactor to be clear that this adds on to it, but it is basically independant from that branch

title: Crash on switching refName
body:
I was pairing with Shreya and we uncovered a bug where switching refNames on from ctgA to ctgB produced a crash

It is not clear yet exactly how we got here but the session URL here is reproducible

title: Remove @typescript-eslint/recommended-requiring-type-checking
body:
I think maybe we can remove @typescript-eslint/recommended-requiring-type-checking rules

It was something I added in the first place but I think it just wastes cpu

Running eslint ~20 second less without it for me, and I think the rules in it are not that interesting, garretts script/getSuggestions is basically doing the same thing probably

title: Alignments track refactor to make each subtrack use it's own ReactComponent instead of relying on AlignmentsTrackBlocks
body:
This refactors the alignments track to simply use the full featured ReactComponent that the subtracks are designated to use

This avoids a fair bit of strangeness in the code I think

Also typescriptifies wigglerendering as an aside...pretty tiny

title: Add refNameColor to LGV overview
body:
May or may not be something we want to do, but this is just a small change that adds the refNameColor (currently used in the circular view) to the LGV overview.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/83677003-c364da00-a598-11ea-8ce6-e7c44bf3583d.png)

title: Discoverability of the sort read options
body:
This is maybe debateable but to me, the "Sort reads feature" now lacks discoverability.

I think it is not intuitive that you have to go to the view menu to turn on this option. I know this was something that had some various different arguments during grooming.

My original stance was that the way the feature was ORIGINALLY demo'd, which had a right click that turned the setting on for all tracks in a way that emulated IGV behavior very precisely, was fine. But we then decided that we should make this function, and turn it into a new menu. I think this reduced discoverability, and if we need to just turn on per track sort to have a track menu item for per-track sort, that would be better IMO

title: Refactoring PileupTrack to behave as a standalone unit again
body:
Currently PileupTrack crashes if run as its own track type, because it tries to reach to the parent track for the showSoftClipping parameter


I think that the PileupTrack should "own" this parameter and then the AlignmentsTrack "looks at" the Pileup model to create extra track menu items based on that

title: Add "notify" to session
body:
Makes session have a "notify" action instead of "pushSnackbarMessage". Also adds levels to the snackbar messages. Uses the levels in jbrowse-web and -desktop for customized snackbar messages:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/83579656-1a19d780-a4f7-11ea-8fbe-fed58d8d957c.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/83579693-30279800-a4f7-11ea-9f14-d65166d14752.png)

Resolves #975

title: Add Admin Mode to jbrowse-web
body:
The basic idea I was trying to work with was to make `editConfiguration` not be a required part of a Session, and so some things can get enabled/disabled when they detect `editConfiguration`.

It also adds an `adminMode` flag to the root model, so plugins can check that when e.g. adding menus.

Admin mode in jbrowse-web can be turned on with `admin=true` or `admin=1` in the URL.

Resolves #741

title: Make URL update debounce instead of throttle
body:
@cmdcolin mentioned that while the throttle on the URL update made it so there was sometimes some scroll jank if you were continuously scrolling, and I started noticing it as well. This makes it so the URL update is debounced, so e.g. it will only update when you are done scrolling.

There was similar behavior to this before #976, but it had to be removed since useDebounce was causing errors. This adds a debounce function that is not a hook, since updating the URL is not a stateful update.

title: Fix tooltip handlers
body:
This attempts to fix tooltip handlers by moving logic into the track component

I think the groundwork for this was already there and the current PileupRendering was circumventing it by trying to inject too much logic into the renderings including the tooltips

I believe by taking it out of the rendering and putting it in the "track" it will become more clear how responsibilities are located

title: Update URL without useState
body: Xref #961

title: Change pushSnackBarMessage to generic notification in Session
body:
The session will have a generic `notify` action, and each app can implement the notification as it sees fit (e.g. jbrowse-web will be a snackbar).

Should also take a notification level: `error`, `warning`, `info`, or `success`.

title: Low CPU usage loading animation
body:
This is a low CPU loading modification

Could look at actual spinners too but this seems like it is not too bad

Note the removal of textAlign center because the text changing length causes the center to move so it is simply left aligned now

title: Reduce re-rendering of track blocks
body: This suggests to remove the index parameter from the TrackBlocks in favor of blockKey which can incorporate the index from the displayedRegions (ref 2362665866)

title: Add some optimizations to improve FPS
body:
There were quite a few things that get constantly re-rendered at each frame including

TrackContainer and all children such as TrackLabels
RubberBand which included all children
All VerticalGuides
All scale bar contents

Also removes the usage of children in VerticalGuides/RubberBand because I observed that the  usage of it was

```
<>
   <SomeStuff>
   {children}
</>
```

This implied to me that since it was a React fragment, it didn't really need to actually be using children

FPS for various parts of the app are restored to 60FPS

Applies to #117 (side scroll slow on firefox) but similarly accelerates chrome just because it accelerates a lot of per frame work

Fails opening the zoom scroll menu currently but should be fixable

title: JBrowse desktop produces error on empty regions
body:
Has error 'cannot read dataURL of undefined' at start of chromosome, and affects BAM and CRAM it seems

Scrolling to where there is content results in it being working

Was using this to try to inspect alignments on a file that would otherwise be cors blocked

```
TypeError: Cannot read property 'dataURL' of undefined
    at ElectronRpcDriver.ts:99
    at async PileupRenderer.renderInClient (ServerSideRendererType.ts:159)
    at async renderBlockEffect (serverSideRenderedBlock.ts:270)
setError @ serverSideRenderedBlock.ts:113
```

title: Finish converting icons to SVG
body:
This is just a quick follow-up to #924  that finishes converting all our icons to SVG icons. Also adds a couple icons to core that were in the icon font but not in Material-UI's icons. They were in a previous release of Google's material design spec, but have been removed, so Material-UI no longer has them, but they're still useful icons.

Finishes resolving #894.

title: alignments track performance optimization
body:
Do a round of performance optimization on the Alignments track. Run some profiling, try to figure out where time is being spent, and try to improve the time it takes to render large alignments.

Main categories of stuff that takes time:
* downloading the data
* parsing the data using `@gmod/bam-js` or `@gmod/cram-js` 
* rendering in the worker onto an OffscreenCanvas
* shipping the features, layout, and rendering to the main thread
* deserializing the features, layout, and rendering on the main thread (mostly native code that we don't see)
* hydrating the rendering on the main thread (ServerSideRenderedContent.js)

Might be worth it to run some profiling on igv.js to compare/contrast where it is spending its time vs. where JB2 is spending time.

Might also compare BAM vs CRAM, to see how they differ.

Main deliverable for this is to know where time is being spent and develop a prioritized list of optimizations that we should do.

title: less resource-intensive LGV loading markers
body:
The current animation for LGV block loading is very nice, but if you have a lot of tracks open and loading, the main thread gets pretty busy just running all those animations.

Also, there is a small bug with the height of the loading indicator, at least in the Alignments track.

title: AlignmentsTrack needs to be able to recover from WiggleGetRegionStats failing
body:
To reproduce

* open a lot of bam files and try to get WiggleGetRegionStats to time out
* the SNPCoverage subtrack of the alignments track should get stuck in the error from the stats failure: 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/73749/83289293-b3648900-a199-11ea-83bb-43d5d178dafa.png)

expected behavior is that it should retry the stats fetch at some point

title: Create storybook configuration
body:
I think that having a storybook configuration that can be browsed will be valuable for a number of reasons

a) enforces testing individual components, so facilitates things like jbrowse embedded and even smaller reusability
b) browsable set of examples
c) fun

Not working yet, ends up 100% cpu'ing but it is an exciting start

![localhost_9009__path=_story_pluginmanager--text (1)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6511937/83241714-3e795b00-a169-11ea-8085-7eb776dc2b21.png)


The rescripts-use-yarn-workspaces had a storybook addon which made this work at least up to this stage which was pretty lucky to get this to play nicely with CRA+monorepo+rescripts

title: Check config for session loading
body: This applies the "useLocalStorage" and "useUrlSession" to loading as well as persisting sessions, also renames "updateUrl" to "useUrlSession"

title: Breakpoint split view connections not appearing
body:
Breakpoint split view connection lines aren't showing up. See https://s3.amazonaws.com/jbrowse.org/code/jb2/alpha/master/index.html?config=test_data/breakpoint/config.json

Git bisect points to merge of #848

title: Add integration testing for SV inspector demo
Update deps and fix a material-ui warning
body:
In the ever-evolving js ecosystem, it is nice to stay updated

This gave a warning about our autocomplete mixing controlled and uncontrolled state however, probably due to a typescript correction that first made me change null->undefined, and then triggered this material-ui warning


https://github.com/mui-org/material-ui/issues/18173

I tried fixing this by making it so the key changes when it is correctly initialized.

title: Move updateUrl and useLocalStorage logic to rootModel for jbrowse-web
body:
Addresses a dev warning that we see pretty much each time we open a track #907 
Basically the idea behind this is that it is improper to call the useState setter outside of the context of the function that it is created in

Therefore the logic like this (not verbatim)

    useEffect(() => onSnapshot(session, setUrlSession(session)))

was invalid.

I found that moving it to the rootModel resulted in more understandable code, no onSnapshot needed (just watches session via autorun), no need for useDebounce, etc.

title: Avoid loop in loading assemblies
body: This uses a reaction instead of an autorun to watch the assembly configs in the assembly manager. This should avoid it looping infinitely when you add an assembly config.

title: LGV touchpad side scrolling is janky on OSX+Firefox
body:
To reproduce:

* be running OS X with Firefox
* open an LGV
* open a track or two
* two-finger side-scroll in the LGV, doesn't respond very well

title: Improve dotplot label collision avoidance
body:
This works by checking if there are going to be colliding labels, and if there are, it starts hiding labels of the smallest blocks first until there are no more collisions. This seems to successfully label "more important" (i.e. bigger) regions over smaller ones

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/82968935-9eb2a600-9f8b-11ea-9e9a-90062ff6553d.png)

Resolves #921

title: Make spreadsheet cells have overflow hidden with a double click action
body: Currently individual cells can be very wide and tall, I think the UI patterns in excel are probably a point of reference for this type of design with "ellipses..." and double click to select

title: Navigate using location input box in integration tests
body:
It is probably worth it to change navigations in the jbrowse.test.js to use the location input box now. I am also moved to write this issue because I found a curious bug(?) when looking at the soft clipping integration test. Changing setNewView  was not resulting in an updated image snapshot. This diff for example did not update the image snapshot. I am not sure what to think of it, but using the location box to navigate in any case is probably preferable

```
diff --git a/packages/jbrowse-web/src/JBrowse.test.js b/packages/jbrowse-web/src/JBrowse.test.js
index 9569e1d9..3eb5f401 100644
--- a/packages/jbrowse-web/src/JBrowse.test.js
+++ b/packages/jbrowse-web/src/JBrowse.test.js
@@ -449,7 +449,7 @@ describe('alignments track', () => {
       <JBrowse pluginManager={pluginManager} />,
     )
     await findByText('Help')
-    state.session.views[0].setNewView(5, 100)
+    state.session.views[0].setNewView(0.5, 4500)

     // load track
     fireEvent.click(
```

title: 938 open split view from sv inspector row
body:
fixes #938 
fixes #957

title: Color refNames in circular view
body:
Makes refNames on circular view colored.

Adds a `getRefNameColor` to assemblies in the assemblyManager. Can be customized in the assembly config as an array of color strings (which will get cycled through if there are not enough for every refName). By default cycles through a list of 26 colors that come from the UCSC color scheme (with some colors slightly darkened to make them readable).

refNames on circular view will darken/lighten the colors if necessary depending on the background to make them readable.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/82716031-cf74a180-9c52-11ea-96d7-c74f47515520.png)

Resolves #620
Resolves #942

Adds refName renaming to WiggleGetMultiRegionStats

Fixes #952

title: 793 highlight features by attribute
body: This is @agduncan94 PR for the GDC data. I think probably this can be merged and iterated on if there is not anything objectionable? Then the demo site doesn't have to link out on a separate branch for it

title: autogenerated configuration docs
body:
We would like a configuration reference manual that is auto-generated from configSchema's

This generates tables of markdown

This probably means our configSchemas should be a bit more self-documenting

- Add more metadata on the config slots
- Add more metadata on the sub-schemas (e.g. each track refers to an adapter, so it will explain what it is "getting from the adapter" or "using the adapter for" e.g. for alignments in an AlignmentsTrack)

This is separate from #729 and more about the complete set of configuration options

title: Timeout on getRefNameMapForAdapter
body:
Open up SKBR3 BAM file on config_demo.js

Error: timed out waiting for getRefNameMapForAdapter($conf, 'hg19')

```
Error: timed out waiting for getRefNameMapForAdapter($conf, 'hg19')
    at when.ts:30
console.<computed> @ index.js:1

```

This implies that perhaps `when` should not have a set timeout for getRefNameMapForAdapter?

title: break JBrowse.test.js into more files
body: JBrowse.test.js needs to be refactored into a bunch of smaller test files.  It's the start of our E2E test suite, so maybe call each of the files .e2e.test.js, or put them into an `e2e/` subdirectory.

title: Navigate with multiple locStrings
body:
This implements proposed option 1 in #899.

It also makes locString parsing compliant with the SAM standard, which allows colons in refNames. This involves allowing the parsing to validate strings against the set of possible refNames. Also, locStrings that contain an assembly are now of the form `{assemblyName}refName:start..end`.

Resolves #899

title: Add ability to view soft clipped bases in alignments track
body:
Addresses #602. Option to show soft clipped bases added to track menu called 'Show Soft Clipping'. This option can be toggled on and off and is default off. The option does not persist upon refresh currently (is a volatile state). 

When turned on for alignments track, the soft clipped bases will be drawn on each read. The colors for the bases are lightened to differentiate them from the regular mismatch bases. Any base outside A C T G (i.e N) will be drawn as black to be quickly noticeable. There is a maxClippingSize config option that users can edit if their file has soft clip lengths that exceed the default value (10,000 bp)

title: Dragging the circular view should rotate it
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

It takes frustratingly long to rotate the circular view by pressing the buttons. Increasing the rotation per button press (as in #942) will help, but at the cost of precision.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Dragging the circular view should rotate it in a direction such that the drag is tangent to the circle at the point where the drag starts. (In other words, clicking at the top and dragging left will rotate it counterclockwise; clicking on the right and dragging down will rotate it clockwise.)

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

Buttons should also rotate it more #942 but this is JBrowse, it should be draggable.

**Additional context**

The prototype at http://jbrowse.org/u24/rotunda/ is a good example of how it should work.

title: Circular view rotation buttons should rotate further
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

It takes frustratingly long to rotate the circular view by pressing the buttons.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Each button press should rotate the view by 30 degrees.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

Making the view draggable (so it rotates when you drag it) would also be good, but the buttons should be fixed.

**Additional context**

The prototype at http://jbrowse.org/u24/rotunda/ is a good reference for the look-and-feel I'm after.

title: Have alignments context menu functional again
body: Some stuff got removed during the cleanup to blockbasedtrackmodel and typescriptifying pileuprendering, these commits fix up the functionality to have right clicking on alignment features working again

title: Add read quality filters to PileupTrack
body:
This is a setting in JBrowse 1 that is enabled by default https://broadinstitute.github.io/picard/explain-flags.html

By default 
```
not primary alignment
read fails platform/vendor quality checks
read is PCR or optical duplicate
supplementary alignments
```

@peterkxie  found this while working on soft clipping, where not primary alignment aka secondary alignments actually have no feature.get('seq') which is confirmed in SAM. In JBrowse 1 supplementary alignments are actually filtered out but I think this is probably wrong, supplementary alignments are important for SVs for us

Most of these reads are generally ok to be filtered, and then we can have options to unfilter them

title: Support bcftools style filtering queries
body:
BCFTools filters are quite powerful and can do tasks like filter variants with high depth (DP>20), and quite a few other complex things. See https://samtools.github.io/bcftools/howtos/filtering.html

I find myself doing this when trying to find examples to display in the poster and manually loading another variant file.

This could apply to both the spreadsheet and tracks themselves

This was something I alluded to when we were first designing the spreadsheet view: I think that a simple query language can be very powerful to filter the table

title: open split view from SV inspector table row
body: Need to have a button or link in each table row in the SV inspector to open the split view. Should run the same view creation callback that clicking on an arc in the circular view runs.
