title: Remove setting to have feature.id() as a label
body:
This was a carry-over from #886 

I propose not allowing feature.id() as a feature label. I think it is reserved as an internal id system and does not help to give features that have no name or id a label

title: 921 dotplot labels
body:
This performs a simple self avoidance of the labels, based on a hardcoded font height

Some notes:

a) It does not try to hide the "smaller" regions or prioritize "larger regions"
b) We are not doing region ellision

title: 931 assembly synchronization
body:
This overhauls the way the assembly manager does its synchronization. Everything in the assembly manager is `undefined` until it's available, which works well for interacting with MST-based code.

Adds new `when` and `whenPresent` util functions that are useful for interacting with this in async code, based on the `when` function from mobx.

fixes #931

title: Website template
body:
This is a template website that could be expanded upon, initialized using docusaurus v2


I thought it would just be worth it to have a template to build on. It could be deployed to jbrowse.org/v2 or similar if there is interest and include expanded documentation, live demos, etc

title: Running individual tests, particularly rename refs, fails
body:
`yarn test packages/jbrowse-web/src/JBrowse.test.js -t 'test renamed refs'`

Results in error in seqFetch

```
Error: sequence fetch failed: fetching 151-358 only returned 0 bases, but should have returned 206
        at CramAdapter._callee$ (/home/cdiesh/src/jbrowse-components/packages/alignments/src/CramAdapter/CramAdapter.ts:118:15)
        at tryCatch (/home/cdiesh/src/jbrowse-components/node_modules/regenerator-runtime/runtime.js:45:40)
        at Generator.invoke [as _invoke] (/home/cdiesh/src/jbrowse-components/node_modules/regenerator-runtime/runtime.js:274:22)
        at Generator.prototype.(anonymous function) [as next] (/home/cdiesh/src/jbrowse-components/node_modules/regenerator-runtime/runtime.js:97:21)
        at asyncGeneratorStep (/home/cdiesh/src/jbrowse-components/node_modules/babel-preset-react-app/node_modules/@babel/runtime/helpers/asyncToGenerator.js:3:24)
        at _next (/home/cdiesh/src/jbrowse-components/node_modules/babel-preset-react-app/node_modules/@babel/runtime/helpers/asyncToGenerator.js:25:9)
```

@rbuels was thinking it could be a ref renaming specific issue

title: pluggable rpc
body:
refactors RPC system to allow plugins to register their own RPC methods.

An RPC method is now a class that extends `RpcMethodType`, which has an `execute` method that it has to override. It can also optionally override several serialization and deserialization methods to give it control over serializing and deserializing its args and return val across the RPC boundary.

In passing, also
* removed last vestiges of pluggable menu bar types
* slightly simplified RPC/IPC infrastructure of jb desktop
* renames RPC stateGroupIds to just call them sessionIds
* overhauls the way RPC sessionIds are calculated. it now traverses upwards in the tree and takes the `rpcSessionId` of the highest parent that has one. this has the effect of grouping all RPC calls for one piece of the subtree into the same worker.

fixes #818
fixes #853

title: Update to typescript 3.9
body:
If mobx-state-tree is not updated there are many errors of this nature

```
 error TS2339: Property 'setError' does not exist on type 'never'.
  The intersection 'ModelInstanceTypeProps<{ id: IOptionalIType<ISimpleType<string>, [undefined]>; type: ISimpleType<string>; height: IOptionalIType<ISimpleType<number>, [...]>; } & { ...; } & { ...; } & { ...; }> & ... 11 more ... & IStateTreeNode<...>' was reduced to 'never' because property 'ReactComponent' has conflicting types in some constituents.

209                     self.setError(e)
```

Therefore we update to mobx-state-tree 3.16.0

title: Assembly manager updates
body:
This moves the assembly manager to its own entity under the root model, and loads the assembly info when it's created so that it's available and observable to use synchronously.

I added 50 human assemblies to the config to load test it. The app remains responsive, there are just loading bars present on all tracks until the assembly for that track is loaded. I tested with 50 .2bit adapters and it took ~30s to load all assemblies, but with 50 .fa.fai.gz adapters, it only took ~5s.

As discussed with @rbuels and @peterkxie, MST seems to be doing some sort of lazy loading internally, but it doesn't appear to be anything we can control.

title: Add keyboard shortcuts
body:
We need keyboard shortcuts for scrolling/zooming/etc.

One problem this presents is that if you have e.g. two LGVs on the screen and use the keyboard shortcut to scroll, which one should scroll? We might need a concept of "active view," and whichever view is active gets any keyboard input. We could have the view container be colored for the active view and gray for the inactive views.

Preliminary list of keyboard actions:
- Scroll with LeftArrow and RightArrow
- Zoom with Shift + (UpArrow || DownArrow)
- Show vertical guide when pressing Shift

title: Add heuristic to sanitize-html to allow things like <TRA> to display in feature details
body: This is a heuristic for santitize-html that allows things like `<TRA>` to be displayed in the feature details panel, but still perform a full sanitation. That way we can have limited html also like the built-in links that people store in feature data e.g. <a href=...> in a gff attribute or bigBed (seen in the clinVarCNV bigBed from UCSC for example)

title: TypeScript suggested code cleanups
body:
This first started because I noticed some suggestions like this in VS Code:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/81719617-8181c180-943a-11ea-9221-369110abb879.png)

I wanted to know where this suggestion came from since `ts80007` looked like some sort of official TypeScript code. I found a list of diagnostic codes [here](https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/blob/cbf15bb6ed1cd8b30403654a0a1c67baac329d06/src/compiler/diagnosticMessages.json), but couldn't find a setting to get the compiler to export any of the "suggestion" level diagnostics programmatically. From what I've been able to tell, these suggestions can only be gotten from the [typescript standalone server](https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/wiki/Standalone-Server-%28tsserver%29), which editors and IDEs can use for various things. So between talks at BoG last week I decided to try and write a script to extract these suggestions. The script is included here and can be run with `node scripts/getSuggestions.js` and writes the suggestions to stdout. A lot of them aren't things we need to fix, but there were quite a few suggestions I thought would be good, so this PR addresses those (and some other things that were related). Here are some highlights:

- Removed some unnecessary `async`s and `await`s
- Removed unused variables
- Removed unused type parameters
- Make documentation [tsdoc](https://github.com/microsoft/tsdoc)-compliant. There's actually a lint rule for this, too, which I've added.
  - tsdoc looks like it's the "official" standard for TypeScript docs, but it's still new so there's not a ton of great tooling for it yet. I mentioned better-docs in the call last week, but I've now realized it doesn't utilize TypeScript typings, so it's probably not what we want. [API Extractor](https://api-extractor.com/) could be another thing to look into, though.
- According to [MST](https://mobx-state-tree.js.org/tips/typescript#using-a-mst-type-at-design-time), MST-based types should be created as interfaces and not types, since they are less complex and will not slow down compiling as much. This changes those types, and also moves them in with the rest of the TypeScript types.

Maybe not all of these are worth keeping, so I could drop some of the commits if needed.

title: 894 svg icon template
body:
This goes some way towards the SVG icon issue

Addresses #894

title: Add `removeAttribute` to workerPolyfill element
body:
Adds a missing `removeAttribute` method to the workerPolyfill.js element. (workerPolyfill basically exists just to fake out `style-loader`, I wonder if there's a more robust way to do that...)

fixes #920

title: add option for breakpoint split view to show only supporting lines
body:
In the breakpoint split view, add some kind of option to show only connections that support the breakpoint currently being viewed.

@ihh wants this for ITCR if possible

body:
Dotplot axis labels currently draw all over each other, let's find a way to make them look nice.

title: Typescript pileup model
body: This performs a couple steps to typescriptify the PileupTrack model. The getSession was replaced by getSessionWithDrawerWidget also, a new util function

title: Remove unnecessary cra provisions
body:
This removes some of our package.json files that are "provided" by create-react-app

Additionally it is recommended to extend the eslint config (e.g. the "react-app" config) using .env https://create-react-app.dev/docs/setting-up-your-editor/#experimental-extending-the-eslint-config

So this removes react-app from our .eslintrc.json and updates some things to follow that

title: Remove manually set css height, fixes #863
body: Made on the road via GitHub UI...lol

title: jbrowse-cli admin server
body:
A little web server/admin daemon that runs in the foreground from the console.

```
$ jbrowse admin-server
Navigate to http://localhost:9090?admin=1&adminKey=5edc8afc89d6d5a864dda to configure your JBrowse installation graphically.

When finished, press ctrl-c to quit.
```

Then you open that in your browser, it gets the admin key from the URL query string,
and you configure all your data and tracks and everything in your web browser. As you make changes, it saves the config with an `onSnapshot` by POSTing it (authenticated and authorized by the admin key) to the admin server (#1148)

title: Remove allowedBpPerPx
body:
This aims to remove allowedBpPerPx

It also makes maxBpPerPx depend on the totalBp of the displayed regions

title: Remove need to manually pass in adapterType to RPC
body: as long as we are in the business of simplifying the RPC interface, getAdapter does not really seem to strictly need adapterType, the config will contain this in itself. I can't think of a reason for manually have it like this, so I just tried removing it

title: Prevent track from scrolling when resizing with resize handle
body: Track no long has scrolling capability during drag to resize a track

title: add Alignments track read grouping
body:
Group reads by:
* read strand
* first-of-pair strand
* sample
* library
* read group
* chromosome of mate
* pair orientation
* supplementary flag
* read order
* tag
* base at XXXX (centerline position)

title: Alignments track coloring options
body:
Add a coloring options menu (similar to sort menu) that can modifying the coloring of the Pileup track. Will most likely be altering the colorCallback in PileupRenderer to do so

Options include
* read coloring option
* color by map quality
* color by per-base methylation
* bisulfite coloring

title: Alignments track sort by tag, sort by read group
body: Add sort options to the Alignments track to allow sorting by tag (need to add UI to be able to put in what tag), and by read group

title: add BAI index (BAM index-index) support to BAM adapter
body:
When https://github.com/GMOD/bam-js/issues/52 is done:
* add BAI index support to the adapter config
* if there is no BAI index, generate one the first time the BAI is downloaded, and cache it in indexeddb

title: For breakpoint split view, use getBoundingClientRect of track div instead of calculating full layout all tracks in view
body: This is an "idea" to try to make breakpoint split view feature layouts a bit more robust to random layout changes because currently it depends on header and such. I think getBoundingClientRect may improve the logic to make it able to ignore such irrelevant aspects

title: Runtime and jest warning/console error
body:
```
index.js:1 Warning: Cannot update a component (`SvgFeatureRendering`) while rendering a different component (`wrappedComponent`). To locate the bad setState() call inside `wrappedComponent`, follow the stack trace as described in https://fb.me/setstate-in-render
    in wrappedComponent
    in wrappedComponent (at SvgFeatureRendering.js:396)
    in svg (at SvgFeatureRendering.js:378)
    in div (at SvgFeatureRendering.js:377)
    in SvgFeatureRendering
    in SvgFeatureRendering
    in RenderErrorBoundary
```

Happens for alignment track and SVG features track

Also found this for closing a track, but may be a race condition

![Screenshot from 2020-05-04 17-21-37](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6511937/81014953-d1093180-8e2b-11ea-8407-56a97aac2158.png)

title: Longread vs ref demo
body:
This is a demonstration of the long read vs ref, with a preloaded instance of a config in the config.json

The read is actually uses PAF adapter but is a placeholder for being usable via BAM/CRAM/SAM. This example uses the PAF cigar string encoded as cs:10M type thing in the PAF extended data

Instance exists on our demo page for our poster already :)

Commits

title: Basic feature specific right click menu
body:
PR addresses #837, and is also a part of the gradual alignments track improvements #792 

When hovering over a feature in pileup track, users can right click to open up a menu with options. The basic options are 'Open feature drawer' which acts the same as left clicking a feature, or 'copy to clipboard' which copies the feature object to clipboard. A snackbar message also appears and notified on successful copy. It looks like this when pasting:

{
    "seq": "AAATTAAAGGATTTTACCTTAGATTGCGACTAGTACAACGGTACATCGGTGATTCGCGCTCTACTAGATCACGGTATGGGTACCATAAACAAACGGTGGA",
    "unmapped": false,
    "qc_failed": false,
    "duplicate": false,
    "secondary_alignment": false,
    "supplementary_alignment": false,
    "start": 579,
    "end": 679,
    "strand": -1,
    "score": 37,
    "qual": "17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17 17",
    "MQ": 37,
    "CIGAR": "100M",
    "length_on_ref": 100,
    "template_length": 0,
    "XT": "U",
    "NM": 1,
    "X0": 1,
    "X1": 0,
    "XM": 1,
    "XO": 0,
    "XG": 0,
    "MD": "73C26",
    "seq_length": 100,
    "refName": "ctgA",
    "name": "ctgA_203_679_1:1:0_1:0:0_a36",
    "type": "match",
    "clipPos": 0
}

NEEDS DISCUSSION: Currently, I have removed the alignments track general context menu (the one with show/hide coverage track and show/hide pileup track). This menu is still accessible in the track menu. This means that a right click inside an alignments track only opens a menu when the cursor is hovered over a feature, or else nothing happens. Should this be the interaction or should the general context menu be brought back whenever user right clicks inside alignments track but not hovering a feature.

title: launch a dotplot view by right-clicking a long read in the pileup track
body:
Right click a read in the pileup view, has a menu option labeled "View dotplot".  Creates a new dotplot view that shows the read on the horizonal axis, the reference assembly on the vertical axis.

Only the regions of the reference that contain segments should be shown, as in:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/73749/80244896-9c70cb00-861e-11ea-9bbc-e71e50869c18.png)

Implementation sketch:
* makes a temporary assembly that has a sequenceAdapter that is a FromConfigAdapter. The FromConfigAdapter has the read's sequence
* make a temporary dotplot track with a FromConfigAdapter that has one feature for each of the read's segments
* launches a dotplot with appropriate displayedRegions and with that track turned on

title: Wiggle score labels cutoff by block boundary
body:
![Screenshot from 2020-04-23 19-34-07](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6511937/80159632-879e2400-8599-11ea-8ced-55fa0ef2b4ac.png)

May be a regression

title: LGV Overview display and rubber band behavior
body:
The LGV overview bar currently shows the whole contig of any displayed regions and highlights the currently visible location. If we want add highlighting of the displayed regions (not just the currently visible regions) and rubber banding, we need to define their behavior, especially with multiple displayed regions.

I think rubber band navigation should not be allowed if there are multiple displayed regions. It's just too hard to decide what the "right" place to navigate to is, especially if some of the regions are reversed or overlap. For example, rubber band navigation on the highlighted area of the overview bar below would either have to ask which displayed region you wanted to zoom in to, or just zoom in to an area that still had both displayed regions in it.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/80157905-772f7e80-8584-11ea-8216-c5fa15db8995.png)

Highlighting the displayed regions on the overview can also get complicated with multiple displayed regions. Just showing overlapping visible regions is complicated enough, without adding highlighting of displayed regions:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/80158270-5156a980-8585-11ea-8b09-d947222e7105.png)

I think one good option might be that instead of highlighting the individual displayed regions, you could color as "disabled" the parts of a contig that are not in any displayed regions.

title: Location box navigation with multiple locstrings
body:
Currently in the LGV, navigation by locstring only works on the current displayed region, and only when there is a single displayed region. (Note, this behavior probably needs to be modified to be like JB1 and allow navigation to a location on any contig in the assembly, see #858, but may be affected by discussion points below). When there are multiple displayed regions, they show up in the location box as semicolon-separated locations, but text entry is disabled.

The behavior for being able to use locstring navigation with multiple locstrings and/or within multiple displayed regions is not yet defined. @rbuels and I discussed a couple options a while back:

### Option 1: Locstrings are for navigation only

- If there is a single displayed region that exactly matches a contig in the assembly:
  - Entering a single location will navigate to that location, updating the displayed region to exactly match the contig of the location if necessary
  - Entering multiple locations is not allowed
- Else (e.g. a single displayed region that is shorter than the whole contig, multiple displayed regions)
  - The location must exactly match a region that exists on the current displayed region(s), or else navigation will fail

This option means that if we want users to be able to create displayed regions from locstrings, there will have to be a separate place in the UI to do that.

### Option 2: Locstrings can create displayed regions

- If there is a single displayed region (whether or not is exactly matches a contig in the assembly):
  - Entering a single location will navigate to that location, updating the displayed region to exactly match the contig of the location if necessary
  - Entering multiple locations will create new displayed regions that match those locations, with the left end of the first displayed region and the right end of the last displayed regions being expanded to the limits of their contig.
    - e.g. entering `chrA:5000..6000;chrB:7000..8000;chrC:9000..10000` would result in three displayed regions: `[{refName: 'chrA', start: 0, end: 6000}, {refName: 'chrB', start: 6999, end: 8000}, {refName: 'chrC', start: 8999, end: 36000}]`, assuming `ctgC` is 36,000 bases long.
- Else (e.g. multiple displayed regions)
  - If the location entered exists on the currently displayed regions, navigate to it, do not create any new displayed regions
  - If the location entered does not exist, behave the same as if there is a single displayed region

This option is not deterministic, since entering the same thing in the location box might navigate in one case and create displayed regions in another case depending on what the current displayed regions are. It also may be confusing to users in some cases why their displayed regions suddenly changed, although it will be undo-able. Also, there's currently no syntax for defining a reversed displayed region via locstring.

---

I favor Option 1, since it seems to me that creating displayed regions should be a separate UI action in a separate place from navigating, and it's less complicated so the behavior is easier to predict for users.

title: Add "Get sequence" to LGV rubber band menu
body:
Get the reference sequence for the rubber-banded area.

Disabled (grayed out) if more than 500MB, or if there is no sequence adapter for the assembly in question.

Pops up a modal dialog that has:

* textarea with the exported sequence in FASTA format, textarea is not displayed if more than 100KB of sequence
* button to copy to clipboard (turned off if no clipboard support)
* filename text field (with good default name), and button to save to file

title: Option to position track label above track
body:
Having an option to put the track label completely above and off the track might be nice for some users (originally suggested by @cmdcolin in a pairing). Currently this minimal change

```diff
--- a/packages/linear-genome-view/src/LinearGenomeView/components/TrackContainer.tsx
+++ b/packages/linear-genome-view/src/LinearGenomeView/components/TrackContainer.tsx
@@ -38,7 +38,7 @@ const useStyles = makeStyles(theme => ({
     height: '100%',
   },
   trackLabel: {
-    position: 'absolute',
+    position: 'relative',
     zIndex: 3,
     margin: theme.spacing(1),
   },
```

produces this proof of concept:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/80151100-b9ea5a00-8576-11ea-8f60-92d980610a49.png)

Questions:

- Would we want the labels full width like this, or the same width as when they are floating over a track?
- Should the labels be resizable?
- What would this option be called? (Maybe have a "Track labels" menu with three radio options, "hidden," "floating," and "above"?)

Also note if implementing this:

- Breakpoint split view will need to be aware of the track label height and position
- Track drag-and-drop handles will also need to be fixed for the "above" option

title: Add option to LGV to hide track labels
body: Adds "Show track labels" option to LGV menu. Also animates track labels being turned on/off as sliding from/to left of screen.

title: LGV animated zoom
body:
This animates the zoom for the zoom in/out buttons in the LGV. This was originally planned for #786, but was omitted to keep that PR from going too long. Try it out here:

https://s3.amazonaws.com/jbrowse.org/code/jb2/alpha/lgv_animated_zoom/index.html

title: Use SVG instead of font icons
body:
Currently for our icons we use the material icon font for our icons. However, Material-UI suggests using SVG fonts whenever possible: https://material-ui.com/components/icons/#font-vs-svg-which-approach-to-use

We originally used font icons because we wanted users to be able to specify menu item icons in config files, which isn't possible with SVG (but with the icon font you could just specify a string).

Now that menus are not in the config, though, that reason no longer holds, so we should perhaps move to using SVG fonts instead. The link above explains some advantages of SVG, but some of the highlights for us might be:

* Smaller: Webpack should only bundle the icons we actually use, instead of the whole icon font.
* Plugins can easily use their own custom icons like this:

```js
<SvgIcon>
  <path d="M20 12l-1.41-1.41L13 16.17V4h-2v12.17l-5.58-5.59L4 12l8 8 8-8z" />
</SvgIcon>
```

* No "loading flicker" where the font hasn't loaded yet, so the icon doesn't appear properly. Especially noticeable on slower machines/connections. Example:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/80029489-1597e300-84a4-11ea-8c83-6e41bb489a75.png)

title: AlignmentsTrack always has a scroll bar
body:
No matter how tall you make the track, the AligmentsTrack always has a scroll bar.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/80028731-cbfac880-84a2-11ea-9927-efe48d910490.png)

title: Move menu out of config
body:
This includes all the changes in #883, so it supersedes that PR. See that PR for a description of those changes.

This  gets rid of the pluggable menu type and makes it so plugins can register menus and menu items on the root model during the `configure` phase. Each plugin is responsible for adding menu items for itself, (e.g. the LGV plugin adds the "New linear genome view" menu item to the File menu).

A plugin can read the current menus from `pluginManager.rootModel.menus` and set new menus with `pluginManager.rootModel.setMenus`. There are also several convenience functions for common actions like adding a top-level menu, adding a menu item to a top-level menu, and adding a menu item to a sub-menu.

This also adds the ability for the menus to be nested, and so attempts to simplify the File menu like this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/80007954-40723f00-8484-11ea-8400-394b567da414.png)

title: "New dotplot view" crashes
body: Clicking "File -> New dotplot view" in dev freezes and eventually crashes the page. In a production build it logs a mobx-state-tree error in the dev console, but the error is too long to paste here (apparently the maximum comment length is 65536 characters).

title: Fix drawer horizontal overflow
body:
This fixes a problem where the drawer sometimes had a horizontal scroll when nothing was overflowing.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/79806176-09394c00-8325-11ea-9357-5eaf9af7af38.png)

title: Adds context menu capabilities and sorting pileup track abilities to alignments track
body:
This addresses step 2 in #792 to improve alignments track. There are two major feature updates

1. Adds a right-click context menu to alignments track. 

User can right click on the pileup or snp coverage portion to reveal a context menu which allows you to hide one or the other track. I.e hide the snp coverage track so only the pileup track is displayed. Feature specific context menus will be implemented soon so there will eventually be two different context menus depending on where the user right-clicks. The options in the context menu also exist in the track controls menu

2. Adds ability to sort the pileup track using view menu level actions.

The view level menu now parses through all the tracks in the view and looks for track type actions. These actions are added to the view level menu with a subheader of the track type it is tied to. When selecting one of these actions, it will apply to all tracks in the view of the same time. I.e, selecting sort under alignments track in the view menu will sort all alignment tracks in the view

Alignments track now can have it's pileup track sorted by either start location, base pair, or read strand. The sort will alway be done on the center bp. To see what bp is in the center, user can toggle 'show center line' in the view menu that toggles a ui element which outlines and writes out what the center bp is.

To clear a sort, either select 'Clear sort' or refresh the page.

title: 793 gdc extended feature detail
body:
Created a custom feature detail for both genes and mutations. This detail has extra panels for external links, consequences (mutation only), and projects.

The projects are fetched via async call when the feature detail is opened or the selected feature changes.

title: Dynamic blocks renderDelay
body: Currently dynamicBlocks renderDelay does not actually do anything, because the block is destroyed and recreated and so the cycle of create block-> afterAttach->new reaction->destroy block is called continuously. This makes it so the dynamicblocks track renderDelay is not really doing anything

title: typescript conversion and adapter config changes
body:
Starting a PR to bring this in on final approach.

Main changes coming in here:

* converted many parts of core to typescript, with better typing of plugins and a type for config schemas (config slots still not typed though)
* data adapters now receive a MST object of their config model, rather than a config snapshot

title: Add arc track for paired reads and long reads
body:
The arc track has a comparatively simple implementation to actually drawing reads as connected with the box layout


It uses the insert size (TLEN) field to draw a circle with radius TLEN/2 in the direction of it's pair (RNEXT:PNEXT)

In jbrowse 2, this could be implemented for paired reads

It could also be done for long reads and connecting all the SA: tag

1. trying to make this work with a single refseq
2. trying to make this work across multiple refseq
2.1 make a new arc renderer (different subclass of ServerSideRendererType, not BoxRendererType)
2.2 the arc renderer uses virtual base pair coordinate space and/or pixel space
3. decide on whether to use block based or something else

title: Add ability to view paired read and split long reads as connected
body:
JBrowse 1 paired read features included

1) Rendering a pair as a single glyph that occupies a single row in an alignment

It also has coloring modes for insert size gradients, color by pairs being oriented incorrectly, color by "abnormal insert size" discretization (from collecting statistics about insert size)

Mechanisms include "extending the length that a block fetches" by a variable called max insert size. This is a configurable variable, to make sure that when a particular block is rendered, that the glyph currently being drawn is fully resolved. Alternative includes drawing only half a feature until you "come into contact" with the other, but this I think suffers from inter-block dependencies whereas max insert size just extends each block fetch size

title: Plugin Manager as Root Object
body:
This adds a reference to the root model to the plugin manager so that it can act as the "root object"(will be renamed at some point). It also now adds two extra steps when setting up the plugin manager. You have to call `createPluggableElements` and optionally `setRootModel` before `configure`. You need to call `setRootModel` if you are using any plugins that need the root model during their `configure` phase (none of ours do yet, but they likely will after #452).

Originally @rbuels and I moved the creation of the plugin manager to index.js, but I ended up factoring it out into Loader.js so that it could be tested. Not sure if there is a better naming/pattern.

This makes `createTestSession` be a bit out of place in rootModel.js, but I also removed the usage of `createTestSession` in many places. `createTestSession` should probably be replaced by something else at some point.

title: Speedup side scrolling in LGV
body:
The usage of setState to batch event updates in the LGV on side scroll was causing double renders as any setState will cause a re-render and slowness. I am not sure if it was just less obvious before but it became more noticeable following the LGV UI update. This makes the event updates batched using refs instead of state

Similar stuff to what Ian was seeing in his work on abrowse :)

title: Add subHeader to Menu
body:
This add a "subHeader" option to the Menu, can be used for naming groups, like the sketch in https://github.com/GMOD/jbrowse-components/issues/792#issuecomment-612153759

Looks like this:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/79016931-6535f080-7b2d-11ea-84b6-6a0d375ceb16.png)

title: Dotplot view
body: This a extract of linear_comparative to the dotplot view

title: Measure View width instead of App width
body:
We were measuring the whole app width and passing that to the session, which had an autorun that then updated the view widths.

This simplifies things by just measuring the view widths directly and setting them, and not worrying about the whole app width at all. Since it measures the actual view widths, if a view shrinks due to a scroll bar appearing, everything updates accordingly and there isn't a problem with unwanted horizontal scroll bars.

The second commit adds a BaseViewModel for views to compose so they will be sure to have the basic requirements of a view (id, width, optional displayName, optional menuOptions).

Resolves #727

title: Use ignoreUnknown to avoid crash on complex configs

title: LGV UI Updates
body:
This entails a lot of changes, but here are some highlights:

- No more track controls, not have a floating track label with a button that opens a track menu
- Container for all views that has close button, optional menu button, and optional editable display name
- Pan buttons in LGV header (with animated pan)
- LocString updates as you navigate around
- Error messages if you try to navigate by a locString and it fails
- Side scrolling works when the mouse is on the scale bar and in the track area when no tracks are open
- Vertical guides in track area
- Rubber band action on scale bar opens a menu instead of automatically zooming
- Cursor guide when hovering over scale bar
- Overview scale bar with polygons that show currently visible region

Here are some things this PR does **not** do, that I feel might be better in separate follow-up PRs:

- Overview just shows currently visible regions. Does not have rubber band navigation yet, and does not show displayedRegions (there are a number of things to consider here that I'd like to lay out in a future PR)
- Animated zoom
- Location box does not allow input when there are multiple displayed regions
- Allow hiding/re-positioning track labels
- Add "Get sequence" to scale bar rubber band menu

If any of these things are must-haves for this PR, I can work on them, otherwise I think it would be best to get this bulky part in and iterate from there.

Can test out at http://s3.amazonaws.com/jbrowse.org/code/jb2/alpha/786_LGV_polish/index.html

Screenshot showing some features:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/78723627-0f710680-78e9-11ea-9adf-511744053952.png)

Resolves #786

title: Greenkeeper is ending, do we need another dependency manager?
body:
Greenkeeper is [ending on June 3](https://greenkeeper.io/). They recommend migrating to [snyk](https://snyk.io/), but I'm not sure we need to.

Have we gained much from Greenkeeper? I feel like we haven't, but maybe I'm wrong.

title: Create concept of store ID and add it to some relevant features
body:
Addresses #763 

This was made awhile ago but never made into a PR :)

title: Bump mobx-state-tree and allow semver upgrades
body:
The resources that we have are pinned to mobx-state-tree 3.14.1

While mobx-state-tree is foundational for what we do, and we should be careful about our version upgrades with it, I think it's worth allowing upgrades via semver. This also upgrades to the latest 3.15.0 release

Apparently this also makes our root package.json use 2 spaces instead of 4, like all the other package.json that we have, and which follows our editorconfig

#860

title: Modularize test data and remove config_in_dev
body: The concept of the config_in_dev was a little messy and also didn't work on s3 demos since that was no longer inDev, the test data directory in general was kind of unorganized. This adds a subdirectory for volvox, removes config_in_dev, where we can possibly plan to add multiple configs similar to jbrowse 1

title: 792 context menu with improved alignments colin
body:
This is a small PR onto the current 792 branch of @peterkxie 's

I propose not using radio buttons to indicate the current sort, because we want to be able to repeatedly perform a sort after scrolling sideways a little

Also there is a clue that the centerline position may have a bug, possibly in the underlying pxToBp code, where it isn't able to properly get some positions

Screenshot attached of a position that should say 3212 but says 3211

![t1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6511937/78454967-9e6feb80-7669-11ea-98b9-fd7131805521.png)

title: 793 gdc plugin
body:
Initial implementation of the GDC plugin.
GDCAdapter.ts and GDCFilter.ts are used to create tracks from the GDC API. For now, they support both gene and mutation tracks. The adapter has four configuration fields which are filters, featureType, cases, and size. These can be edited in the configuration editor drawer.

There is also a new GDCFilterConfigurationEditorDrawerWidget which provides an easy way for users to apply filters to their track and also see what filters are currently applied. Any time a filter is added/removed, the track will be updated. Currently, the logic for these filters is that they are combined with an AND operation and the individual filters use an IN operation. In the future, this can be expanded to use more operations, such as NOT IN and OR.

Use /?config=test_data%2Fconfig_gdc_test.json to see the track in the browser.

title: Enable checkJs in typescript config
body:
The typescript compiler can check raw javascript code to some extent with the checkJs setting turned on, and the process can reveal some interesting things. I would suggest we move to turn on the setting


This is a draft PR for about half our codebase having it turned on

title: BioNano data support
body:
BioNano can be very good at showing structural variation but it has not yet been prioritized as a format for looking at. There was the bionano jbrowse plugin here https://github.com/bionanogenomics/JBrowsePlugin/wiki/Using-the-BioNano-Genomics-JBrowse-Plugin

it would be interesting to consider rebooting this if we can find more test data. It appears they market for cancer researchers https://twitter.com/bionanogenomics/status/1243206337330384897?s=20

Step 2. Try to drag track height handle down

title: Update @babel namespace packages

The 7.9 release of babel allows using "import type" and "export type" which are interesting features, this PR just solely upgrades babel. See https://babeljs.io/blog/2020/03/16/7.9.0#typescript-38-type-only-imports-and-exports-11171-https-githubcom-babel-babel-pull-11171

Note that doing these upgrades (which just involved `yarn upgrade-interactive` and checking the babel boxes) required manually adding babel-jest to the project root

title: Add a cascading menu to Core
body:
One thing Material-UI lacks by default is a good cascading menu. There's been an [open issue](https://github.com/mui-org/material-ui/issues/11723) for it for almost two years, and people have tried various solutions, but I tried many of them and they had limitations. The biggest problem is that most people seem tried to create a NestedMenu component that you could drop in as a replacement for a MenuItem, but each submenu then gets opened in a new modal, which makes it hard to coordinate mouse and keyboard events between the menu and submenu.

I needed a good menu for the track label menu in the LGV polishing, and @peterkxie needs one for his right-click menu, so I decided to make our own and add it to core. You provide an array of menu entries (which can have submenus) to the component and it creates a cascading menu. The submenu opens when you hover your mouse on its parent, and it's fully keyboard navigable. It supports:

- Icons
- Secondary text on labels
- Radio buttons
- Checkboxes
- Dividers

This PR also converts the LGV menu and Spreadsheet column menus to using the new menu.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/76990966-757ff480-690e-11ea-8ab3-74ca510ea99e.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/76991145-b972f980-690e-11ea-8a21-009b2cfee5ad.png)

Expected: a navigation to occur
Result: nothing happens

Resolution

title: Make each displayed region have "reversed" flag
body:
@cmdcolin and I were [chatting on gitter](https://gitter.im/GMOD/jbrowse2?at=5e6c0e4017d3e742347a3a62) about flipping of displayedRegions, which got me thinking about what I felt would be the best way to represent that. The limitation I kept coming up against was that if `horizontallyFlipped` were an attribute of the view, you couldn't have a forward and reverse region in the same view. For example, with breakend W/Y below:

![image](https://github.com/samtools/hts-specs/raw/8b0a59271f13eea9cff30c6e372b7fe675f815f0/img/all_orientations-400x296.png)

If you want to show a single-LGV view of the breakend, you'd need to do something like:

```
_______________________________________________
-->|--------->|------->|<-------|<---------|<--
321,500    321,600     |     198,900    198,800
```

We've talked about this before, and decided to make flipping per-region in #258. I wanted to see how hard that would be to implement, and it wasn't bad, so I made this PR for it as a proposal.

In this, the `horizontallyFlip()` action on the LGV reverses the order of the displayed regions and flips the `reversed` flag on each region.

The only thing I couldn't get to easily work was the breapoint split view's overlays, since they look a `horizontallyFlipped` in the view and don't have a region to look at because they're getting their data from the features on the screen.

Resolves #258

title: display methods
body:
In order to allow different views e.g. circular and linear of a dataset e.g. a VCF with SVs, we would like a single "track" to be able to be displayed on those different views

Currently track's pertain to only a single view type though

Therefore, we would like to make a new concept of "Track" that contains different "DisplayMethods"

Some considerations are

How does a plugin create a new "top level track type"
How does a plugin add a new display method to an existing "top level track type"
Can we avoid issues related to "stringly typed view names"


BreakpointSplitTrack, which uses bam, and StructuralVariantChordTrack, which uses VCF, are relevant examples of this

title: Track selector for view with subviews
body:
When we have views with subviews, it would be valuable to have a top-level track selector that has all the subview's track selectors rather than having each individual view having it's own track selector


Track selector

```
parent view's tracks->things like synteny tracks
subview 1 tracks->
subview 2 tracks->
```

Would be interesting if we can get larger tooltip contents

title: Dynamic blocks returns an empty state initially

The change to the moveTo function is the most important one

title: Opening 2+ tracks (BAM) with large amounts of data at same time causes rpc timeout and failed to fetch issues
body:
Found when testing out #843. This occasionally happens on master too but much easier to reproduce on #843 because it is rendering 4 total tracks

2 or more tracks, typically the SNPCoverage and the PileupTrack of the second alignments track loaded will fail to load with one or more of the following issues:
- Uncaught (in promise) TypeError: Failed to fetch
- worker did not respond within 30000 ms, terminating and replacing.
- Uncaught (in promise) Error: Timeout exceeded for RPC method "ping"
- Error: Timeout exceeded for RPC method "render"

Failed to fetch is the most common error returned

To reproduce, open a new LGV, select hg19 and then open HG002 Nanopore ultralong(BAM) and HG002BAM nanopore+whatshap from track selector. Scroll to around 13k bp
Note: These tracks with the CRAM adapter load successfully

What the console typically looks like while loading:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22454194/75919020-a2fa7780-5e11-11ea-8ee4-a6c8c6abec5b.png)

The network tab after completion. Note the number of requests and size of resources:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22454194/75919075-befe1900-5e11-11ea-83ab-94732dd54e62.png)

Console when it fails on master branch:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22454194/75919851-2799c580-5e13-11ea-92fa-603c08ef3fcc.png)
When failing on master, I've only seen 'fail to fetch' and have not run into 'rpc ping timeout' yet. Master branch is less consistent on producing this bug, both tracks load successfully from time to time. 


After discussion with @cmdcolin, source of issue could be Bam.js or rangeFetcher.js

title: Improve AlignmentsTrack by displaying both SNPCoverageTrack and PileupTrack (old alignmentsTrack) when selected
body:
Addresses step one in issue #792 by combining the old alignments track and snp coverage track into a single track type with subtracks. 

Old alignments track has been renamed to pileup track, and new track is named alignments track and renders both the Pileup track and SNP Coverage track when selected. Config is compatible with any old configs, no changes needed and it will display both tracks when selected from track selector. 

Adding a track allows to select between alignments track or just pileup/snp coverage track individually, but alignments is the default guess.

title: multi-wiggle track
body:
Make a new track type that contains multiple wiggle tracks, displays them all as subtracks, and has powerful features for working with multiple wiggle datasets.

Most fundamental is displaying all the datasets with the same Y scale (or heat colors or whatever) so that they can be easily compared visually.

title: Keep static and dynamic blocks in sync
body:
Fixes #839 

Dynamic blocks were missing InterRegionPaddingBlocks, but just adding those didn't fix it completely: 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/75466519-8eb50700-5947-11ea-8cbf-8c8646146ec9.png)

The only way to keep everything in sync was to have both block types allocate space in the offset for all potential padding blocks, whether or not they were in the returned block set.

Also includes a bug fix where a dynamic block got elided when it was scrolled to be almost off screen. 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/75466778-ed7a8080-5947-11ea-9322-3b3a97ff6cb2.png)

title: staticBlocks and dynamicBlocks can get out of sync
body:
**Describe the bug**
If there are multiple displayedRegions, staticBlocks and dynamicBlocks can get out of sync:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/75463529-30862500-5943-11ea-8e2c-44c938ad7b0e.png)

**To Reproduce**
1. Create a new LGV of volvox
2. Set a bunch of displayedRegions. I used:
```text
MODEL.views[0].setDisplayedRegions([ {assemblyName: 'volvox', refName: 'ctgA', start: 0, end: 10}, {assemblyName: 'volvox', refName: 'ctgA', start: 10, end: 20}, {assemblyName: 'volvox', refName: 'ctgA', start: 20, end: 30}, {assemblyName: 'volvox', refName: 'ctgA', start: 30, end: 40}, {assemblyName: 'volvox', refName: 'ctgA', start: 40, end: 50}, {assemblyName: 'volvox', refName: 'ctgA', start: 50, end: 60}, {assemblyName: 'volvox', refName: 'ctgA', start: 60, end: 70}, {assemblyName: 'volvox', refName: 'ctgA', start: 70, end: 80}, {assemblyName: 'volvox', refName: 'ctgA', start: 80, end: 90}, {assemblyName: 'volvox', refName: 'ctgA', start: 90, end: 100}, {assemblyName: 'volvox', refName: 'ctgA', start: 100, end: 110}, {assemblyName: 'volvox', refName: 'ctgA', start: 110, end: 120}, {assemblyName: 'volvox', refName: 'ctgA', start: 120, end: 130}, {assemblyName: 'volvox', refName: 'ctgA', start: 130, end: 140}, {assemblyName: 'volvox', refName: 'ctgA', start: 140, end: 150}, {assemblyName: 'volvox', refName: 'ctgA', start: 150, end: 160}, {assemblyName: 'volvox', refName: 'ctgA', start: 160, end: 170}, {assemblyName: 'volvox', refName: 'ctgA', start: 170, end: 180}, {assemblyName: 'volvox', refName: 'ctgA', start: 180, end: 190}, {assemblyName: 'volvox', refName: 'ctgA', start: 190, end: 200}, {assemblyName: 'volvox', refName: 'ctgA', start: 200, end: 210}, {assemblyName: 'volvox', refName: 'ctgA', start: 210, end: 220} ])
```
3. Scroll to the last regions and turn on the reference sequence (a static block track) and lollipop (a dynamic block) tracks.

title: Remove displayRegionsFromAssemblyName
body:
This gets rid of `displayRegionsFromAssemblyName` and has the view setup wizards manually set a single `displayedRegion`.

It also adds and autocomplete box for refName to the LGV setup wizard and LGV header. There's a demo assembly that has 200,000 contigs you can try out by going to: http://localhost:3000/?config=test_data/config_many_contigs.json

The autocomplete is a bit sluggish at 200,000 contigs, but I'm not sure if there's much we can do. You can try out a demo of the MUI component at https://codesandbox.io/s/7g677. If you crank up the number of of options on that demo, you can see that it's the component that is having trouble, not our data or implementation in particular.

Up to about 75,000 contigs it does fine. At 200,000 it takes ~3 seconds to open the drop-down box after clicking on it (though once it's open, you can scroll all 200,000 entries just fine, so react-window seems to be doing well at virtualizing). It also takes a couple seconds to fill in the first letter if you try to type into the autocomplete, though subsequent letters are much faster.

I would say this is probably good enough performance for now, since we're not even totally sure how many contigs users are really going need, and then we can explore other ways to do the autocomplete if we feel we need to later.

title: right-click menu for Pileup features
body:
Right-clicking on an alignment in a pileup should pop up a context menu with actions you can do on it.

Viewing the feature details would be one obvious one, but there will be others, like spawning a detail view in #791

title: SV inspector better support for deletions, SNPs, insertions, CNVs, tandem duplications
body:
depends on #795 

Job one, we should probably just rename it to a variant inspector if we are going to support SNPs and such.

## deletions
* when opened, open with one panel showing the drop in coverage, and another one showing both sides of the deletion stuck together in two different displayedRegions, both with the evidence tracks opened

## SNPs
* circular view should have density wiggle, or points, or triangles around the outside of the circle
* when opened, just navigate to that spot in a regular linear view, with the evidence tracks opened

## insertions
* when opened, show a regular linear view with the evidence tracks opened, which should hopefully show soft clipping etc

## CNVs
* navigate to the location with the evidence tracks opened, hopefully the evidence track has coverage active

## tandem duplications
* navigate to the location with the evidence tracks opened, and then the user can just look at it, or if they have long-reads, maybe they can open an alignment detail view of it using functionality from #791

title: Use eslint-config-airbnb-typescript since yarn upgrade is producing typescript lint errors
body:
Currently running yarn upgrade on master has some breakage for yarn lint

It gives errors about requiring the extension on various typescript imports. I wasn't sure how to fix that directly but found this PR which suggested just using eslint-config-airbnb-typescript https://github.com/benmosher/eslint-plugin-import/pull/1637

These rules seem pretty good. It reveals some cycles in imports for our typescript files that were not being found previously, which are "just warnings" but could be addressed, as well as some other errors.

title: Expose more config-level control over breakpoint split-view splines
body:
As a simpler alternative/complement to #814 (and the earlier #779), we could simply dial back the number of splines we display on the screen, by default. (I tend to think we are just overwhelming the user with a few too many splines, because splines were a design innovation we were enthusiastic about, and trying to "fix" this with more design innovation is perhaps to overlook the first commandment: [simplify](https://thevisualcommunicationguy.com/2019/11/15/information-design-rule-simplify-your-audiences-life/).)

Specifically, I propose the config allows one of the following options to be selected:
- Do not show any split-read splines
- Show split-read splines ONLY for the currently moused-over read   **<- the default option**
- Show split-read splines ONLY for splits across the current breakpoint
- Show all split-read splines

If and when we have an option for selecting a feature (or features), then we could show the splines for selected reads as well as moused-over reads as part of option 2.

title: If you use "Add track" on hg19, but choose hg38 as the assemblyName in the add track, it still adds it to your view with region assembly does not match error
Avoid a double fetch of adapter resources using adapter fingerprint as webworker sessionId
body:
Ref #578 

It requires some careful work to make sure getRefNames gets the sequence adapter as well as the normal adapter, because the full adapter fingerprint is the combination of a sequence config and a normal config (this is because we need cram adapter to not get the dataAdapterCache of an instance of the cram adapter that lacks the sequence adapter, e.g. one that was initialized when getRefNames is not passed a sequenceAdapterConfig)

The removal of memoize-one in BamAdapter is just because it's unnecessary and wasn't actually helping, and is now more similar to the CramAdapter code

title: Deep sequencing data examples
body:
This contains some deep sequencing data, also called amplicons or targetted sequencing (not sure if the terms are all interchangeable but main thing we see is high coverage of specific areas). The illumina file is only 13MB and has 12,000x sequence depth and works pretty good I think

Then I also found nanopore data and it is a 400MB BAM, 200+MB CRAM and it ends up crashing with out of memory with both

title: Linear comparative view
body:
We accomplished synteny view on the synteny_demo branch

We are going to evolve this to become a more general linear comparative view, that can encompass breakpoint split view and synteny


- We will have synteny tracks, and the config for drawing them will exist there.
- We will not do synthetic events as normal, and might investigate making the concept of "layers" more clear to users
- We will get rid of the "synteny group" configRelationships in favor of explicit references to relevant trackIds
- The "synteny tracks" will do the fetching of the data in some cases in order to pair it with data that is drawn on the tracks e.g. gene names


Supercedes
https://github.com/GMOD/jbrowse-components/issues/54
https://github.com/GMOD/jbrowse-components/issues/115
https://github.com/GMOD/jbrowse-components/issues/116

title: Improvements to feature detail drawer widgets
body:
In the alignment feature detail drawer, it extends the info with a custom card, but this duplicates some info

Solution:

Allow passing an "omit list" to the feature drawer widget so that you can customize
Allow creating a custom card that has specific attribute list to render
Extra metadata on the field names, e.g. the yellow cards in the jbrowse 1 feature detail with mouseover tooltip text

title: allow plugins to add their own RPC calls
body:
Plugins don't have a way to use web workers for novel things.

Add ways for plugins to add RPC calls.

title: jbrowse-web and desktop Rescripts setup is broken on Yarn versions 1.22+
body:
On yarn version 1.22, get the following error: 
yarn start
yarn run v1.22.0
$ rescripts --max-http-header-size=100000 start
It seems that your Rescripts configuration is invalid. Please refer to the docs or post an issue if you believe this to be an internal bug. Thank you!
error Command failed with exit code 1.
info Visit https://yarnpkg.com/en/docs/cli/run for documentation about this command.

@cmdcolin also tested on yarn v1.23.0 beta and encountered the same error

Downgrading yarn to v1.21.0 fixes the issue

title: checkpointing undo manager, back button support
body:
* make an mst middleware undo manager that is kind of like the stock UndoManager described at https://www.npmjs.com/package/mst-middlewares#undomanager, but that supports "labeled checkpoints"
  * `undoManager.setCheckpoint()` adds a default checkpoint to the undo history
  * `undoManager.setCheckpoint('my_label')` adds a checkpoint with label 'my_label'
  * `undoManager.undo()` rolls back the history until it encounters any checkpoint, no matter its label
  * `undoManager.undo('my_label')` rolls back the history until it encounters a checkpoint with label 'my_label'
  * and so on for the corresponding redo actions

* make the session model have one of these checkpointing undo managers as a regular property or maybe as a volatile
* add an action to the session model like
  ```js
  function setCheckpoint(label = undefined) {
      self.undoManager.setCheckpoint(label);
      if (label === 'back_button') window.pushState(....)
  }
  ```
* add a `session.undo(label)` action
* add `session.setCheckpoint('back_button')` checkpoints to actions around the codebase that should be undoable by the back button
* add `session.setCheckpoint()` checkpoints to actions around the codebase that should be undoable with ctrl-Z/edit->undo
* add global ctrl-Z and shift-ctrl-Z keybindings for undo and redo
* add a `popstate` window event handler to deregister any existing popstate handlers, and then add a handler that runs `session.undo('back_button')`


An example of an action that should set a back_button checkpoint would be `addView` in the session model.
An example of an action that should set a default checkpoint would be `showTrack` in the LGV.

This proposes removing the DevTools bar

I think it more often than not it causes me confusion and  the "UI just for dev" seems weird a lot of the time. Also the session options do not persist across refreshes which can be confusing too, the undo/redo options are not decided on yet, and the "Add view" is available from the main menu

title: Display implied UTRs in transcript glyphs
body: Functionality exists in JB1, not yet in JB2

title: Package a monospace font
body:
Currently we package the Roboto font so that JBrowse users on any platform will have a consistent experience (Roboto was chosen because it is the [suggested font for Material-UI](https://material-ui.com/getting-started/installation/#roboto-font)).

We don't package a monospace font, though, and rely on the user's system fonts (or generic font fallbacks), meaning things like the callback editors and pileup renderer may vary depending on the user's system.

I propose we package a monospace font so that users have a consistent experience. I suggest the [Roboto Mono](https://fonts.google.com/specimen/Roboto+Mono) font, for consistency with the font we already have.

Biggest downside I can see is increasing our bundle size a bit.

title: Show snackbar when connection fails to connect
body:
This is from a pairing between @peterkxie and me today.

When a UCSC hub or JBrowse 1 connection fails to connect, it shows a snackbar message and turns the connection off. It also tries to connect as soon as the connection is added, mirroring the behavior of when you add a track.

fixes #805

title: Support BAI index aka BAM index index
body:
For some BAM files like nanopore and pacbio, the index file is regularly 100MB or bigger

There is the concept of a BAI index created here
https://github.com/hammerlab/bai-indexer/

This implementation doesn't include the chromosome names in the BAI index, so it is actually not really usable for us IMO. I don't think it's a good thing to rely on chromosomes being connected to the index in an array e.g. chr1 is position 0 in array

So we probably want our own BAI index, and also we could create a BAI index on the e.g. first download BAI, then index it and store it in localstorage or similar, then subsequent refreshes use the BAI index. This is good because chrome decides not to cache large BAI files in it's file cache. We can also have a on-disk representation of the BAI index so that this could be used instead of the localstorage also

title: Get rid of datasets
body:
This moves assemblies, tracks, and connections to the top level of the config, so a config looks something like this:

```json
{
  "configuration": {},
  "assemblies": [],
  "tracks": [],
  "connections": [],
  "defaultSession": {},
  "savedSessions": []
}
```

Tracks now have a config of `assemblyNames` which is a string array of names of assemblies the track applies to. Connections were a bit harder to do with multiple assembly names, so for now connections are just for a single assembly.

Need to manually test a bit more thoroughly, but thought I'd open the PR for discussion now.

title: 601 Create standalone SNP Track
body:
Creates new SNP Track that uses a SNPAdapter and SNPXYRenderer. SNPAdapter wraps either a Bam or Cram Adapter using a 'subadapter' concept (thanks to @cmdcolin) and draws mismatches onto a canvas using coverage bin information. Still working on some deeper integration testing.

Issue with using types: 'frozen' left in for now, idea of changing to pluginManager.pluggableConfigSchemaType('adapter') commented out for now due to difficulty of getting pluginManager to work in an Adapter's index.js file. Since there are two adapters (the main SNP adapter and one sub adapter), has issues identifying the correct adapter for config schema

title: config editor should hide convert-to-callback button for config slots with no arguments
body:
Lots of configuration slots really don't make much sense to have as callbacks.

If a config slot has no arguments in its function signature, the config editor should just not render its button that toggles it back and forth between a callback and a value.

title: Having large featureData in URL slows down jbrowse-web
body:
Having large feature data in the URL, which can come from a long read or gene feature with many subfeatures (as all of this is encoded into the URL) can result in slowness because then it is subsequently run through the deflate+base64 mechanism in the URL encoding (of which the deflate part is the most expensive part)

This was mentioned in #432 and is a concrete specific thing (e.g. probably removing featureData from the session

Large computations hang the client side 1s repeatedly on each session update for a 10,000bp read (pretty standard long read)

title: getConf(track, 'adapter') doesn't instantiate defaultValue entries
Re-organize the readme
body: This is a small README update that removes the plugin development notes and moves it to the docs folder. It also suggests running yarn start in jbrowse-web or jbrowse-desktop

title: Handle BED header in spreadsheet view
body:
```
track name='ClinGen Gene Curation Triplosensitivity Scores' db=hg19
chr1    100652477       100715409       DBT     Not yet evaluated
chr1    103342022       103574052       COL11A1 0
chr1    10535002        10690815        PEX14   0
chr1    10696660        10856733        CASZ1   0
chr1    109419602       109476957       GPSM2   0
chr1    109606997       109618624       TAF13   0
chr1    110091185       110138465       GNAI3   0
chr1    11072678        11085549        TARDBP  0
```


The track header in BED file is kinda weird, causes spreadsheet view crash. Note that the header is not delimited by hashes e.g. `#`. Lines that are the header start with "browser" or "track" https://genome.ucsc.edu/FAQ/FAQformat.html#format1

I had a file I found in the wild that had these lines and it caused "TypeError: Cannot read property 'text' of undefined"

title: Spawn a linear-comparative-view alignment detail from a PileupTrack
body:
depends on #820 and #399 

We have a scenario where we want to inspect a structural variant that we find while looking at a linear genome view (as opposed to a SV inspector). This can come from a feature on a VCF or from an alignment e.g. long read

We propose a right-click menu that allows spawning the linear-comparative-view 

The scenario of inspecting  insertions or  deletions will be especially aided by the linear-comparative-view, possibly where the thing being compared is a long-read vs the reference or contig-vs-reference

title: Fix a few browser incompatiblilties
body:
I wanted to see if JBrowse 2 works on the new [Chromium-based Edge browser](https://blogs.windows.com/windowsexperience/2020/01/15/new-year-new-browser-the-new-microsoft-edge-is-out-of-preview-and-now-available-for-download/), and it seems to work fine with no changes. While I had my Windows environment going, I tried jbrowse-web in the old Edge browser to see what would happen. With a couple changes, I got it going on the old Edge (except for Canvas-based tracks, and the layout was a bit off), and it looks like these changes will be relevant to Safari, too.

(Also note, I had to use the production build to get it to work on the old Edge, since our development build just targets Chrome)

* Use [`fastestsmallesttextencoderdecoder`](https://github.com/anonyco/FastestSmallestTextEncoderDecoder) instead of `text-encoding-polyfill`. `text-encoding-polyfill` is the same as `text-encoding`, which is deprecated and no longer maintained. I tried `fast-text-encoding`, but it doesn't support the `fatal` option for `TextDecoder`, which we use.
  * Instead of importing the polyfill in the plugins, just assume it exists and polyfill it in jbrowse-web or tests as needed.
* Polyfill `requestIdleCallback`
* Check for `OffscreenCanvas` during startup of jbrowse-web, and no longer throw an error when it's not found in `offscreenCanvasPonyfill.js`. Checking for `window.chrome` doesn't work, since apparently the old Edge has a `window.chrome`. For now we just assume if it has `OffscreenCanvas`, it has the other things we need. We can add more detailed feature sniffing later.

title: Don't throw error from offscreenCanvasPolyfill
body: This gets rid of the concept of throwing an error from offscreenCanvasPolyfill as this fatally errors out browsers instead of allowing us to give our unsupported message

title: Re-enable yarn upgrade
body:
This makes it so that running `yarn upgrade` shouldn't break everything anymore. Basically, some of the rescripts were looking for `babel-plugin-named-asset-import` in the top-level `node_modules`, which meant keeping a duplicate there that might get out of sync. Now they properly look for it as a dep of the `react-scripts` package, as well as giving the instances of the plugins a unique name just in case.

I also upgraded all our deps, which was mostly uneventful, except the most recent versions of material-ui which made it have to update a couple tests slightly and update some snapshots. Also looks like a few `prettier` rules updated, too, and changed a few things.

Resolves #585

title: spreadsheet column filters, SV inspector can now show features from CSV/TSV
body:
* adds the ability to add additional filters to the spreadsheet view, each of which adds a toolbar to the edit and remove the filter at the top, giving you a (I think) easily understandable "stack" of filters that are easy to control.
* improves the machinery around column types, adding 4 new column types for feature locations (LocString, LocRef, LocStart, and LocEnd), and makes LocString columns be links that will open a new genome view
* adds some basic auto-detection of column data types (Text, Number, LocString) during CSV/TSV import


So now you can make filters on each column, and the SV inspector will show features if your CSV or TSV has 2 locstrings or 2 sets of ref/start/end, and importing will do some limited type detection.

Resolves #690 
Also resolves #714 
Also resolves #755

title: Create more "untangled" SV inspector views
body:
At least one set of feedback from SV inspector demo is to create less overlapping from the features

Approaches to this, to me could include

(a) joint layout
(b) parameter to the layout: sort by feature name
(c) single line SV inspector (left-right split view instead of top bottom)

title: Fix horizontal flip in translocation
body:
Fixes #773 

The synteny_demo branch worked a bit on the getPxFromCoordinate concept so this enhances the getPxFromCoordinate call for the breakpoint split view which takes into account horizontal flipping and has a further bugfix (see removed TODO comment in this PR) that is relevant to the code being scalable to there being multiple displayedRegions in a single row of the breakpoint split view (previously assumed just one displayedRegion in the split view)

title: Dynamically toggle off feature labels and descriptions at high zoom levels
body:
When zoomed out of a gene track, an SVG track's labels and descriptions overwhelmingly take over the screen real estate

In JBrowse 1, the feature density governs when to toggle off the feature labels and descriptions

title: Synteny and/or breakpoint split view in the middle, possibly instead of as overlay
body:
As visual inspiration
![](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/EFxsy_GX0AI-v0N?format=jpg&name=900x900)

Instead of making the synteny draw within the views space, as the breakpoint split view has, it can maybe be nice to just have it in the middle

I tested it out here https://github.com/GMOD/jbrowse-components/tree/synteny_in_the_middle

There is a weird sort of conceptualization that is a little different than overlay which is that it assumes, for example, that if you have 3 views, view 1 isn't going to connect to view 3, just 1->2 and 2->3

title: Make pluggable glyph type
body:
This was not a commonly extended feature in JB1 but it can enable some special use-cases

Could be done for both canvas (which is currently just pileup, but it being just pileup may need revisiting) and svg if needed

title: Add reduced representation of genes
body:
Adds a couple features for reduced representation of genes via "displayMode" on PileupRenderer and SvgFeatureRenderer

Also renames alignmentHeight to just height

The displayMode code here has to do some work in various parts of the code here, it's be nice if it was a little more hands-off, but it does accomplish jbrowse 1 compatibility

title: Filter AlignmentsTrack
body: Specifically bitmask (BAM flag https://broadinstitute.github.io/picard/explain-flags.html) filters have been requested.

title: Filter VariantTrack by VCF's FILTER column
body: Filter by VCF FILTER == "PASS", or by any other combination of detected filters. Remember VCF's FILTER can be an array of filter strings.

title: update root model to support multi-assembly tracks
body:
The track model can be useful for synteny, even though it doesn't necessarily fit the conventional notion of a track, so that users can edit colors, turn on and off an overlay, etc.

Some possible todos

Make the hierarchical track selector use dataset as a source of tracks instead of an assembly name?

We discussed about how we could allow multiple datasets per assembly name, so I am trying to fit that into the picture that we have where we are selecting a assembly name in  various concepts.

title: Make changing filters trigger a layout change, see #597
Propagate feature ID store prefix across more adapters
body:
Currently feature IDs can collide from different adapters by chance

NCList is an example where it does this already

title: Usage of the ?config= causes missing track ID
body:
Using ?config= results in a fully alternate config being loaded. I find this very useful for testing things. However, the local storage will get filled with a session and then this results in "Failed to resolve reference to some_track_id" when going to a different config

Solutions include

1) Removing local storage from anything I load from ?config=
2) Removing ?config=
3) Fixing  to make it so it so that localstorage is related to the active config or some early warning mismatch

title: JBrowse 1 Connection updates
body:
This fixes a few things found while @keiranmraine has been testing connections with his JBrowse 1 configs

- Connections can no longer provide reference sequences for datasets. It was unused, complicated, and probably didn't actually work correctly. We'll add back in the ability to add assembly sequences from certain types of sources (like JBrowse 1) later as part of dataset management.
- If the JBrowse 1 track is recognized as valid, it just flags it as unsupported and moves on instead of erroring out
- JBrowse 1 store classes are used to guess the JBrowse 2 track and adapters, and if the store class isn't recognized it falls back to guessing based on the `urlTemplate` filename
- When falling back to `urlTemplate` filename, it now recognizes the `.bgz` file extension for block-gzipped files

I'll send a build based on this to Keiran

title: Find way to share code between jbrowse-web and jbrowse-desktop
Remove `configId`
body:
This gets rid of `configId`s in the config schemas. It's now possible to specify an option in a config schema to define an identifier. The options that do that are `explicitIdentifier` and `implicitIdentifier` (mutually exclusive). With `explicitIdentifier`, the config snapshot must have an identifier. With `implicitIdentifier`, an identifier will be generated if the config snapshot doesn't have one (similar to the old `configId` behavior). If you specify something like `{ explicitIdentifier: 'trackId' }`, then the name of the identifier will be `trackId`, otherwise if you just put `{ explicitIdentifier: true }`, the name of the identifier will be `id`. `implicitIdentifier` isn't currently used, and we may remove it in the future if it turns out there's no need for it.

Currently track and connection configs are the only things that define ids (`trackId` and `connectionId`, respectively). There were some usages of adapter ids, but they weren't used as MST references, just as ways to keep track of adapters. These have been replaced by keeping track of the adapter by `json-stable-stringify`ing its contents (dataAdapterCache.js already did this).

A few small notes:

- There are some things commented out in a couple of the connections that are due for proper removal as part of of addressing #513. I didn't want to get them working with this change just to get rid of them.
- We started removing configuration from views a while back, and this fully removes them. None of the views had any configuration defined, anyway.
- I re-created all our config files by loading them and then re-exporting them, so they should now match exactly what our MST snapshots look like. I deleted a few configs that appear to be unused, but can re-create and update them if someone needs them. Deleted files:
  - test_data/config_circular_test.json
  - test_data/config_human_circular.json
  - test_data/config_integration_test_displayed_region_list.json
  - test_data/root.snap.1.json

Resolves #722

title: Get MCScan data loaded for synteny view
body:
The data format is

anchors
```
grape   peach   score
grape   peach   score
grape   peach   score
grape   peach   score
###
grape   peach   score
grape   peach   score
grape   peach   score
grape   peach   score
###
...
```

there is another anchors.simple format containing 

```
grape_start grape_end peach_start peach_end ...
grape_start grape_end peach_start peach_end ...
```

this collapses all the anchor blocks to a start & end gene

This needs to be collected and rendered against the source file's gff to get chromosome coordinates. there are also coordinate agnostic plots just based on gene rank too
