title: Fix scrolling the App pane
body:
This addresses #440 Some app notes: The preventDefault at the lower level appears to prevent scrolling at all levels You can see this in a basic html script like this where scrolling in the inner div, which preventDefault's the wheel event, makes it so the outer one does not scroll (I think this is basically equivalent circumstances ```
``` The unfortunate aspect of this is that we have to manually scroll both the track and the app vertically. Note: most of the problems here can be sort of seen as coming back to this idea that the TrackRenderingContainer is horizontally scrollable but it just has overflowX: 'hidden'. It is difficult to disable scrolling without preventDefault but when that happens all vertical scrolling stops. This also addresses an unaddressed problem of #439 which was that if you did scrolling outside the track e.g. in the blank areas before or after a chromosome it could trigger horizontal scrolls that caused #437 so I moved the wheel listener to TrackRenderingContainer

title: Vertical scrolling of the entire App view preventDefault'd
body:
Following things like fix #439 

We preventDefault on all wheel events, which prevents all wheel events that originate over a track from getting to the App view

While the #439 fix is important, it might be that a different fix is needed to allow easier scrolling of the entire app view (either via making a similar thing to propagate the deltaY to the App level or other method)

title: Fix vertical scrolling
body:
This makes it so that scroll events are always get event.preventDefault()'d but they get propagated "appropriately" via callback props. The track rendering container handles the vertical scroll so it is propagated to there. A modularized "TrackContainer" containing current scroll state is extracted from inside the LinearGenomeView

Addresses #437

title: session versioning and migration
body:
After we start having public releases, we will need to version our session snapshots so that older sessions can be opened in newer versions of the browser.

We will eventually need migration logic to upgrade old snapshots so that they can be opened in newer versions of the browser, but for now let's just get version numbers in the session snapshots.

title: Scrolling down in a track can result in the track then extending to the left of the view
body:
This is pretty reproducible by 

1. zooming out so the alignments track has a scrollbar
2. then scrolling sideways to the right
3. scroll up and down inside the alignments track
4. go back to beginning of chromosome

body:
This proposes a fix for #347 

It requires changing some CSS at two locations (the WiggleRendering div and removing the wrapper div around the SVG)

I don't fully *get it* but this seems to work and is at least a fairly minimal change set

title: move trackSelectorType out of views
body:
The choice of track selector view shouldn't be tied to each data view. It is usually chosen based on the number of tracks and the characteristics of the track metadata.

But where should that configuration be?  Need to discuss this in grooming.

title: reduce LGV block rerenders to speed up scrolling
body:
Right now, the Block and Ruler elements updating as you scroll is starting to have a real performance impact.

It's due to code like this:

https://github.com/GMOD/jbrowse-components/blob/master/packages/linear-genome-view/src/LinearGenomeView/components/ScaleBar.js#L59

and this:

https://github.com/GMOD/jbrowse-components/blob/master/packages/linear-genome-view/src/BasicTrack/components/TrackBlocks.js#L56


Need to reduce the rerenders of these blocks, using the techniques in https://mobx.js.org/best/react-performance.html

title: Use IntersectionObserver for scrolling LGV
body:
I haven't evaluated what would be needed but I think using the IntersectionObserver API could be an interesting optimization for the linear genome view


https://medium.com/the-non-traditional-developer/how-to-use-an-intersectionobserver-in-a-react-hook-9fb061ac6cb5

title: Reduce amount of information in session
Integration tests each need a separate file (?)
body:
Right now we have the integration tests for jbrowse-web in JBrowse.test.js. I have been having a lot of trouble getting the tests to pass for #430, even where I don't feel like what I did really should affect some of the tests that aren't passing.

After doing a bunch of digging, I've found out that even though we're using `afterEach(cleanup)`, some of the tests are affecting other tests, so they're not isolated from each other. One concrete example is the menus. When you click on a menu title in the menu bar, such as "HELP", it opens the menu. The implementation of the menu in material-ui ends up using `ReactDOM.createPortal(menuStuff, document.body)`, which adds the menu to `document.body` at _the same level_ as the app, so it looks like:

```html
<body>
  <div>
    app stuff...
  </ div>
  <div>
    menu stuff...
  </ div>
</body>
```

`afterEach(cleanup)` then only cleans up the original `div` and not the new menu `div`. Also, since the only way to search for things in the menu is to search the whole body (since they're all at the root level), different tests that use then menus could end up finding things in menu `div`s that they didn't create.

We could try to work around this problem (maybe find some way to not use Popper from material-ui), but I get the feeling that this isn't the only cross-test contamination that's happening. It's just the first concrete example I was able to find. So, I think we need to run each integration test in isolation.

I've tried things like creating a new JSDOM document for each test, but can't find a way to have each test in the same file have a different global `document`. Thus to truly isolate the tests we may have to put each integration test in its own file.

title: Save and load sessions
body:
The first change is that the config file no longer has "session" and "sessionSnapshots". It just has "savedSessions" and optionally "activeSession", which is just the name of one of the sessionSnapshots. The actual active session is stored separately. It looks like this:

```
        ┌───────sessionModel (the UI state)
rootModel
        └───────jbrowseModel (the config, basically)
```

Here is how things get loaded:

- Checks for a saved config in localStorage
  - If none in localStorage, uses the one in the React props
- Creates model with config
- Checks for a session in the URL
  - Can be either the name of one of the "savedSessions" or a whole encoded session
  - If none in URL, checks localStorage
  - If also none in localStorage, uses the first entry in "savedSessions"
  - If none in "savedSessions" uses "defaultSession" (which can be in the config, but has a default of just a name and menu bar if there isn't one in the config)
- Loads session
- URL gets updated with encoded session every 3 seconds
- Config and session get written to localStorage every 3 seconds
- Any updates to the currently active session get automatically written to the corresponding "savedSession" in the config

Using the Google Docs paradigm, here are the UI actions this enables:

* File -> New Session opens a "defaultSession" (appends the date and time to the default session name for uniqueness)
* File -> Open Session... opens a drawer widget where you can see saved sessions and click on one to open it
* File -> Duplicate Session makes a copy of the current session and names it the session name with " (copy)" appended
* Session name is editable from the menu bar

I was worried some of these things wouldn't work with undo/redo, so I looked into it and it was actually pretty simple to add undo/redo, so I just did it. It's pretty raw, but but basically works. Also, my worries were unfounded, undo/redo seems to work fine with these changes.

Screenshots:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/62141983-84e8f980-b2bb-11e9-9d28-0aeb7ab6f5b8.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/62142025-992cf680-b2bb-11e9-85d4-9ad53959dd87.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/62142090-ae098a00-b2bb-11e9-8267-2844f33595e3.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/62142179-d3969380-b2bb-11e9-9667-129f92f23d8e.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/62142198-dabda180-b2bb-11e9-96a5-e9240967c63c.png)

resolves #146 
fixes #420

title: White unfilled blocks in human BAM data on initial load
body:
![localhost_3000_ (3)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6511937/61717230-b0ee0300-ad2e-11e9-8282-52edadb4254b.png)


Simply loading up a BAM track at the default configured view position in human seems to produce this

title: Add better browser error messaging
body:
In aims of addressing #21 

This PR

a) adds a simple modernizr config to check for bad browser
b) adds a better error message for firefox's bad offscreen canvas, we will probably need to address that for real in some way but I figure we just keep most of firefox working for now

The way we check for a try/catch on getContext isn't ideal but I found that if the error that gets thrown from offscreenCanvasPolyfill was not caught it fatal error's the whole app (could be a separate issue to follow up on)

title: Add SVG labels with ellipsis
body:
This aims to address some concerns in #381 

It adds ellipses for textWidths that are very long instead of trying to pack it into the a small range constrained by textWidth. It also removes the usage of textWidth so that it always keeps the natural text layout

It keeps the estimator of fontWidth*55 (we saw in the thread #381 that this can overestimate which is why the text looked weird)

I added a test track with a test for the ellipses with an integration test

Aside: I looked a little bit into what might be possible with measuring the text but the interplay with the layout means that it would have to calculate things like this up front instead and we couldn't really use things like this https://reactjs.org/docs/hooks-faq.html#how-can-i-measure-a-dom-node afaik since we'd have to do that, then send that back to the layout via a callback, and then it would have to re-render which would definitely induce a double render (whereas that method might not)

title: Create "add track" and "add connection" menu
make TransferableFeatureSet, Feature.toArrayBuffer
body:
make a TransferableFeatureSet object that holds a bunch of features in one or more arrayBuffers.

In the worker, constructing the set will call toArrayBuffer on each of the features, and record that feature's class and offset in an index.

Draft API:

* get(featureId) -> a lazy feature object
* [iterator symbol] iterate over the entries
* .entries() get entries arrays for all the features in the set

title: Bump material-ui version
body: This allows us to move slider from @material-ui/lab into @material-ui/core

title: Add Code of Conduct
body: As discussed in the email thread. Let me know if you think we should keep or get rid of the README badge.

title: Session API
body:
I'm basing this PR off the new session branch for now so changes are more clear.

This is something I ran into in the session branch I threw away, so I've pulled in things here that I tried. Basically, "session" is called in the code a lot, and for us to be able to easily combine JBrowse2 components into different products and to support plugins, we need to say what a session can do. I made some changes to consolidate the session actions a bit. With these changes, all the actions or views on the session are (this doesn't include stuff in e.g. the ui/ dir of jbrowse-web, it only applies to plugins):
```
display()
hide()
displayed
select()
selection
configuration
datasets
connections
makeConnection()
breakConnection()
pluginManager
rpcManager

// and optionally
assemblyData
```

Looking at this list, the connections and datasets likely should be replaced by something more generic, but I'm not sure what yet.

Also, after these changes, it was pretty easy to get the protein-widget working again since I knew what actions/views the root MST model needed.

Another thing we probably need is some mock session in core/ for testing that has the minimum session pieces mocked out so that plugins can stop importing `createTestEnv` from jbrowse-web.

title: Lessen the amount of information about features that should be serialized
body:
Recalling issue #229, we decided against this concept, but it could be worth reconsidering

Currently we do send the layout to the main thread, which makes some things easier, but if a feature has a lot of metadata, say a BAM feature, then I wonder if this can end up slowing our app down serializing every single BAM feature's complete details, because it needs the complete serialization in order to reconstitute the feature details widget for the alignments

title: Figure out the relative path system of the data directories
body:
This is a little vague but the relative paths system for data directories is an important part of the configuration/data loading system

Currently we hardcode the path `/test_data/` in things like config_volvox.json

I think our configurations should be absent of this

title: Restore horizontal flip of entire LGV
body:
Even with the idea of #258 we should be able to flip the view of the entire LGV. This was a feature we had but was removed.

Depends on #400, because the "flip" button should go in the LGV header.

title: Renamed reference doesnt work with BigWig local autoscale
body:
The getMultiRegionStats doesn't work with the RpcManager's treatment of reference renaming

Maybe wait on the session code to figure this out

Note that this passes a variable "regions" that all need renaming potentially. Sort of similar to some stuff rbuels is working on too

title: Disable hot module reloading
body: We don't get any benefit from this it seems as all changes basically trigger a full page reload

title: Optimize clicks and mouseovers on pileup
body: This is a possible optimization: currently any click requires actually searching through a list of all features to get which rectangle was clicked. It would be better if there was a mapping from coordinate space to feature. If mouseovers are to be implemented that give us any info, this is probably required.

title: Callback editor fixes
body:
This proposes fixes for callback editing to address issue #393 
I made these changes

1) make the CallbackEditor use react hooks
2) only update the callback if it passes a baseline stringToFeature test
3) remove the try/catch from the SvgFeatureRendering loop

Together, this appears to address some basic callback concerns

Either detach nodes first, or don't use objects after removing / replacing them in the tree." all coming from RpcManager related region code for attributes like "refName", "assemblyName", "start", "end"

I imagine this is related?

title: Modify how SimpleFeature.fromJSON is called to fix NCList features
body:
This modifies how SimpleFeature.fromJSON is called, which helps fix issues we were seeing in #396 

The features being received are raw objects that contain a uniqueId

SimpleFeature actually expects the uniqueId to be inside of {data:{uniqueId:..., ...}} though

By placing the fromJSON call to expect the data to be in a "data" property the code works again. It reduces confusion about when a feature actually has an "id" as in column 9 of GFF

This also says that we do not display a feature name as feature.id(), since this is often autocomputed. We only display an "id" if it is from feature.get('id')

Add a header (blue maybe?) to the linear genome view that has

This can be a context menu for features that will use the ActionManager #211

The initial implementation does not necessarily need to use the action manager to dispatch the actions when clicked, if the action manager isn't done yet.

title: Move event handlers to linear genome view and allow vertical scrolling
body:
This addresses #142 by just allowing vertical scrolling on individual tracks. This specific change is actually a smaller part of this PR

The main action of this PR is to move the event handlers from the track to the LGV. It also moves the Rubberbanding logic directly into the LGV also.

I felt that the existing "Rubberband" component that existed was containing the logic that could be used to implement a highlight, so I made it so Rubberband was just a stateful instance of a highlight in the LGV

The logic of the linear genome view ends up looking a bit more complicated after this but I think it puts the logic for things like scrolling and rubberband zoom in the right location, that could be modularized out as a hook behavior if there is a need

Other notes, the scroll deltaX should be sufficient and we shouldn't need to check other types of deltas on the event as React should have smoothed over this event for us already.
Also the performance concern mentioned in gitter shouldn't be an issue anymore. I was seeing some slower behavior with the devtools open, but it is gone when devtools is closed

title: "Add linear genome view" devtool has empty tracklist
New session under new root
body:
My last branch had some problems which became even more apparent when I tried to merge in the latest stuff from master. It was trying to do too many things at once. This is a subset of those changes, and I'll factor the other changes out into separate PRs after this.

This changes the former root model to the "session" and adds a `getSession` util to use in place of `getRoot`. The root is now a separate model above the sessions. The pluginManager and rpcManager are there, so they can be shared by all the sessions.

~~One effect of having things like this is that we now have to make sure that any IDs (track IDs, drawer widget IDs, etc.) are unique not just in their session, but in all active sessions so that MST doesn't complain about having multiple possible targets for a reference.~~(No longer true)

resolves #315 
resolves #388 
resolves #403

This proposes a fix to warnings like this in the tests

```
  console.warn node_modules/mobx-state-tree/dist/mobx-state-tree.js:3007                                                                                                                             [28/28]
    Error: [mobx-state-tree] You are trying to read or write to an object that is no longer part of a state tree. (Object type was 'AnonymousModel'). Either detach nodes first, or don't use objects after 
removing / replacing them in the tree.           
```

We check isAlive before updating the statetree, and also check whether it is a state tree at all because it appears some not state tree things can come through here.

title: Extra block render
body: This is a proposal to add a rendering of an extra block on each side of the screen. There is a cost associated with this in terms of data fetching. At high zoom levels it makes scrolling look much better though. Potentially an extra block could be fetched only if you are at more zoomed-in levels so that it would not incur heavy amounts of data fetching.

Avoiding this could involve proper usage of calculating textLength or not using textLength as an actual SVG attribute

title: structural variant detail/QC/toolbar view
body:
Structural variants can be really complex.

Let's make a first-class view (same screen real estate as an LGV or a circular view) that focuses on a specific variant call to examine the evidence for it and visualize it in different ways to understand it.

A "variant" in this case is a group of breakends (grouped by EVENT, PARID, and/or MATEID), or an insertion, a deletion, or even a SNP.

It would have some basic details about the variant in it, such as the name, number of breakends, insertion length if it's an insertion, etc.

And then it would have buttons along the top to spawn different views of the variant.  Show it in a linear view, in a whole-genome circular view, etc.

For an insertion, it would be nice to open a special view with a gapped reference to see the insertion in context.

title: find complicated human VCF data for testing
body:
Stuff like

* MATEID and PARID used together
* insert sequences as part of a breakend
* breakends that contain uncertainty
* EVENT groups
* breakends with no MATE
* any usage of genotypes with these calls??

body:
When I run tests I often get an error message NetworkError. Sometimes it is just console logged as an unhandled exception and tests pass, sometimes it fails them.

I saw this just now running tests locally (failed the tests that normally pass on master locally)

```

```

Also see this on travis pretty often in render.test.js (so unrelated to nclist) https://travis-ci.com/GMOD/jbrowse-components/builds/117598430#L1036-L1043

title: Fix sidescrolling smoothness
body:
This proposes speeding up scrolling noted in #365 by using the timeout on requestIdleCallback, which I set to a very short value. This requires unpolyfilled requestIdleCallback due to the shim library not passing the options to the global.requestIdleCallback (see https://github.com/santiagogil/request-idle-callback/issues/2)

If a polyfill is strongly needed for a particular browser we can find a workaround.

I also removed the nested requestIdleCallback because I wasn't sure if it was aiding smoothness, but I could restore. Also, more speculative outside-the-viewport data rendering could make it perceived as smoother since the content would just be ready before you arrive there via scrolling

title: replace UCSC page scraping with UCSC json API
body:
Use the [UCSC API](https://genome.ucsc.edu/goldenPath/help/api.html) /list/ucscGenomes endpoint instead of scraping UCSC's web page in packages/data-management/scripts/getUcscAssemblies.js

This is for getting default .2bit files to use when track hubs don't specify them.

title: Add free resources
body:
This implements the freeResources function for serverSideRenderedBlock using the beforeDestroy method


Then it wires up rpc calls to freeResources for the renderer (which performs discardRange) and the data adapters



It also performs serialize region to only send features relevant to a region to the client for things like pileup renderer (see #229). The logic here is that instead of not sending the layout, we just try to optimize the layout that is sent, because not sending the layout could incur some trouble (e.g. makes mouseovers more difficult or similar)

Feel free to test this out and let me know how it works

title: pileup renderer needs a maxheight
body:
The pileup render needs a maximum height limit for how deep it will lay out features.

Probably the best way is to configure the layout with a certain max height, and have it return undefined from `addRect` if that is reached. Then the pileup renderer can tell the front end that the max height is reached, and the frontend track can draw a little indicator to notify the user that it's deeper than what can be laid out.

title: Blocks aren't filled for bigwig or pileup rendered alignments while sidescrolling continuously
body:
If I sidescroll continuously without any pause (e.g. a slow move of fingers across touchpad) then the bigwig and pileup rendered alignments track does not render new blocks as you scroll, only when you stop or create a momentary stop in the scroll. This isn't critical but it looks better way better if the blocks load on demand during scroll, otherwise it just is a white unfilled block as you scroll slowly sideways that gets filled in only when you stop

Other tracks such as the reference sequence track and svgfeatures appear to work in this scenario

body:

For whole genome views such as circos we need to stream pretty much a full VCF file to get all features. We have seen examples like https://downloads.pacbcloud.com/public/dataset/HG002_SV_and_SNV_CCS/pbsv/ where breakends are mixed in with other SV calls, so it's worth it to make this scalable and maybe use some streaming (or iterate over bgzip blocks in some other way)

title: Plugins to Packages
body:
I've got several new packages with this: alignments, linear-genome-view, sequence, and wiggle. In general, the structure I've been working toward is this:

```text
package-name/
├── package.json
├── tsconfig.json
└── src
    ├── index.js
    ├── index.test.js
    ├── PluggableElementOne
    │   ├── configSchema.js
    │   ├── index.js
    │   └── model.js
    └── PluggableElementTwo
        ├── configSchema.js
        ├── index.js
        ├── model.js
        └── components
            └── PluggableElementTwo.js
```

Each pluggable element has its own directory (although many of the individual pluggable elements pull code from others in the same package). The pluggable element exports its model, configSchema, React component, etc., and the main package index.js imports all this and creates the plugin class.

The plugins I haven't done so far are BigBedAdapter, FilteringTrack, FromConfigAdapter, LollipopRenderer, MainMenuBar, ProteinReferenceSequenceRenderer, SvgFeatureRenderer. My instinct is to just move everything out into packages since it will probably all get re-bundled into jbrowse-image, jbrowse-lite, etc. If anyone thinks anything anything should stay just in jbrowse-web, let me know.

resolves #333

title: special "feature detail" session URL
body:
Make the session URL parsing support a special nice-looking "feature detail" session URL, that just opens a particular feature detail view in the main area, with no other views open.

This would basically allow people to link to JBrowse feature detail pages to use them as quick-and-dirty gene pages.

Maybe something like `/feature_detail/trackID/locstring/featureID`

Depends on #71 and #353

title: main-area feature detail view
body:
We need a view in the main area that *just* looks at the details of a particular feature in a particular track.

A feature is uniquely addressable by the combination of its:
* track ID that it comes from
* location in that track
* uniqueID of the feature

This main-area feature detail view can be used for comparing the details of two different features, or for making really basic "gene page" displays that can be linked externally (in combination with #TODO).

title: Update DynamoDB table to have proper query-ability and add sort key
body:
Since our DynamoDB partition key is unique, we can't Query our DynamoDB table, we can only Scan it. We might want to think about what kind of data we want to get out of the table most often and then recreate it with a different partition key. (https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/database/choosing-the-right-dynamodb-partition-key/)

Talked with @cmdcolin, and it sounds like having "host" as a partition key might be best for analytics.

DynamoDB says it splits tables on sort key when it is greater than 10gb. I am not sure if our current table has a sort key and it is >1gb now

title: Proposed updates to VCF Feature
body:
When I re-did JB1's VcfFeature after the create of vcf-js, I had to keep a lot of things compatible with the old VCF features. Since we're not bound by that in JB2, I'd like to propose some changes:

- Just assume what's in `get()` is the correct case, don't mess with `toLowerCase()` at all.
- Get rid of references to "genotypes", since really it's actually sample-specific data that can contain a lot more than just genotypes
- Just have `get()` access the variant information as-is. Only store in `data` things that are derived from the variant info (like SO terms).
- Don't copy INFO fields into `data`. This has the danger of overriding other fields and I think can be a bit confusing.

Here's what's available via `get()`:
```js
console.log(feature.tags())
// ["refName", "start", "end", "description", "type", "name", "aliases", "CHROM", "POS", "ID", "REF", "ALT", "QUAL", "FILTER", "INFO", "samples", "SAMPLES"]
```
(I aliased "samples" to "SAMPLES" since "SAMPLES" isn't actually a VCF field like "ALT", "QUAL", etc. are.)

This makes it so metadata like "description" aren't in the feature data itself, but they can still be easily accessed by doing e.g. `feature.parser.getMetadata('INFO', 'DP')`

Hopefully these changes make the relationship between the feature and the underlying VCF data more clear. Thoughts?

title: Add a BUILT_TESTS flag for the fs.exists tests
body: This adds a BUILT_TESTS flag to the CI. This can allow tests to fail faster on CI. It doesn't necessarily give you a green light faster but it gives you a red light faster.

title: move most plugins into packages/ directory in monorepo
body: Right now most plugins are in jbrowse-web/src, but they need to move out into packages/

title: test native async iterators for data adapters
body:
rxjs has a steep learning curve and its documentation is fragmented and hard to quickly grasp. JS has native asynchronous iteration (`for await (...) { ... }`) that seems to be well supported now.

However, there has been some uncertainty around the web about whether async iteration is slow. Let's make a branch of JB2 that changes the data adapter API to use async iterators instead of rxjs observables, and see if it's any faster.

The best vehicle for this would probably be the BAM data adapter, used with the high-coverage human BAM in our human development dataset.

title: Pluggable connections
Top-level error handling
body:
When an error is uncaught, we need to bring that to the user's attention, probably with a SnackBar or other dismissable error dialog with some kind of expansion functionality, similar to what VS code and Atom do. We also would like to capture the full error details as much as possible to give the development team as much as possible to go on when troubleshooting.

This is the last-resort global error handler. Views and components should make every effort to handle errors internally in smart ways.

title: Re-organize docs for easier onboarding
body:
As part of an effort to make docs accessible, I think it is worthwhile to make the README files more minimal, and link to different places for detailed information.

-<root>/README.md <minimal quick start guide basically>
-<root>/docs/README.md
-<root>/packages/jbrowse-web/README.md <minimal quick start guide basically>
-<root>/packages/core/README.md <minimal>
-<root>/docs/developer/renderer.md <renderer / developer mind mapping about renderer>
-<root>/docs/developer/monorepo.md <lerna concepts>

These types of docs in the docs directory can get rolled into a packaged documentation solution like docusaurus at some point (or maybe docs folders inside respective packages). README's can stay minimal.

Concept
https://github.com/GMOD/jbrowse-components/tree/docs_reorganization

title: track selector loading optimizations
body:
Right now HierarchicalTrackSelector uses requestIdleCallback to load tracks incrementally since it's pretty slow for hundreds to thousands of tracks. For small numbers of tracks, though, the requestIdleCallback overhead probably makes things slower. Likely need to do a few things:
* Figure out if Material-UI is slowing things down significantly
  * If so, are there optimizations/workarounds?
  * Would a simple checkbox-list component without all the Material-UI overhead be worth it?
* Make track selector lazy only after some X number of tracks

title: add button to block loading and error messages to force a reload of the block
body: If something goes wrong with a block, the user should be able to click this button and try to force a reload manually.

title: Worker overhaul
body:
spawns multiple web workers, up to the client machine's number of cores minus 2 (can detect this from navigator.hardwareConcurrency).

improves performance of web worker data transfer by recognizing more objects as [Transferable](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Transferable)

pings workers at a hardcoded interval and terminates+replaces them if they don't respond.

fixes #30 
fixes #295 
fixes #305

title: open igv "genome server" format as a data hub
body: see https://software.broadinstitute.org/software/igv/configuring_genome_server for how these go

title: split out a separate "session" model from the root model
body:
There are some things about the application state that should not be contained in a session, such as:
* user login state (such as authentication tokens that have been gotten from somewhere)
* the rpc manager
* maybe the assembly manager?
* "app-level" configuration/state, such as the desired number of web workers, language/i18n settings, etc

I propose renaming the current root model to the "session" model and making it a child of the new root model user the key `session`.

This would simplify switching between sessions as well, because then we could just use MST machinery like everything else does, instead of react state.

Thoughts?

title: Make connections pluggable

What if someone has some random data or API and they want to build a connection to that just populates a couple tracks in the connection? If connections are pluggable and flexible, it could be an easy way to do that.

title: Make data access modules pure node (no Babel)?
body:
I'm opening this issue so we can keep track of a discussion about it, and then we can decide if we actually want to do it or not.

I know Rob had this idea and he and I have talked about this, but what if we got rid of Babel on our data access modules (bam-js, bbi-js, vcf-js, etc.)? We would just write them in pure Node (might need Node 10+ for some modules), and if someone wants to use them on the web, they just need to make sure their webpack is set up to handle it.

This would hopefully simplify maintaining the data access modules since we wouldn't have to deal with Babel runtime stuff, etc. It would hopefully make them function better as generic libraries, too.

A big argument against this is not being able to use TypeScript.

One other thing, I know some of our modules build a webpack bundle so people can use them in the web without having their own webpack toolchain. Do we want to make that consistent across our modules, or just on a case-by-case basis?

What have I missed in this discussion?

title: Create BEDPE parser
body:
BEDPE data is a simple format that shows interactions between two regions of the genome, and sometimes breakend data can come in this format

Small data files could be parsed in their entirety

Larger files might need a 2D index scheme (e.g. pairix).

Many applications end up with this type of data and/or a subtype of it

* gene fusion
* sv
* hi-c

https://github.com/cancerit/BRASS/wiki/BEDPE
https://support.10xgenomics.com/genome-exome/software/pipelines/latest/output/bedpe
https://docs.higlass.io/data_preparation.html

title: spawn multiple web workers
body:
The web worker RPC driver supports state groups, which ensures that RPC calls in the same state group are always sent to the same web worker, so that they can get good caching behavior.

But we don't launch multiple web workers yet. We should launch and register multiple web workers. Detect the number of cores to launch using `navigator.hardwareConcurrency` https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/workers.html#navigator.hardwareconcurrency.  A polyfill is available at https://github.com/oftn-oswg/core-estimator

title: VCF breakend indexing
body:
The VCF adapter will need an extra index to performantly reconstruct EVENT, MATEID, and PARID groups.

vcf spec: https://samtools.github.io/hts-specs/VCFv4.3.pdf

## strategy
* make a Trix index (depends on #303) of EVENT, MATEID, and PARID names -> list of locations in the file like:
`EVENT:myevent  1:123445,2:2342334,MT:34524`.  We don't want to index every feature's ID, just the ones that appear in MATEID and PARID info attributes.
* can do this on the fly and store the index in `LocalStorage` or `IndexedDB`
* we could eventually make this available as a script that people can run offline

If we want, we could reconstruct MATEID relationships by incrementally re-fetching parts of the file based on the mate location of the breakends. This doesn't work for EVENT and MATEID relationships though. So let's just do the indexing approach first.

I think we can use trix to implement this, so depends on #303 (trix-js)

title: make trix-js
body:
UCSC has a text indexing format called trix that lets you associate a text key with some other text.

https://genome.ucsc.edu/goldenpath/help/trix.html

Let's make a `trix-js` that can read and write these.

title: make a central data proxy
body:
Let's make a central REST API running at https://jbrow.se/proxy that all JBrowses can use to sidestep CORS incompatibilities and to access data that is only available over FTP.

## Implementation Notes

* Use `X-*` request headers as the primary way of communicating side-band stuff like analytics.
* Security strategy
  * File type whitelist, validated by magic number (note that `##gff-version 3` is a magic number, so is `##fileformat=VCF...`) or other deeper data validation if file has no magic number (e.g. fai)
* QoS/rate limiting/usage limiting
  * throttle all clients to 1MB/sec
  * limit range request sizes to 50MB
* Need to make some cost estimates
  * outbound data transfer from AWS is 8-10 cents per GB
  * EBS is 10 cents per month of provisioned storage
  * inbound data transfer is free
  * compute resources should be mild
  * 2 cents per GB transfer S3->proxy


## Architecture

### Version 1 (the stupid thing/MVP)

* EC2 server running a node daemon deployed with pm2, not even caching things, just directly proxying each request, and applying the security logic.
* Not even rate limiting right now
* Not even caching things to the filesystem

### Version 2 (the scalable thing)

* keep file chunks in S3, fronted by Cloudfront.  Cloudfront understands HTTP range requests.
* keep a chunk index in DynamoDB
* when a browser requests something, give them a JSON REST response giving them one or more URLs and ranges that they can fetch to get their data
* when filling the cache, record that the chunk is being filled in the database, and download the chunk from the original destination and put it in S3, then record the chunk in the database
* maybe do the fill in-band, or maybe have a separate worker daemon that queries the DB for chunk fill requests and processes them
* also does rate limiting/QoS
* still does the same security logic
* need an evictor process as well that evicts expired stuff from the cache

## API draft

### GET /v1/{url}

Returns data exactly as if the browser had requested that file from the given URL. The url does not even have to be escaped additionally at all, `https://jbrow.se/proxy/v1/http://terrible.org/some/file/someplace.bw` is valid.

title: Bigbed adapter
Use generic-filehandle for LocalFile and BlobFile
body:
We should integrate @cmdcolin's `generic-filehandle`. Using `generic-filehandle` actually already works if you do this:

```diff
diff --git a/packages/jbrowse-web/src/util/io/index.js b/packages/jbrowse-web/src/util/io/index.js
index 7195301..e2e120f 100644
--- a/packages/jbrowse-web/src/util/io/index.js
+++ b/packages/jbrowse-web/src/util/io/index.js
@@ -1,10 +1,9 @@
-import { openUrl } from './rangeFetcher'
-import LocalFile from './localFile'
+import { LocalFile, RemoteFile } from 'generic-filehandle'
 
 // eslint-disable-next-line import/prefer-default-export
 export function openLocation(location) {
   if (!location) throw new Error(`must provide a location to openLocation`)
-  if (location.uri) return openUrl(location.uri)
+  if (location.uri) return new RemoteFile(location.uri)
   if (location.localPath) {
     return new LocalFile(location.localPath)
   }
```
which is pretty cool. We'll want to not use RemoteFile for now, though, until we can integrate it with `http-range-fetcher`.

Need to add BlobFile to `generic-filehandle` first (see https://github.com/cmdcolin/generic-filehandle/issues/1).

title: Update dependencies to enable Greenkeeper 🌴
body:
Let’s get started with automated dependency management for jbrowse-components :muscle:

🔒 Greenkeeper has found a `yarn.lock` file in this repository. Greenkeeper supports lockfile updates for public packages. If you use private packages in your repository, please use [greenkeeper-lockfile](https://github.com/greenkeeperio/greenkeeper-lockfile) to make sure these can get updated as well.

This pull request **updates all your dependencies to their latest version**. Having them all up to date really is the best starting point for keeping up with new releases. Greenkeeper will look out for further dependency updates and make sure to handle them in isolation and in real-time, but only after **you merge this pull request**.

**Important: Greenkeeper will only start watching this repository’s dependency updates after you merge this initial pull request**.



📦 📦  Greenkeeper has detected multiple `package.json` files. Since this repo already has a `greenkeeper.json` config file with defined groups, Greenkeeper has only checked whether they’re still valid. 

---
<details>
<summary>💥 Tests on this branch are failing. Here’s how to proceed.</summary>

To solve the issue, first find out which of the dependency’s updates is causing the problem. Then fix your code to accomodate the changes in the updated dependency. [next-update](https://www.npmjs.com/package/next-update) is a really handy tool to help you with this.

Then push your changes to this branch and merge it.
</details>
<details>
<summary>🏷 How to check the status of this repository</summary>

Greenkeeper adds a badge to your README which indicates the status of this repository.

This is what your badge looks like right now :point_right:  ![Greenkeeper badge](https://badges.greenkeeper.io/GMOD/jbrowse-components.svg)
</details>
<details>
<summary>🏗 How to configure Travis CI</summary>

Greenkeeper has added a rule to your `.travis.yml` that whitelists Greenkeeper branches, which are created when your dependencies are updated. Travis CI will run your tests on these branches automatically to see if they still pass.

No additional setup is required 😊

</details>
<details>
<summary>🙈 How to ignore certain dependencies</summary>

You may have good reasons for not wanting to update to a certain dependency right now. In this case, you can [change the dependency’s version string in the `package.json` file back to whatever you prefer](https://github.com/GMOD/jbrowse-components/edit/greenkeeper/initial/package.json).

To make sure Greenkeeper doesn’t nag you again on the next update, add a `greenkeeper.ignore` field to your `package.json`, containing a list of dependencies you don’t want to update.

```js
// package.json
{
  …
  "greenkeeper": {
    "ignore": [
      "package-names",
      "you-want-me-to-ignore"
    ]
  }
}
```
</details>
<details>
<summary>👩‍💻 How to update this pull request</summary>

```bash
  # Change into your repository’s directory
  git fetch --all
  git checkout greenkeeper/initial
  npm install-test
  # Adapt your code until everything works again
  git commit -m 'chore: adapt code to updated dependencies'
  git push https://github.com/GMOD/jbrowse-components.git greenkeeper/initial
```
</details>
<details>
<summary>✨ How do dependency updates work with Greenkeeper?</summary>

After you merge this pull request, **Greenkeeper will create a new branch whenever a  dependency is updated**, with the new version applied. The branch creation should trigger your testing services and check whether your code still works with the new dependency version. Depending on the the results of these tests Greenkeeper will try to open meaningful and helpful pull requests and issues, so your dependencies remain working and up-to-date.

```diff
-  "underscore": "^1.6.0"
+  "underscore": "^1.7.0"
```

The above example shows an in-range update. `1.7.0` is included in the old `^1.6.0` range, because of the [caret `^` character ](https://docs.npmjs.com/misc/semver#ranges).
When the test services report success Greenkeeper will silently delete the branch again, because no action needs to be taken – everything is fine.

However, should the tests fail, Greenkeeper will create an issue to inform you about the problem immediately.

This way, you’ll never be surprised by a dependency breaking your code. As long as everything still works, Greenkeeper will stay out of your way, and as soon as something goes wrong, you’ll be the first to know.

```diff
-  "lodash": "^3.0.0"
+  "lodash": "^4.0.0"
```

In this example, the new version `4.0.0` is _not_ included in the old `^3.0.0` range.
For version updates like these – let’s call them “out of range” updates – you’ll receive a pull request.

This means that **you no longer need to check for new versions manually** – Greenkeeper will keep you up to date automatically.

These pull requests not only serve as reminders to update: If you have solid tests and good coverage, and the pull requests passes those tests, you can very likely just merge it and release a new version of your software straight away :shipit:

To get a better idea of which ranges apply to which releases, check out the extremely useful [semver calculator](https://semver.npmjs.com/) provided by npm.
</details>
<details>
<summary>FAQ and help</summary>

There is a collection of [frequently asked questions](https://greenkeeper.io/faq.html). If those don’t help, you can always [ask the humans behind Greenkeeper](https://github.com/greenkeeperio/greenkeeper/issues/new).
</details>


---

Good luck with your project and see you soon :sparkles:

To enable Greenkeeper, you need to make sure that a [commit status](https://help.github.com/articles/about-statuses/) is reported on all branches. This is required by Greenkeeper because it uses your CI build statuses to figure out when to notify you about breaking changes.

Since we didn’t receive a CI status on the [`greenkeeper/initial`](https://github.com/GMOD/jbrowse-components/commits/greenkeeper/initial) branch, it’s possible that you don’t have CI set up yet. We recommend using [Travis CI](https://travis-ci.org), but Greenkeeper will work with every other CI service as well.

If you _have_ already set up a CI for this repository, you might need to check how it’s configured. Make sure it is set to run on all new branches. If you don’t want it to run on absolutely every branch, you can whitelist branches starting with `greenkeeper/`.

Once you have installed and configured CI on this repository correctly, you’ll need to re-trigger Greenkeeper’s initial pull request. To do this, please click the 'fix repo' button on [account.greenkeeper.io](https://account.greenkeeper.io).

title: clustal data adapter
body:
Takes a clustal-format multiple sequence alignment, produces features with MD and CIGAR tags.

Say you have a multiple alignment with sequences A, B, and C.

* `getFeatures({ refName: 'A', start, end})` will produce 2 features, one for B and one for 
C.
* `getFeatures({ refName: 'B', start, end})` will produce 2 features, one for A and one for C.
* `getFeatures({ refName: 'C', start, end})` will produce 2 features, one for A and one for B.


`getRefNames` will list all of the sequence in the alignment, because any one of them can be a reference.

Can also act as a reference sequence store.

title: gapped sequence alignment track
body:
like here's a clustalw output:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/73749/55250329-2fb4b280-520b-11e9-81d9-c8783d327fc7.png)

title: render cancellation
body:
Adds AbortController-based cancellation to much of the rendering machinery. Passes AbortSignals to data backends, which can pay attention to them if they want.

resolves #155

title: pileup performance: make pileup rendering not send layout to main thread
body:
When navigating around deep-coverage alignments, the pileup rendering is shipping the feature layout to the main thread, and it is taking a really long time to serialize and deserialize.

Can't really avoid this with the svg+react renderers, because they need to hydrate all the elements on the frontend, but I think we should be able to avoid this just for the canvas-based pileup renderer if we provide some kind of RPC mechanism for being able to fetch a feature from a canvas pixel location.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/73749/54965091-49fd4080-4f2c-11e9-84b4-4106fd3d2005.png)

title: track-close button
body: Need a little 'X' button to hide a track in the LGV.

title: dev env source mapping does not work

There are a number of issues with current jbrowse-web webpack setup that are really impacting our productivity:

* source mapping does not work, we can't set breakpoints in the chrome debugger, we have to use debug statements

I suspect some webpack/babel configuration work can smooth over a lot of this.

title: split plugins out into their own packages
body:
Take most of the plugins out of jbrowse-web and put them in packages/, with their own npm publishing machinery.

Lerna is the thing to use for this.  Everything just needs to have a package.json, and that should be all.

Lerna can set up all the publishing stuff.

title: runtime exports for plugins
body:
Add the concept of "runtime exports" of dependencies to plugins/components.

Port most of the plugins/components to get their inter-plugin deps from the plugin/component manager's runtime exports facilities.

title: config layers
body:
Make a new thing called a "ConfigLayer" that can be treated just like an instance of a config schema, but only stores "overrides" that differ from its base config.

It does not have its own schema, it is a layer over a base schema.

When getting a value, it gets the value from itself if it is set, or it gets the value from the parent.
When a value gets set, it stores the value in itself, but does not modify the parent.

Layers can override whole subschemas as well.

title: Track selector doesn't update correctly when switching configs
body:
To reproduce in current master (ef361134808a6f8e74af1470e865fb75fcf1d23f):
- Refresh page
- Switch to "Human Example"
- Open track selector
- Switch back to "Volvox Example." The track selector will have the wrong tracks in it.

Tried making the drawer components regular components instead of lazy components and that didn't fix it. Maybe has to do with component keys in an array somewhere?

title: Connect to a remote UCSC hub
body:
This adds the ability to "connect" to remote UCSC track hubs. When the config is loaded or a connection is added, the connections (stored in "connections" in the root config) are retrieved and the tracks/assemblies added to a root config entry called "volatile," which is excluded from export when using the "Download configuration" button. (Too confusing with MST volatile state? Couldn't decide on a good name.)

There's a new config in the config switcher that demonstrates this with a connection to a little volvox hub I set up.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/54708880-b76b3480-4b1a-11e9-8e30-d94f302aacea.png)

I had to change several things in the track selector and data hub manager drawer widgets, and converting them to use react hooks actually made those changes easier, so I did that as well. Testing with hooks is still a bit tricky, though, since React is [still working on some updates](https://github.com/facebook/react/issues/14769#issuecomment-474656273) to make testing hooks with async actions work. This means that the tests for the data hub manager are a bit unfinished, as I couldn't get them to work (I think they will after react releases their updates).

That being said, I found a couple blog posts on testing React ([here](https://kentcdodds.com/blog/testing-implementation-details) and [here](https://kentcdodds.com/blog/react-hooks-whats-going-to-happen-to-my-tests)) that made me realize my prior Enzyme tests were testing implementation details and not the actual function of my components. The author of those posts has a library called [react-testing-library](https://testing-library.com/react) that helps write tests that don't test implementation details, which I try out here (but which still don't quite work because of the above-mentioned React problems).

resolves #139
Still need to implement copying remote tracks to local config (#140) and track config overrides (#141)

title: required and optional config slots
body:
Add support for config slots that are required, and ones that are optional.

Initial ideas for this:

config slots that are required just don't have a defaultValue, and getConf will throw if a read is attempted from them and they are unset.

config slots that are optional will return `undefined` from a getConf, and the graphical config editor will need to have "+" and "-" or "add" and "delete" buttons or similar controls to change the slot between set and unset.

title: make a pluggable ActionManager and actions
body:
When you click on a thing somewhere in the UI, the actionManager will be able to tell you what actions are available to run on it.

For example, when you right-click a feature in a track, the track can ask the actionManager what actions are available for that feature, and then use that to populate a context menu of actions for that feature.

Tracks might want a defaultAction configuration slot as well. 

Plugins should be able to add new actions and override the built-in actions for certain things as well.

We probably want an Action have a lot of similarity to the browser Event objects, but containing information that's relevant to JBrowse code, like what view it came from, what data is attached to it (e.g. "the user just searched for the string HER2"), and so forth.

title: make lineargenomeview assembly tieing optional
body: Add a `tieToAssembly` action to the LinearGenomeView MST model, and make setting displayed regions untie it from the assembly, if it is tied.

title: Whitespace on sequence track
body:
If you use MODEL.views[0].setNewView(0.871504157218443,21631.56634865568) on volvox sample data you'll see there is a little whitespace on the sequence track


![](https://files.gitter.im/GMOD/jbrowse2/hpYP/image.png)

Just wanted to make sure this didn't get lost, will probably get involved in a sequence track re-design that includes translation frames

title: Fix event listeners in chrome
body:
Event listeners are passive by default and now this is giving some  console errors https://github.com/facebook/react/issues/6436

Probably need to manually setup event listeners instead of using onWheel

title: Reference sequence subtracks
body: Right now there is a reference sequence track for every assembly that defines a sequence. Would probably make sense for these to be subtracks of a single parent reference sequence track.

title: Make a ViewManager
body: Right now, in the interest of getting code merged, `displayedRegions` in the view is tied to all regions defined by the `AssemblyManager`. Need something in between the view model and the assembly manager (a RegionManager?) that can keep track of what regions the view is displaying, where they came from (assembly, config, regions file, user interaction, etc.), and switch among them.

title: Multi wiggle template
body:
This PR adds

- Track type for multibigwig
- Local/global autoscaling that works across multiple files

title: Update build scripts to support react-dev-utils >= 8.0.0
body:
Right now react-dev-utils is set to <8.0.0 because of a breaking change in one of the functions `start.js` uses. We probably want to include this if we are going to start using typescript because it includes a bunch of speedups for typescript compilation in the dev build.

This package is part of create-react-app. The easiest way to do this might be to create a test app with create-react-app, eject it, and see how `start.js` has changed between when we ejected and now.

title: Pin mst
body:
If we don't pin this, we'll keep getting false positive build breaking messages from greenkeeper (like #191). Issue to track un-pinning is #193.

resolves #187
resolves #191

title: Update to MST 3.14
body: Currently some of our things break when MST 3.11.0 is used. For example, the `defaultValue` attribute was made private in this update (it's now `_defaultValue`).

title: Be able to define adapter capabilities
body:
Need to know if an adapter can i.e. fetch sequences, features, aliases, etc.

Probably just a static array on the adapter class that defines a list of these (keep a master list somewhere?)

Release Notes for v0.2.2

0.2.2 (August 22, 2016)

Build Dependency (react-scripts)

  • When the bundle size changes, we now display the difference after build. (@elijahmanor in #340)
  • npm installing a missing dependency now forces a rebuild. (@gaearon in #349)
  • Autoprefixer config now includes more commonly supported browsers. (@kripod in #345)
  • All the configuration is now documented inline so ejecting doesn’t leave you in the dark. (@gaearon in #362)
  • Object.assign() polyfill is now bundled by default. (@gaearon in #399)
  • React Native Web now works out of the box. (@grigio in #407)
  • Same asset filenames in different folders don’t confuse the server now. (@arunoda in #446)
  • The otf font format is now supported. (@A-gambit in #434)
  • The new-cap linting rule has been disabled thanks to feedback from Immutable.js users. (@rricard in #470)

Migrating from 0.2.1 to 0.2.2

Update react-scripts to point to 0.2.2 in your package.json and run npm install. You shouldn’t need to do anything else.

Newly created projects will use 0.2.2 automatically. You don’t need to update the global create-react-app CLI itself. It stays at 0.2.0 for now because it doesn’t have any changes.

title: write a high-level integration test without selenium
body:
In jest, start a JBrowse app running on test data, scroll around, and inspect the DOM (maybe using `toMatchSnapshot` on certain parts of it?) to make sure the right things are rendered.

Basically the intention is to test the whole app kind of like the JBrowse 1 selenium tests do.

JBrowse will need to be configured to use main-thread rendering, see https://github.com/GMOD/jbrowse-components/blob/master/packages/protein-widget/src/Viewer.js#L68 for an example of what that configuration looks like.

because of MainThreadRendering, this depends on #287

title: floating labels for SvgFeatureRenderer
body: svgfeaturerenderer labels were added in #159, but now we need to make them "float" like they do in JBrowse 1.

title: standardize on `renderer` for track config schemas
body: Right now we have some track types using the config "renderer" (like FilteringTrack), some using "renderers" (like AlignmentTrack), and some using "rendering" (SequenceTrack). Should we just standardize on "renderers" and use a config like the one AlignmentTrack uses for maximum consistency and flexibility?

title: Add more dependency management info to README
body: resolves #169

title: Configuration and Sessions
body:
Converts JBrowse to a React component and enables switching among multiple configs (each with a defaultSession) defined either in a file or as an object.

Adds the ability to define a reference sequence source (2bit, fasta, or sizes as an object) to an assembly, and views using that assembly will automatically use that for their displayed regions.

resolves #102
resolves #136
resolves #145
resolves #192

title: Draw labels on protein lollipops
body:
Would be good to draw meaningful labels on lollipops, that's basically all my original request boils down to :)

In some cases I suppose it may not be possible to draw inside tiny lollipop bubbles so it could necessitate a different layout for labels?

title: Update and pin react-simple-code-editor
body: Updating this to the latest version and pinning to that version for the same reason `material-ui` is pinned: minor or patch version updates may break snapshots.

title: Clarify deps and devDeps
body:
Here's the best TL;DR I could think of:
- All `dependencies` go in `<root>/packages/<package>/package.json`
- All `devDependencies` go in `<root>/package.json`

Or saying it a different way:
- `<root>/package.json` should only list devDependencies and no dependencies
- `<root>/packages/<package>/package.json` should only list dependencies and no devDependencies

Adding a bit more information:
- `dependencies` are any NPM package `import`ed or `require`d in a package's `src/` directory _except for any `*test.js` files, which follow the next rule_
- `devDependencies` are any NPM package `import`ed or `require`d in any other files and not already in `dependencies`

To add NPM packages:
- `dependencies`: from root directory run `cd packages/<package> && yarn add <npm_package_name>`
- `devDependencies`: from root directory run `yarn add --dev -W <npm_package_name>`

I'd like to disallow running `yarn add --dev` in any individual package's directory, but I can't find any yarn hooks or anything that would facilitate that. Plus that doesn't cover hand-editing the package.json. Maybe a git hook that tests for the presence of `devDependencies` in `package.json`, or is that overkill?

@rbuels I'll add this to the README, but what parts do you think need clarification/fixing?

title: lollipop rendering, dynamicBlocks
body:
Adds a LollipopRenderer, which is designed for only non-block-based display. Solidifies support for non-block-based displays by changing LinearGenomeView to have `staticBlocks` and `dynamicBlocks`, which have different updating strategies to support different kinds of displays.

resolves #137 
resolves #160

title: syntax errors in config slot callbacks crash the app
body:
To reproduce:

* open a track configuration
* make one of the slots a configuration callback, and introduce a syntax error
* it will crash the app

It should not crash the app, but should show as a validation error.

title: drawer resize handle is tied to drawer content scroll
body:
To reproduce:

* open a track configuration editor in the drawer
* scroll its content all the way to the bottom
* you now cannot resize the drawer, because the resize handle has scrolled out of view

title: Add parsers to monorepo (or another monorepo)?
body:
After having to address an issue in some of our parsers, I feel like moving the parsers to this (or another) monorepo might be a good idea. Here are some advantages I see:
- Easier to keep track of: You can just clone one repo and get all the packages. Also, if you have a fix for the packages, it's less easy to accidentally forget one.
- Better dependency management: Everything uses the same version of babel, jest, eslint, etc., as well as using the same rules (everything would share the same eslint config, babel config, etc.)  Also much more DRY.
- Better release management: lerna provides a consistent way to release all packages.

Some cons:

- Could be confusing at first: would need to make sure the README in the root was descriptive or had good links to the READMEs in the individual packages
- Issues would all be in a single github repo instead of individual repos (could also be a pro)

Just to clarify, I don't foresee changing anything on the NPM side, so all of the packages would be exactly the same if you were installing them from NPM

Also, having parsers grouped into the jbrowse-components repo or their own repo (maybe a `gmod-utils` repo?) have different advantages. If they were in the jbrowse-components repo, you could modify a parser and your local version of jbrowse2 would automatically pull in those changes, so testing would be easy. I think I'm leaning toward creating a separate monorepo for them, though, since they are logically tied together, but not necessarily to jbrowse2, and they already almost all share a very similar architecture, so it would be a very clean monorepo. And in 15 years when jbrowse3 is rewritten again as a virtual reality genome browser :smirk:, we won't have to pull the parsers out of the jbrowse2 monorepo.

title: add domains track to protein-widget
add labels and descriptions to SvgFeaturerRenderer
protein data demo web service
body:
Little express.js-based web service that we will use to demo the protein viewer, that just takes a single human protein name as input (e.g. KRAS), picks the canonical isoform (if there are isoforms), and returns:

* the aa sequence
* the translated DNA sequence (with UTRs and introns removed)
* protein domains in AA coordinate space
* variants some someplace (COSMIC) that has some variant info, and the *number of samples*

title: grid-bookmark widget
body:
Allow keeping a list of regions aka bookmarks

These are basically simple features (e.g. a region with start and end)

title: add simple "max-zoom-level" to BasicTrack and DynamicTrack
body:
Right now when the sequence track is still fetching features even when it's zoomed out far enough to display the "Zoom in to see sequence" message. Need to not do that fetching when zoomed out.

First thought: add to base track

Easiest way to reproduce: open the human example and zoom way out and watch the crazy network traffic

title: render request cancellation
body:
the UI needs to cancel render requests that are no longer relevant, like if the user is scrolling really fast and it scrolls past the relevant static block before its render finishes.

useful resources about this:

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Fetch_API#Aborting_a_fetch
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/AbortController
https://www.npmjs.com/package/abortcontroller-polyfill

MST has a pull to add cancel to flows https://github.com/mobxjs/mobx-state-tree/pull/691, but may not be directly relevant since we don't use the MST flows, at least so far

title: protein-widget package updates
body:
@rbuels this does a couple things:
- loads the local material icons font so it doesn't have to be `link`ed in the html
  - updates the weback config to handle this
- removes unused dependencies and moves devDependencies to the root package.json (that's where all devDependecies are for our packages)

title: embeddable protein widget
body:
makes a protein-widget embeddable app that is packaged with UMD, adds a ProteinReferenceSequence renderer that's optimized to show protein seqs, and more stuff.

also refactors all the RPC plumbing to add a driver system, and now we have the ability to render in the main thread, which is good for embedded scenarios like this one

also changes the way the width of the lineargenomeview is updated.  the app root model directly sets the width of the view, instead of the view watching root.viewsWidth.  this provides more flexibility for how views can be embedded.

resolves #138

title: load a configuration JSON from the top menu bar
Rubber band
body:
Draft pull request for rubber band functionality

Aiming to move some of the functions from Rubberband.js into util library and maybe add refinement to avoid excessive zoom ins?

Also need to consider using rubber band behavior to induce highlight, popup context menu, etc

title: WIP sessions and configuration import
body:
This makes it so you can load the initial configuration with either a config object or a file location of a config JSON. If the object passed to `JBrowse.configure()` has a key `uri` or `localPath`, it assumes that it should use a config file, otherwise it assumes the object is a config object. i.e. both
```js
JBrowse().configure({
tracks: [
      {
        type: 'SequenceTrack',
        name: 'Reference sequence',
        ...
  })
```
and
```js
JBrowse().configure({ uri: 'test_data/config.json' })
```
will work.

I had to make JBrowse.configure() async to do this, so if there's a better way of making that change let me know.



And this also adds stuff for saving and restoring default sessions.  TODO expand this


resolves #102 
resolves #145

title: create navigateToLocation type convenience method
body: calculate offsetPx, bpPerPx given some displayed region

title: Initial config import
body:
This makes it so you can load the initial configuration with either a config object or a file location of a config JSON. If the object passed to `JBrowse.configure()` has a key `uri` or `localPath`, it assumes that it should use a config file, otherwise it assumes the object is a config object. i.e. both
```js
JBrowse().configure({
tracks: [
      {
        type: 'SequenceTrack',
        name: 'Reference sequence',
        ...
  })
```
and
```js
JBrowse().configure({ uri: 'test_data/config.json' })
```
will work.

I had to make JBrowse.configure() async to do this, so if there's a better way of making that change let me know.

resolves #102

title: save and load sessions
body: We need to be able to name sessions and save them in localstorage, and we need a UI for doing CRUD on saved sessions.

title: sessions and defaultSession
body:
We need the concept of a session, which is a partial state snapshot that doesn't include configuration, but includes the views and stuff that are open at a given time.

The root configuration should also have a non-editable `defaultSession` that has this state snapshot, which is what is initially loaded when the browser is shown, if there is not some other active session.

We will probably eventually be persisting sessions in localstorage, but that isn't in scope for this issue.

title: 138 embeddable app
body:
* removes support for decorators
* refactors some other things to improve bundling and embeddability

title: Add track drawerwidget
body:
This adds a UI to add a new track from scratch. You can add from a file or from a config. If you add from a file, it uses the filename to guess an adapter configuration.

resolves #114

title: add track vertical wheel scrolling
body: Put the mouse pointer inside a track block, and scroll vertically. The track should scroll up and down if there is room, or if it is scrolled all the way the work area should scroll up and down.

title: track overrides
body:
From meeting 2/8/19

Track overrides can be applied and persisted. A user edited configuration for a track can be saved in localstorage. On refresh, a track override is applied and gets a indicator such as a red icon. That override can be "thrown away" or reverted with a trash icon or similar

JBrowse admins can hardcode track overrides in the config that applies to tracks loaded from a track hub remotely. The user edited track overrides can be applied over the admins track overrides

We discussed how possibly we need to have "read only" tracks that need cloning to create user edits, but after discussion this seemed to be not a strict requirement.

Bad mspaint mockup 
<details>
![untitled](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6511937/52503523-c671d500-2bb3-11e9-9de8-43b2bedf06f6.png)
</details>

Some related issues include config import, and data hubs, because remote directory includes are treated as data hubs.

title: track cloning
body: Need a way to "clone" a track

title: support "connection" to a hub
body:
When you are connected to a hub, its tracks and assemblies show up in your UI.

The "connections" are part of the main configuration, but the actual track and assembly configurations are not.

You can clone the track (#140), or you can edit its settings to override the hub settings (see #141)

title: single-view embeddable app
body:
Make a function, built into a UMD package, that instantiates a single LinearGenomeView on the page based on a plain javascript object that is passed to it as configuration.

Proximate use case is an embeddable protein viewer.

title: lollipop rendering
body:
Make a 'lollipop' non-block-based rendering type that renders lollipops with numbers in them, with variable size and color, and lays the heads and labels out independently of their actual coordinate position.

Kind of like the ProteinPaint lollipops.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/73749/52499535-82210d80-2b90-11e9-8cec-3963306c3a53.png)

title: changing the config of one track makes other tracks rerender
body: to reproduce: at startup with our current default configurations, open the config editor for the reference sequence track and change rendering.height.  You will see the wiggle and alignments tracks re-render, but they should not.

title: reference sequence detail
body: clicking on a reference sequence name should bring up a detail with what we know about that ref sequence.  its length, aliases, what assembly it's from, what type of sequence it is (protein, coding, genomic), etc

title: add translation to SequenceRenderer
body:
Support just 6-frame for genetic sequence.

There is now ProteinReferenceSequenceRenderer for protein reference sequences.

this is a refinement of #87

title: Fix greenkeeper
body:
I think this should make greenkeeper actually work, even though it still messes up the yarn.lock files. I pinned the material-ui packages (which I think is the right thing to do since a lot of things change when they update) and one other package that was actually breaking the build when it updated (jest-pnp-resolver). If we upgrade to Jest 24 we can probably un-pin that last one.

resolves #91, resolves #119, resolves #122, resolves #123, resolves #124, resolves #125, resolves #129, resolves #130, resolves #131

title: Compact tracklist
body:
This makes the tracklist more compact. Subclassing material ui is a non trivial task but hopefully something that doesn't need doing all the time

Let me know if there is any feedback

title: protein viewing improvements
body:
Adds a FromConfig adapter, feature filtering to the base adapter, and a FilteringTrack track type that has a configurable UI for filtering the features via checkboxes.

resolves #87

title: Drawer update
body:
Drawer now has a "stack" that allows one of each type of drawer widget. When you close a widget, if there are others in the stack they appear. If there are none the drawer hides completely.

Drawer widget resizing is now smoother.

Keeping track of the app width is now done with react-sizeme instead of calling `window.innerWidth`

Also added a very simple alignments feature drawer widget to help illustrate the stack.

resolves #98

title: Side scrolling performance improvements on chrome
body:
Side scrolling on chrome is generally quite fast, however if you quickly side scroll then there are blank white blocks for awhile until it is able to re-render. The sequence track is slightly better than the other tracks in load time, but I think all tracks should be a bit more performant.  I have not done profiling to see what the issue is, so I am not sure the key area to target

See  attached video
[screencast-localhost-3000-2019.02.01-18-12-04.zip](https://github.com/GMOD/jbrowse-components/files/2823654/screencast-localhost-3000-2019.02.01-18-12-04.zip)

This is of course nitpicky but I think it could look smoother and would look really good if data was already loaded as you were scrolling

Note that scrolling back over areas you have already seen have this issue too so it's not necessarily like a "first time the data is loading" thing...should be in a cache already.

title: Side scrolling slow on firefox

title: first-run/initial configuration wizard
body:
I think we need some sort of UI that guides the user in what to do if JBrowse is started with no configuration. I'm thinking it would give them a few options:
- Define a reference sequence (entering chromosomes and sizes manually or adding a .sizes, .fasta, .2bit, etc. file) (xref #103)
- Upload a config file (probably one exported from JBrowse previously) (xref #102)
- Attach to a remote source (a config file hosted somewhere, a track hub, etc.)

title: UI to add references/assemblies
body: We need a UI for adding or defining a reference sequence or an assembly. We'll probably need to add information such as the type of reference used (fasta, twobit, etc.) to the "assemblies" portion of the root config.

title: Initial configuration import
body: Now that we can export configurations (#62), we should be able to import them as well.

title: Regularize assembly and sequence names
body:
This moves a lot of the data adapter functionality to a shared BaseAdapter class so that name regularization can all happen in a single place. Individual adapters will only have to provide an array of reference sequences names they use, and everything else will be handled by the base class. Each individual adapter should implement:

- `loadData` this is where any metadata loading, etc. should happen and should return a promise for an array of reference sequence names
- `getFeaturesInRegion` returns a promise for an Observable, same as before. Does not need to do anything with assemblyName, as that is handled in the base class
- `freeResources` not used in any of our adapters yet

I've updated the BamAdapter and TwoBitAdapter to use this model, so you can look at those for an example.

Resolves #51

title: Rearrange styling elements a bit
body:
@cmdcolin I like this way of positioning the zoom controls a lot better. I've got a couple mostly code-style-related suggestions, but didn't want to commit directly to your PR. In keeping with [this advice](https://material-ui.com/getting-started/faq/#when-should-i-use-inline-style-vs-classes), I've been trying to use the inline `style` prop only for dynamic style properties and use `classNames` with a styles class for other things. This particular file is a bit of an exception since I've left the `grid`-related stuff (event the static stuff) all in the `style` props just to keep it all together and easier to read, but I've still tried to keep everything else using the JSS styles with `classNames`.

I also added just a little bit of padding to the right of the zoom controls since it was causing a bit of horizontal overflow in my browser.

body:
Currently there is a lot of whitespace in the track selector.

JBrowse 1 volvox sample data on my screen shows ~30 tracks at once without any scrolling and has nested categories
JBrowse 2 currently displays 4 tracks if you include having some nested categories

I would say material ui override or something here :)
