title: An in-range update of material-ui is breaking the build 🚨
body:
## There have been updates to the *material-ui* monorepo: + - The `dependency` [@material-ui/core](https://github.com/mui-org/material-ui) was updated from `3.9.0` to `3.9.1`. - The `dependency` [@material-ui/lab](https://github.com/mui-org/material-ui) was updated from `3.0.0-alpha.28` to `3.0.0-alpha.29`. 🚨 [View failing branch](https://github.com/GMOD/jbrowse-components/compare/master...GMOD:greenkeeper%2Fdefault%2Fmonorepo.material-ui-20190126140954). This version is **covered** by your **current version range** and after updating it in your project **the build failed**. This monorepo update includes releases of one or more dependencies which all belong to the [material-ui group definition](https://github.com/greenkeeperio/monorepo-definitions). material-ui is a direct dependency of this project, and **it is very likely causing it to break**. If other packages depend on yours, this update is probably also breaking those in turn.
Status Details - ❌ **Travis CI - Branch:** The build **failed**.

title: Reverse complement
body:
adds a `reverse` config variable to linear genome views and makes the svg and pileup renderers support it.

the linear view configs are also not singletons anymore, because i realized we don't want to reverse all of them at the same time.

resolves #58

title: multi-region feature layout engine
body:
GranularRectLayout is not great. It uses quite a bit of memory, you have to worry a lot about having the right `pitchX` and `pitchY`.

I think a layout engine based on binning, R trees, or similar, which places a feature by just narrowing the search space and then brute-force searching within that would probably be faster and easier to manage.

title: Update dependencies to enable Greenkeeper 🌴
body:
Let’s get started with automated dependency management for jbrowse-components :muscle:

🔒 Greenkeeper has found a `yarn.lock` file in this repository. Greenkeeper supports lockfile updates for public packages. If you use private packages in your repository, please use [greenkeeper-lockfile](https://github.com/greenkeeperio/greenkeeper-lockfile) to make sure these can get updated as well.

This pull request **updates all your dependencies to their latest version**. Having them all up to date really is the best starting point for keeping up with new releases. Greenkeeper will look out for further dependency updates and make sure to handle them in isolation and in real-time, but only after **you merge this pull request**.

**Important: Greenkeeper will only start watching this repository’s dependency updates after you merge this initial pull request**.



📦 📦  Greenkeeper has detected multiple `package.json` files. They have all been added to a new `greenkeeper.json` config file. They’ve been collected in a group called `default`, meaning that all of them will receive updates together. You can rename, add and remove groups and freely assign each `package.json` to whichever group you like. It’s common, for example, to have one `frontend` group and one `backend` group, each with a couple of `package.json` files. In any case, all files in a group will have their updates collected into single PRs and issues. 

---
<details>
<summary>💥 Tests on this branch are failing. Here’s how to proceed.</summary>

To solve the issue, first find out which of the dependency’s updates is causing the problem. Then fix your code to accomodate the changes in the updated dependency. [next-update](https://www.npmjs.com/package/next-update) is a really handy tool to help you with this.

Then push your changes to this branch and merge it.
</details>
<details>
<summary>🏷 How to check the status of this repository</summary>

Greenkeeper adds a badge to your README which indicates the status of this repository.

This is what your badge looks like right now :point_right:  ![Greenkeeper badge](https://badges.greenkeeper.io/GMOD/jbrowse-components.svg)
</details>
<details>
<summary>🙈 How to ignore certain dependencies</summary>

You may have good reasons for not wanting to update to a certain dependency right now. In this case, you can [change the dependency’s version string in the `package.json` file back to whatever you prefer](https://github.com/GMOD/jbrowse-components/edit/greenkeeper/initial/package.json).

To make sure Greenkeeper doesn’t nag you again on the next update, add a `greenkeeper.ignore` field to your `package.json`, containing a list of dependencies you don’t want to update.

```js
// package.json
{
  …
  "greenkeeper": {
    "ignore": [
      "package-names",
      "you-want-me-to-ignore"
    ]
  }
}
```
</details>
<details>
<summary>👩‍💻 How to update this pull request</summary>

```bash
  # Change into your repository’s directory
  git fetch --all
  git checkout greenkeeper/initial
  npm install-test
  # Adapt your code until everything works again
  git commit -m 'chore: adapt code to updated dependencies'
  git push https://github.com/GMOD/jbrowse-components.git greenkeeper/initial
```
</details>
<details>
<summary>✨ How do dependency updates work with Greenkeeper?</summary>

After you merge this pull request, **Greenkeeper will create a new branch whenever a  dependency is updated**, with the new version applied. The branch creation should trigger your testing services and check whether your code still works with the new dependency version. Depending on the the results of these tests Greenkeeper will try to open meaningful and helpful pull requests and issues, so your dependencies remain working and up-to-date.

```diff
-  "underscore": "^1.6.0"
+  "underscore": "^1.7.0"
```

The above example shows an in-range update. `1.7.0` is included in the old `^1.6.0` range, because of the [caret `^` character ](https://docs.npmjs.com/misc/semver#ranges).
When the test services report success Greenkeeper will silently delete the branch again, because no action needs to be taken – everything is fine.

However, should the tests fail, Greenkeeper will create an issue to inform you about the problem immediately.

This way, you’ll never be surprised by a dependency breaking your code. As long as everything still works, Greenkeeper will stay out of your way, and as soon as something goes wrong, you’ll be the first to know.

```diff
-  "lodash": "^3.0.0"
+  "lodash": "^4.0.0"
```

In this example, the new version `4.0.0` is _not_ included in the old `^3.0.0` range.
For version updates like these – let’s call them “out of range” updates – you’ll receive a pull request.

This means that **you no longer need to check for new versions manually** – Greenkeeper will keep you up to date automatically.

These pull requests not only serve as reminders to update: If you have solid tests and good coverage, and the pull requests passes those tests, you can very likely just merge it and release a new version of your software straight away :shipit:

To get a better idea of which ranges apply to which releases, check out the extremely useful [semver calculator](https://semver.npmjs.com/) provided by npm.
</details>
<details>
<summary>FAQ and help</summary>

There is a collection of [frequently asked questions](https://greenkeeper.io/faq.html). If those don’t help, you can always [ask the humans behind Greenkeeper](https://github.com/greenkeeperio/greenkeeper/issues/new).
</details>


---

Good luck with your project and see you soon :sparkles:

title: Create search bar/search drawer
body:
The searching in a mockup we had was placed in the menu bar, which would be quite compact and not interfere with other UI areas

A search drawer that is more multi-featured might also help and in a multi species scenario it might specifically ask you which assembly you want to search or something similar

title: circular view
body: We want to create circos views of data that can include multiple genomes (synteny between genomes, sometimes this is even more than two), whole genomes (e.g. circular manhattan), and multiple tracks

title: Add snap-to-certain-values zooming
body:
JBrowse 1 has certain specified zoom levels e.g. bpPerPx snapped to 25,10,5,1,0.1,0.001,etc and it seems to be fairly expressive and reliable and doesn't need arbitrary zoom levels

Could help with the idea of rounding bpPerBlock being a whole number

title: Add rubberband zooming
body:
Add rubber band zooming where you drag mouse over the scale bar in order to elicit zoom

Has also been recommended to tie this to other actions like sequence download and stuff like this which might be a useful option and/or mode for rubber band

title: Sequence track
body:
This adds a bare bones sequence track that copies the BamAdapter, Boxrenderer, and AlignmentTrack as sort of a template



Possible confusing things include

```
    for (const seq of features.values()) {
      s += seq.seq || seq.data.seq // index.js:1452 Warning: Text content did not match. fix?
    }
```

Without this I would get something about differences between server and client rendering

Also after the latest merge from master I am getting this error when doing zoom out too far:

```
Error: [mobx-state-tree][error] You are trying to read or write to an object that is no longer part of a state tree. (Object type was 'Region'). Either detach nodes first, or don't use objects after removing / replacing them in the tree.
```

Anyways I was happy to get this far and add a simple track type! feel free to add review. I may be some vestigial things in the copying/pasting of alignmentstrack,boxrenderer,bamadapter in the new sequencetrack,divsequencerenderer,twobitadapter

![screenshot-localhost-3000-2019 01 18-12-16-17](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6511937/51402233-ecf3a180-1b1a-11e9-9517-7870b8db1a96.png)

title: 0 or 1 based coordinates
body: We are currently, as of this moment, using 0-based coordinates. JBrowse 1 is 1-based

title: "share" UI, session from URL
body:
scope of this issue has changed to just be the "share" UI.

"file -> share session" will pop up a drawer widget or popup with sharing options.


===============================================

Given that there can be more than just a simple location for example in a given view, a more complex session might need encoding

The simplistic &data= and &loc= URL navigation has been quite valuable in the past and would be worth preserving in some type of way too (moved to #348)

title: multi-zoom-level linear view
body:
Make a mult-level view can show 2 or more zoom levels simultaneously, linking them with polygons, and drawing tracks on any of them. Could do this by having several "child" LGVs (with overviews turned off), or by just implementing a multi-level view from scratch.

```
====|=|=========
   /   \
=|===========|==
 /            \
===============
```

Rob's off-the-cuff guess is that implementing from scratch would be the easiest and get the best results.

title: Add framework for "remote" tracks
body: "Remote" tracks will be those on a server, connected hub, etc. They'll be "static" in the sense that you won't be able to edit the configurations, but there will be an easy way to copy them over to your own tracks, and the copy can be edited and saved freely.

title: Get rid of lint warnings, re-enable build failure of lint warnings on CI
body:
After this, lint warning will cause a build failure when running on CI again.

Resolves #38

title: Make some devDependency versions more flexible.
body: Like @cmdcolin noticed, many of the devDependencies were pinned to very specific versions instead of the `^` ranges since that's how create-react-app put them when it ejected. This opens up most of those to what seems to be more standard ranges. I'm working on setting up [Greenkeeper](https://greenkeeper.io/), and using that we can make sure that no updates within these ranges break anything. It also allows Yarn to be more flexible, which will hopefully help keep our bundle size down.

title: Package Material Icons font ourselves instead of pulling from CDN

Pulled in latest service worker code from create-react-app. Also added "location" to the web worker polyfill.

title: Parser and format for synteny data types
body:
http://dagchainer.sourceforge.net/


You can see the output file looks like this

```
1       At1g01010       3760    5630    1       At1g02230       436775  433031  1.3e-45
1       At1g01010       3760    5630    1       At1g02250       439559  437951  1.5e-37
1       At1g01010       3760    5630    3       At3g04420       1172846 1174301 1.9e-33
1       At1g01010       3760    5630    4       At4g01520       659178  656407  5.6e-34
1       At1g01010       3760    5630    4       At4g01540       672629  670483  2.8e-36
1       At1g01010       3760    5630    4       At4g01550       676225  674025  1.5e-44
1       At1g01020       8666    7729    4       At4g01510       642683  644190  2.6e-33
1       At1g01030       12940   11864   2       At2g36080       15158490        15155691        1.2e-39
1       At1g01030       12940   11864   2       At2g46870       19268382        19269314        6.2e-56
```


This is sort of a "2D" data format and if we need to query in 2D format it might be worth looking at something like pairix? https://github.com/4dn-dcic/pairix Or some other format. Could also parse entire file client side if it is small enough

Scrolling side to side on the BAM track produces repeated errors of this type

```
Uncaught Error: [mobx-state-tree][error] You are trying to read or write to an object that is no longer part of a state tree. (Object type was 'BlockState'). Either detach nodes first, or don't use objects after removing / replacing them in the tree.
    at ObjectNode$$1.assertAlive (mobx-state-tree.module.js:1576)
    at ObservableValue$$1.ObjectNode$$1._this.unbox [as dehancer] (mobx-state-tree.module.js:1359)
    at ObservableValue$$1.dehanceValue (mobx.module.js:762)
    at ObservableValue$$1.get (mobx.module.js:822)
    at ObservableObjectAdministration$$1.read (mobx.module.js:3936)
    at Object.get [as key] (mobx.module.js:4199)
```

title: Enable coverage reports
body: Would be good to enable something like [codecov](https://codecov.io/). Probably don't need to focus on getting really high coverage right now while everything is new, but would be a good reminder to keep writing tests.

title: Create TrackDB parser
body: Need a parser for [trackDb.txt](https://genome.ucsc.edu/goldenpath/help/trackDb/trackDbHub.html) files in order to be able to connect to track hubs. It's probably complex enough that we'll want to put it in its own NPM module. We'll see once it's written.

title: spring-based animated MST properties
body:
flowAnimator in the rbuels_junk branch has the beginnings of this: https://github.com/GMOD/jbrowse-components/compare/rbuels_junk?expand=1#diff-c6daf6500d7e92631a04b09422fde771

Basically I envision an MST model that has a current value, a stiffness, and a damping, and is updated with some kind of flow action that will animate the current value to the new target.

Basically an MST version of https://github.com/chenglou/react-motion

title: Add a main menu bar

This adds a main menu bar that includes two built-in entries ("Help" and "About") and can be extended to add other entries.

The built-in entries each include a drawer widget that they open when clicked.

Closes #5

title: implement configuration editing

when you hit the 'configure' button on something, that button stays down/active, and a configuration editor for that thing pops up in the side drawer.

configuration edits are validated as they are input, and if they are valid, they take effect immediately upon typing

Can possibly try https://github.com/casperlamboo/canvas-webworker#readme, or try porting the remote canvas rendering stuff that I implemented in the old 2.x branch

title: Fix up lint warnings

title: mini-css-extract-plugin and worker-loader fail webpack child compilation

Currently `workerPolyfill.js` works for the dev builds, but not for prod since it uses a different library (mini-css-extract-plugin). Need to try to get that working.

mini-css-extract-plugin and worker-loader both run as child compilers, and create-react-app doesn't handle errors in child compilers all that well.

title: detect misbehaving workers and replace them

If a web worker is not responding, terminate it, start a new one, and add it to the pool.

Probably want to just add a ping() rpc method to render.worker.js and call it from the main thread at some interval

title: Create sample non-core build-time plugin
body:
All the plugins developed so far have been core plugins, so I decided to create and test a simple non-core menu bar for testing before I create the core Main Menu Bar.

I also added a Yeoman generator to generate this testing menu bar. It's working now in 9022ca02255c7fb0f8763cb8dcbdd5ee419f27af if you follow these steps:

1. `cd` into the jbrowse-web plugins dir
2. run `yo jbrowse` and follow the prompts
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/49412983-705c5d80-f73c-11e8-99c3-a60292115fc7.png)
3. add a few lines to the main `index.js`
```js
...
import HelloWorldMenuBar from './plugins/HelloWorldMenuBar'
...
jbrowse.pluginManager.addPlugin(new HelloWorldMenuBar())
...
model.addMenuBar('HelloWorldMenuBar')
...
```
4. yarn start
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/49413322-83bbf880-f73d-11e8-992a-a12e36e3b9ba.png)

It would be good to have an integration test that basically does what I showed in the steps above.

title: hierarchical track selector config options: collapse by default, sort ordering
body:
@rbuels I decided to not actually do any configs for the track selector until the stuff you're working on now gets merged.

I was just planning to do some simple configs to have categories be expanded or collapsed by default. We could probably do a category and track sorting config sometime too, but not sure if we want to add that quite yet.

title: Add track filter and tests to hierarchical track selector
Manage drawer and track widths
body: Closes #23

title: Manage drawer and track widths
body:
This is pretty much done in 1b2190043c78b2db4c1234a550b38193d1aa0f8e, just needs some tests. The drawer defaults to 25% of the window width, and the tracks automatically fill up the remaining space. The drawer can be dragged to resize it, and when the window is resized it tries to keep the drawer approximately the same proportion of the window width.

Possible idea: having an option where the drawer is disabled, but can still be temporarily rendered as some sort of pop-over in response to something like the "select tracks" button being clicked.

title: plugin bootstrapping and code generators
body: @rbuels I thought it would be nice to have a sample run-time plugin that does something basic that we could use to experiment with. I could work on this if you want, but I'd need a bit of direction since I'm not entirely sure how we are going to implement them.

body: Basically we just want to inform users if their browser is unsupported either by browser or feature detection

title: Change track model from array to map, add ability to show and hide tracks
body: I had to update the track model to be a map instead of an array so that the track selector can more easily interact with the tracks. I also added the ability to show and hide tracks. I still haven't added the actual track selector yet, but now that the track model is updated it will be a lot easier.

title: Get hierarchical track selector to display dummy text
body: @rbuels I decided I'm going to worry about the drawer and track positioning later and just get the components themselves working first. I want to try to get my changes merged with yours fairly often, though, so we can stay on the same page. This change just adds the drawer and enough stuff to just have the track selector display some dummy text. I'll start working on getting proper state for it next.

title: Add app bar menu with mst store
body:
@rbuels hopefully your branch hasn't diverged too much from this. I tried to alter your changes as little as possible and just add in stuff for some UI elements. I did make one change, though: at the bottom of `JBrowse.js` I switched out
```html
<App getViewType={this.getViewType} rootModel={this.model} />
```
for
```html
<Provider rootModel={this.model}>
  <App getViewType={this.getViewType} />
</Provider>
```

So that way any downstream component can grab the state by using something like
```js
@inject('rootModel')
@observer
class SomeComponentHere extends Component {}
```
which will cause `rootModel` to be inserted in to that component's `props`.

Implement dynamic imports?
body:
Since we want basically everything to be configurable, we're going to need a way to load things like plugins from user-defined sources. With [dynamic imports](https://reactjs.org/blog/2017/05/18/whats-new-in-create-react-app.html#code-splitting-with-dynamic-import), we can at least load custom React components, which is a good start.

Need to experiment and see if this will work well for us.

title: Fix service worker
body:
Right now if you do a production build and run it, the service worker throws an exception:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25592344/46691752-9dc0db00-cbd3-11e8-8243-bb4fdc57625c.png)

If we want to use service workers, we'll have to figure out what's going on here.

title: Update to create-react-app 2.0.3
body:
I mostly ended up rebuilding the app with 2.0.3 and then adding in our ESLint, webworker, and other stuff. Doesn't seem to be an easy way to bring in the changes otherwise (CRA docs confirm this). Basic idea is:
* Create a new CRA project
* Eject the project
* Compare all the files to the ones in the existing project and bring in changes that don't conflict with ones we've made
  * Right now we've added the webworker code to `config/webpack.config.dev.js` and `config/webpack.config.prod.js`, as well as the workaround in "output:" in those files to get webworkers to work.
  * package.json is the tricky one to do, since it's hard to tell what CRA changed and what we added manually.

On another note, I'm guessing that CRA doesn't support webworkers right now because Webpack4 has trouble with them (https://github.com/webpack/webpack/issues/6525). I bet once that gets resolved it will support webworkers and we might be able to un-eject.

Resolves #7

title: Upgrade create-react-app
body: Upgrade dependencies to match create-react-app v2.0.3. Document how this was done so we can pull in future updates.

title: make a hierarchical track selector
body: Takes a structure of just track names and ids, and the categories they go under, and make a react implementation of the hierarchical track selector, pretty much exactly like JBrowse 1.

title: make a menu bar
body:
takes a data structure of menu names and the callbacks to be executed for each, just returns a `<div>` that's appropriate for sticking at the top of an app.

should probably be implemented with some off-the-shelf react menu bar.

title: add first linear view
body:
first little linear view will just take some input of how things should be rendered, and render it. no mouse events or anything yet.

input:
* track configuration for every track that should be displayed.  all tracks in the input will be displayed (track selection is handled above this level)
* the reference sequences and ranges that should be displayed.  these will be laid out end to end.
* metadata about how it should be displayed 
  * the zoom level: base pairs per pixel
  * scale number bar configuration (on or off, maybe hints about scale frequency)

output:
* react rendering of the requested ranges laid out horizontally, and a column of track names on the left side

title: implement render worker as a web worker
body:
input: a request for a range, output: a rendering of the features in the range, and also the feature data itself

a render request contains:
* the reference sequence and range to render
* all relevant configuration for how it should be rendered, including URLs for the data, etc

the response contains:
* the rendering of the range
* appropriate metadata about the rendering (is it svg or canvas, what are its pixel dimensions, etc)
* the feature data itself (may be needed by the frontend for doing .... whatever)

should develop this in a way that the request and response could actually go from and to anywhere, so this could run in a web worker, or on the server side in an expressjs app

title: move jb2 react app into monorepo
create monorepo infrastructure
body:
This is going to have a bunch of highly inter-related components in it, so we probably should make it a monorepo.

using Lerna maybe. or just some little scripts.

includes:
* appropriate directory structure
* travis build for each component that runs its tests

will do deployments later

We would keep the Perl version of it in JBrowse 1 of course.
